TEXT.English: [TAB]The Karakhanids were a Turkic dynasty that ruled parts of Central Asia from the 9th through early 13th centuries. Their arrival in Transoxania signaled a definitive shift from Iranian to Turkic predominance in Central Asia, though the Karakhanids themselves gradually assimilated the local Perso-Arab Muslim culture. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Kara-Khanid Khanate was a confederation formed in the early 9th century by the Karluks, Yagmas, Chigils, and other Turkic peoples living in the Zhetysu, Western Tian Shan, and Western Xinjiang areas. By the mid-10th century, the Karakhanids had converted to Islam, and adopted Muslim names and honorifics while retaining Turkic regnal titles such as Khan, Khagan, Ilek and Tegin. Later on their rulers adopted the title sultan, though as was common of Turkic and Mongol nomads the Kara-Khanid state remained divided into appanages. By 950, they had absorbed Kashgar and were waging religious war against their Buddhist and Tengrist neighbors, reportedly prompting a mass conversion of Turks in the year 960.[PARAGRAPH:1]Starting in 990 the Karakhanids began full scale invasions of the Samanid domains. By 999, the Samanids had been largely destroyed and their lands split between the Karakhanids and the Ghaznavids. In 1006, the Buddhist Kingdom of Khotan was conquered, and the Kara-Khanid state was at its greatest extent and arguable peak. Early in the 11th century however, the unity of the Kara-Khanid dynasty was fractured by frequent internal warfare, and the state was eventually split into two independent parts. This disunity would contribute to the Karakhanids being successively vassalized or conquered by their more powerful neighbors, including the Seljuks and the Kara Khitai. They were finally extinguised in the early 13th century by the the Khwarezmshah, the Kara Khitai, and the Mongols.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Shaybanids are the patrilineal descendants of Shayban (Shiban), the fifth son of Jochi and grandson of Genghis Khan. Until the mid-14th century, they acknowledged the authority of the descendants of Batu Khan and Orda Khan, such as Uzbeg Khan. The Shaybanid horde was converted to Islam in 1282 and gradually assumed the name of Uzbeks.[PARAGRAPH:1]As the lineages of Batu and Orda died out in the course of the great civil wars of the 14th century, the Shaybanids under Abu'l-Khayr Khan declared themselves the only legitimate successors to Jochi and put forward claims to the whole of his enormous ulus, which included parts of Siberia and Kazakhstan. Their rivals were the Timurids, who claimed descent from Jochi's thirteenth son by a concubine. Several decades of strife left the Timurids in control of the Great Horde and its successor states in Europe, namely, the Khanates of Kazan, Astrakhan, and Crimea.[PARAGRAPH:1]However, the Shaybanids under Muhammad Shaybani were able to wrest control of Samarkand, Bukhara and (for a time) Herat from the Timurids, establishing the Shaybanid dynasty as rulers of the independent Khanates of Bukhora and Khwarezm (Khiva).

TEXT.English: [H1]Ali ibn Hasan[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ruler of the Western Karakhanids[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 1020 - 1034[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Ali ibn Hasan, also known as Harun Bughra Khan and best known as Ali-Tegin, was the ruler of the Transoxiana branch of the Karakhanids. Seizing power with the help of a group of Oghuz Turks, he quickly captured Bukhara and soon occupied all of Sogdia. He become quite a powerful and influential figure in the region, but spent much of his reign quarreling with the Ghaznavids and members of his own family. He died in 1034, having largely been able to preserve his power base in Transoxiana.
TEXT.French: [H1]Merkurios[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ruler of Nubian kingdom of Makuria[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 697 - c.722[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Merkurios was ruler of the Nubian kingdom of Makuria. During his reign Makuria absorbed the Nubian kingdom of Nobatia. The first year of Merkurios' reign can be dated by an inscription on the foundation stone in Faras, which was dated to AD 707, and also to Merkurios' eleventh regnal year. In 710, Merkurios erected an inscription at Taifa, which indicates that his kingdom had united with Nobatia by that date. John the Deacon, an Egyptian Christian writing around 768, described Merkurios as the "New Constantine", which means that Merkurios likely played some important role in the Nubian church.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Kara Khitai was a Central Asian empire ruled by the Khitan Yelu clan. The dynasty was founded by Yelu Dashi, who led the remnants of the Liao dynasty to Central Asia after fleeing the Jurchen conquest of their teritory in China.[PARAGRAPH:1]When the Jurchens, once vassals of the Khitans, allied with the Song dynasty and overthrew the Liao, Yelu Dashi led a group of nomadic Khitans west by way of Mongolia. Dashi recruited Khitans and other tribes to form an army, and in 1134 captured Balasagun from the Kara-Khanid Khanate, which marked the start of the Kara Khitai empire in Central Asia. The Khitan forces were soon joined by 10,000 additional Khitans, who had been subjects of the Kara-Khanid Khanate. The Khitans then conquered Kashgar, Khotan, and Beshbalik. They defeated the Western Kara-Khanid Khanate at Khujand in 1137, eventually leading to Kara Khitai control over the Fergana Valley. On September 9, 1141, the Khitai won the Battle of Qatwan against the Western Kara-Khanids and the Seljuk Empire, which allowed them to gain control over Transoxiana.[PARAGRAPH:1]When Yelu Dashi died his wife Xiao Tabuyan became regent for their son. The son, Yelu Yilie, ruled from 1150 to 1163, to be succeeded by his sister, Yelu Pusuwan. She fell in love with her husband's younger brother, Xiao Fuguzhi. Both were killed in 1177 by her husband's father, Xiao Wolila, who then placed his son Yelu Zhilugu on the throne. During this time, the empire became weakened by rebellions and internal wars among its vassals. The empire contracted in the northeast when, in 1175, the Naimans east of the Altai and the Qangli north of Lake Balkhash made a partial submission to the Jurchens. In the west there were many conflicts with Khwarezm involving non-payment of tribute and rival claimants to the throne, though this did lead to some territorial expansion at Khwarezm's expense. In the south the Kara-Khanid vassals were lightly held and engaged in various conflicts with one another and their neighbors.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1208, a Naiman prince, Kuchlug, fled his homeland after being defeated by Mongols. Kuchlug was welcomed into the empire of the Kara Khitans, and was allowed to marry Yelu Zhilugu's daughter. However, in 1211, Kuchlug revolted, and later captured Yelu Zhilugu while the latter was hunting. Zhilugu was allowed to remain as the nominal ruler but died two years later, and many historians regard his death as the end of the Kara Khitan empire. In 1216, Genghis Khan dispatched his general Jebe to pursue Kuchlug; Kuchlug fled, but in 1218, he was finally captured and decapitated. The Mongols fully conquered the former territories of the Kara Khitans in 1220.

TEXT.English: [H1]Yelu Dashi[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Gurkhan of the Kara Khitai[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 1124 - 1143[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Yelu Dashi was the founder of the Kara Khitai, also known as the Western Liao dynasty. He initially ruled as king from 1124 to 1132, then as emperor from 1132 to 1143. He fled the Liao dynasty in northern China as it was on the verge of destruction by the Jurchen Jin dynasty, in 1124 leading a band of his fellow Khitans northwest to the Liao garrison town of Kedun. Emperor Tianzuo of Liao was captured by the Jurchens in 1125, and the Liao dynasty was ended. As the Jurchens grew stronger, the disorganized lands to the west became an increasingly attractive prospect.[PARAGRAPH:1]On March 13, 1130, Dashi headed west with less than 20,000 men. After some minor fighting with the Yenisei Kyrgyz he established a new base on the Emil River about 1500 km west of Kedun. At about the same time, he was welcomed by the ruler of the Kingdom of Qocho who became his ally or vassal. In 1131 or 1132, he was proclaimed Gurkhan by his followers, establishing his authority over Almaliq and Qayaliq. The Eastern Karakanid ruler of Balasaghun, Ibrahim II b. Ahmad, invited him to help fight the Karluks and Kankalis, and in 1134 Dashi took the opportunuty to depose him.[PARAGRAPH:1]Dashi made Balasaghun his new capital, and took over 16,000 Khitans that had served the old ruler. He spread his power over Jetysu, later gaining control over what is now Xinjiang. In May 1137 he defeated a Western Karakhanid ruler at Khujand and then spent several years consolidating his power in the Ferghana valley and Tashkent. He died in 1143, two years after his victory at Qatwan, as the master of much of Central Asia.

Several decades of strife left the Timurids in control of the Great Horde and its successor states in Europe, namely, the Khanates of Kazan, Astrakhan, and Crimea.[PARAGRAPH:1]However, the Shaybanids under Muhammad Shaybani were able to wrest control of Samarkand, Bukhara and (for a time) Herat from the Timurids, establishing the Shaybanid dynasty as rulers of the independent Khanates of Bukhora and Khwarezm (Khiva).

TEXT.English: [H1]Duwa[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Khan of the Chagatai Khanate[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 1282 - 1307[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Duwa was the second son of Chagatai khan Baraq. Kaidu, who held much of the power in the khanate, appointed Duwa as ruler in an effort to gain peace between himself and the sons of Baraq. This ensured the loyalty of the Chaghataids from that point until Kaidu's death. In early 1295, Kaidu's attempts to spread his power within the Ilkhanate gave Duwa an excuse to invade that Mongol kingdom. Supported by Kaidu's son Sarban, he invaded Khurasan and Mazandaran while the Ilkhanid commanders were involved in a succession struggle far to the west. For eight months he stayed in Mazandaran; when he left, he pillaged many cities on the way back. Duwa attempted to convince the Kartids of Herat to defect to his side, but they refused. Due to a lack of progress he was recalled by Kaidu back to Central Asia, and the campaign ended.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the east, Duwa was engaged in constant conflict with the Yuan dynasty. When Kaidu died after battling against the Yuan, the political situation changed. Duwa ignored Kaidu's choice of successor, Orus, and instead picked Kaidu's firstborn son Chapar to take his father's place. Chapar was enthroned in 1303, thanks to Duwa's effort. Duwa insisted Chapar submit to Temur Khan, and around 1304 a general peace among the Mongol states was declared, finally ending the Kaidu-Kublai war. The settlement favored Duwa much more than Chapar, a fact which set a rift between the two. Fighting broke out between the troops of both parties, and the sons of Kaidu were ultimately defeated by Duwa with assistance from the Yuan. In 1307 Duwa died, to be succeeded by his own son Konchek.
TEXT.French: [H1]Merkurios[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ruler of Nubian kingdom of Makuria[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 697 - c.722[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Merkurios was ruler of the Nubian kingdom of Makuria. During his reign Makuria absorbed the Nubian kingdom of Nobatia. The first year of Merkurios' reign can be dated by an inscription on the foundation stone in Faras, which was dated to AD 707, and also to Merkurios' eleventh regnal year. In 710, Merkurios erected an inscription at Taifa, which indicates that his kingdom had united with Nobatia by that date. John the Deacon, an Egyptian Christian writing around 768, described Merkurios as the "New Constantine", which means that Merkurios likely played some important role in the Nubian church.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Byzantine Empire was first known as the eastern Roman empire, when Constantine I relocated the Roman capital from Rome to Constantinople and his successor Valentinian I made the division between Western and Eastern Empire official. When barbarians sacked Rome and defeated the western armies a century later, the Byzantine Empire was the final bulwark of Roman civilization to stand against the increasing pressure from European barbarians to the north and Persia in the east. Byzantine government was based largely on that of Rome, although unlike Roman emperors a Byzantine emperor was elected by a threefold vote of the senate, the people, and the army. To govern the empire, Byzantine emperors relied on a labyrinthine system of advisors, ministries, and offices -- hence the pejorative "Byzantine" today, used to describe overly hierarchical and intrigue-prone systems.[PARAGRAPH:1]Byzantine military reform came mostly during the reign of Heraclius, the son of Africa's imperial governor. Arriving in Constantinople to restore order after a disastrous interregnum (marred by assassination, intrigue, and civil disorder), Heraclius placed tremendous power in the hands of the army. It was also during the reign of Heraclius that Greek fire, the medieval precursor to napalm, was invented, and used extensively by Byzantine ships called dromons in battle against Persian and barbarian ships. Heraclius also ordered the army to emulate the barbarian horse archers previously employed as mercenaries; the result was the cataphract, a heavily armored cavalryman who could fight with bow, sword, or lance.[PARAGRAPH:1]After two hundred years of defeats and erosion, during which Byzantium lost virtually all of its possessions south of Asia Minor, the ascension of Basil I to the imperial throne in 867 marked a turnaround in Byzantine military fortunes. Byzantine armies beat back the Arabs in the east and south, and despite several humiliating defeats at the hands of the Muslims, reasserted dominance over the eastern Mediterranean. Syria, along with the key city of Antioch, also came back to Byzantine control, along with Armenia and large parts of the Balkans. For 150 years, Byzantium enjoyed civil prosperity and military victory.[PARAGRAPH:1]But new adversaries appeared where the old ones had fallen. In 1071, Byzantium suffered two catastrophic defeats -- they lost their last toehold in Italy to the Normans, who had earlier sacked Constantinople during a crusade gone awry. In the east, the Turks broke Byzantine power in Asia Minor forever at Manzikert, and the once dominant empire was reduced to a rump state comprising Constantinople, parts of the Balkans, and a few remaining provinces in western Turkey. The heart of it, though, was now ruled by the Turks. Nonetheless, during this time, art, religion, and philosophy flourished within the walls of Constantinople. It was as if the learned men of Byzantium were unaware of the threats lurking outside. Another fateful event, the Schism of 1054, finalized the separation between the Byzantine (Eastern) and Catholic (western) churches. This would lead to deep suspicion between the two churches, and western reluctance to assist Byzantium against the Turks years later.[PARAGRAPH:1]Eventually Byzantium was forced to resort to bribery and compromise with the Turks and the new western powers that coveted its territory and former influence. In 1421, after a hundred years of co-existence with the Turks, the new sultan Murad II revoked all of the arrangements that had existed between the two empires. As a last resort, the Byzantine emperor begged Rome for help, but the Christian army sent to fight the Turks was utterly defeated. In 1453, the Turks assaulted Constantinople itself, and the walls that had stood for over a thousand years finally fell, marking the end of the Byzantine Empire.

Als die Barbaren ein Jahrhundert spter Rom plnderten und die westlichen Armeen besiegten, war das Byzantinische Reich das letzte Bollwerk der rmischen Zivilisation, das dem zunehmenden Druck europischer Barbaren im Norden und Persiens im Osten standhielt. Die byzantinische Regierung basierte grtenteils auf der rmischen Regierung, obwohl ein byzantinischer Kaiser im Gegensatz zu rmischen Kaisern durch eine dreifache Abstimmung des Senats, des Volkes und der Armee gewhlt wurde. Um das Reich zu regieren, sttzten sich die byzantinischen Kaiser auf ein labyrinthisches System aus Beratern, Ministerien und mtern daher das abwertende byzantinisch, das heute verwendet wird, um bermig hierarchische und intrigenanfllige Systeme zu beschreiben.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die byzantinische Militrreform erfolgte grtenteils whrend der Herrschaft von Heraklius, dem Sohn des kaiserlichen Statthalters von Afrika. Whrend der Herrschaft von Heraklius wurde auch das griechische Feuer, der mittelalterliche Vorlufer von Napalm, erfunden und von byzantinischen Schiffen, sogenannten Dromonen, im Kampf gegen persische und barbarische Schiffe ausgiebig eingesetzt. Heraklius befahl der Armee auerdem, den barbarischen berittenen Bogenschtzen nachzueifern, die zuvor als Sldner eingesetzt worden waren. Byzantinische Armeen schlugen die Araber im Osten und Sden zurck und behaupteten trotz mehrerer demtigender Niederlagen durch die Muslime erneut die Vorherrschaft ber das stliche Mittelmeer. Auch Syrien gelangte zusammen mit der Schlsselstadt Antiochia, Armenien und groen Teilen des Balkans wieder unter byzantinische Kontrolle. Byzanz erlebte 150 Jahre lang zivilen Wohlstand und militrische Siege.[PARAGRAPH:1]Aber neue Gegner tauchten dort auf, wo die alten gefallen waren. Im Jahr 1071 erlitt Byzanz zwei katastrophale Niederlagen es verlor seinen letzten Halt in Italien an die Normannen, die zuvor Konstantinopel whrend eines fehlgeschlagenen Kreuzzugs geplndert hatten. Im Osten brachen die Trken bei Manzikert die byzantinische Macht in Kleinasien fr immer, und das einst dominierende Reich wurde auf einen Rumpfstaat reduziert, der Konstantinopel, Teile des Balkans und einige verbleibende Provinzen in der Westtrkei umfasste. Das Herzstck davon wurde jedoch nun von den Trken beherrscht. Dennoch blhten in dieser Zeit Kunst, Religion und Philosophie innerhalb der Mauern von Konstantinopel auf. Es war, als ob die gelehrten Mnner von Byzanz sich der Bedrohungen, die drauen lauerten, nicht bewusst waren. Ein weiteres schicksalhaftes Ereignis, das Schisma von 1054, vollendete die Trennung zwischen der byzantinischen (stlichen) und der katholischen (westlichen) Kirche. Dies wrde zu tiefem Misstrauen zwischen den beiden Kirchen und zu einer Zurckhaltung des Westens fhren, Byzanz Jahre spter im Kampf gegen die Trken zu untersttzen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Schlielich war Byzanz gezwungen, auf Bestechung und Kompromisse mit den Trken und den neuen westlichen Mchten zurckzugreifen, die sein Territorium begehrten und frherer Einfluss. Im Jahr 1421, nach hundertjhriger Koexistenz mit den Trken, widerrief der neue Sultan Murad II. alle zwischen den beiden Reichen bestehenden Vereinbarungen. Im Jahr 1453 griffen die Trken Konstantinopel selbst an und die Mauern, die ber tausend Jahre lang gestanden hatten, fielen schlielich, was das Ende des Byzantinischen Reiches bedeutete.

TEXT.English: [H1]Basil II[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emperor of the Byzantine Empire[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 958 - December 15, 1025[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Basil II, known in his time as Basil the Porphyrogenitus and Basil the Young to distinguish him from his ancestor Basil I the Macedonian, was a Byzantine emperor from the Macedonian dynasty who reigned from 10 January 976 to 15 December 1025.[PARAGRAPH:1]The first part of his long reign was dominated by civil war against powerful generals from the Anatolian aristocracy. Following their submission, Basil oversaw the stabilization and expansion of the Byzantine Empire's eastern frontier, and above all, the final and complete subjugation of Bulgaria, the Empire's foremost European foe, after a prolonged struggle. For this he was nicknamed by later authors as "the Bulgar-slayer", by which he is popularly known. At his death, the Empire stretched from Southern Italy to the Caucasus and from the Danube to the borders of Palestine, its greatest territorial extent since the Muslim conquests, four centuries earlier.[PARAGRAPH:1]Despite near-constant warfare, Basil also showed himself a capable administrator, reducing the power of the great land-owning families who dominated the Empire's administration and military, and filling the Empire's treasury. Of far-reaching importance was Basil's decision to offer the hand of his daughter Anna to Vladimir I of Kiev in exchange for military support, which led to the Christianization of the Kievan Rus', and the incorporation of Russia within the Byzantine cultural sphere.

Dezember 1025[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD] Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Basilius II., zu seiner Zeit als Basilius der Porphyrogenitus und Basilius der Junge bekannt, um ihn von seinem Vorfahren Basilius I., dem Mazedonier, zu unterscheiden, war ein byzantinischer Kaiser aus der mazedonischen Dynastie, der ab 10 regierte Januar 976 bis 15. Dezember 1025.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der erste Teil seiner langen Regierungszeit war geprgt vom Brgerkrieg gegen mchtige Generle der anatolischen Aristokratie. Nach ihrer Unterwerfung berwachte Basilius die Stabilisierung und Erweiterung der Ostgrenze des Byzantinischen Reiches und vor allem die endgltige und vollstndige Unterwerfung Bulgariens, des grten europischen Feindes des Reiches, nach einem langen Kampf. Aus diesem Grund wurde er von spteren Autoren als Bulgarentter bezeichnet, unter dem er im Volksmund bekannt ist. Bei seinem Tod erstreckte sich das Reich von Sditalien bis zum Kaukasus und von der Donau bis zu den Grenzen Palstinas, seiner grten territorialen Ausdehnung seit den muslimischen Eroberungen vier Jahrhunderte zuvor.[PARAGRAPH:1]Trotz nahezu stndiger Kriegsfhrung zeigte sich auch Basilius selbst ein fhiger Verwalter, der die Macht der groen Landbesitzerfamilien, die die Verwaltung und das Militr des Imperiums dominierten, reduzierte und die Schatzkammer des Imperiums fllte. Von weitreichender Bedeutung war Basilius Entscheidung, Wladimir I. von Kiew die Hand seiner Tochter Anna als Gegenleistung fr militrische Untersttzung anzubieten, was zur Christianisierung der Kiewer Rus und zur Eingliederung Russlands in den byzantinischen Kulturkreis fhrte.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Kingdom of Makuria was a kingdom located in what is today Northern Sudan and Southern Egypt. It was one of a group of Nubian kingdoms that emerged during the decline of the Aksumite Empire, which it had been part of from approximately 4BC to AD 950. Makuria originally covered the area along the Nile River from the Third Cataract to somewhere between the Fifth and Sixth Cataracts. It also had control over the trade routes, mines, and oases to the east and west. Its capital was Dongola (Old Nubian: Tungul), and the kingdom is sometimes known by the name of its capital.[PARAGRAPH:1]By the end of the 6th century it had converted to Christianity, but in the 7th century Egypt was conquered by the Islamic armies, and Nubia was cut off from the rest of Christendom. In 651 an Arab army invaded, but it was repulsed and a treaty known as the baqt was signed creating a relative peace between the two sides that lasted until the 13th century. Makuria expanded, annexing its northern neighbour Nobatia either at the time of the Arab invasion or during the reign of King Merkurios. The period from roughly 750 to 1150 saw the kingdom stable and prosperous, in what has been called the "Golden Age". Increased aggression from Egypt, and internal discord led to the state's collapse in the 14th century.

TEXT.English: [H1]Merkurios[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ruler of Nubian kingdom of Makuria[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 697 - c.722[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Merkurios was ruler of the Nubian kingdom of Makuria. During his reign Makuria absorbed the Nubian kingdom of Nobatia. The first year of Merkurios' reign can be dated by an inscription on the foundation stone in Faras, which was dated to AD 707, and also to Merkurios' eleventh regnal year. In 710, Merkurios erected an inscription at Taifa, which indicates that his kingdom had united with Nobatia by that date. John the Deacon, an Egyptian Christian writing around 768, described Merkurios as the "New Constantine", which means that Merkurios likely played some important role in the Nubian church.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Arab descendants of Abbas, an uncle of the Prophet Muhammad, began a rebellion against the unpopular Umayyad Caliphate in 747 AD. Within a few years they had massacred most of the Umayyad dynasty and established the Abbasid Caliphate, which would last for the next five hundred years. At its greatest extent in the late 8th century, the Caliphate controlled Morocco on the Atlantic Ocean to central Asia as far as the borders of India. They also contributed much toward scientific progress at a time when European culture was stagnant and backwards. [PARAGRAPH:1]One of the first things the Abbasids did was to move the administrative center away from Damascus to Mesopotamia. In 762 AD the second Abbasid caliph, al-Mansur, began the construction of a new capital city. The site he chose was on the banks of the Tigris at a small village called Baghdad. The new city was originally built with three concentric round walls. The caliphate palace and parks occupied the center and were surrounded by a ring of military barracks and offices, which in turn were surrounded by housing. Suburbs quickly appeared beyond the outer wall, and by 800 AD the city had half a million residents, and would continue to grow over the next several centuries. Because it was the principal trade center to the silks of China and the spices of India, Baghdad became the wealthiest city in the world at its height. It was filled with marble palaces of several stories, gardens, beautiful mosques, immense main avenues, and aqueducts. [PARAGRAPH:1]Such wealth attracted invaders. By the early 10th century Buyid mercenaries from Iran gained temporal power, sacking parts of Baghdad in 945 AD, and subordinating the caliph to a puppet with spiritual authority at best. The Buyids in turn were pushed out by nomadic Seljuk Turks from Central Asia. The Muslim Seljuks also retained the caliph, respecting his symbolic role, but they were not averse to replacing him with another as desired. [PARAGRAPH:1]After the Crusades eroded the Seljuk Empire in the 12th century, the Abbasid Caliphate regained secular power over southern Mesopotamia. However, within a hundred years, a new and merciless invader from the Asian steppes appeared. In 1258, the Mongols conquered Baghdad. They massacred hundreds of thousands of its citizens, razed the city, destroyed its irrigation system, and trampled Caliph al-Musta'sim to death with horses, thus bringing the Abbasid dynasty to a violent conclusion.

The caliphate palace and parks occupied the center and were surrounded by a ring of military barracks and offices, which in turn were surrounded by housing. Suburbs quickly appeared beyond the outer wall, and by 800 AD the city had half a million residents, and would continue to grow over the next several centuries. Because it was the principal trade center to the silks of China and the spices of India, Baghdad became the wealthiest city in the world at its height. It was filled with marble palaces of several stories, gardens, beautiful mosques, immense main avenues, and aqueducts. [PARAGRAPH:1]Such wealth attracted invaders. By the early 10th century Buyid mercenaries from Iran gained temporal power, sacking parts of Baghdad in 945 AD, and subordinating the caliph to a puppet with spiritual authority at best. The Buyids in turn were pushed out by nomadic Seljuk Turks from Central Asia. The Muslim Seljuks also retained the caliph, respecting his symbolic role, but they were not averse to replacing him with another as desired. [PARAGRAPH:1]After the Crusades eroded the Seljuk Empire in the 12th century, the Abbasid Caliphate regained secular power over southern Mesopotamia. However, within a hundred years, a new and merciless invader from the Asian steppes appeared. In 1258, the Mongols conquered Baghdad. They massacred hundreds of thousands of its citizens, razed the city, destroyed its irrigation system, and trampled Caliph al-Musta'sim to death with horses, thus bringing the Abbasid dynasty to a violent conclusion.

TEXT.English: [H1]Harun al-Rashid[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Abbasid Caliph of Baghdad[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] March 17, 763 - March 24, 809[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Harun al-Rashid was the fifth and most famous Abbasid Caliph. He ruled from 786 to 809, and his time was marked by scientific, cultural and religious prosperity. Art and music also flourished significantly during his reign. He established the library Bayt al-Hikma ("House of Wisdom"). [PARAGRAPH:1]Since Harun was intellectually, politically and militarily resourceful, his life and the court over which he held sway have been the subject of many tales: some are factual but most are believed to be fictitious. An example of what is known to be factual is the story of the Clock that was among various presents that Harun had delightfully sent to Charlemagne. The presents were carried by the returning Frankish mission that came to offer Harun friendship in 799. Charlemagne and his retinue deemed the clock to be a conjuration for the sounds it emanates and the tricks it displays every time an hour ticks. Among what is known to be fictional is the famous The Book of One Thousand and One Nights containing many stories that are fantasized by Harun's magnificent court, and even Harun al-Rashid himself. The family of Barmakids which played a deciding role in establishing the Abbasid Caliphate declined gradually during his rule.

Er regierte von 786 bis 809 und seine Zeit war von wissenschaftlichem, kulturellem und religisem Wohlstand geprgt. Auch Kunst und Musik blhten whrend seiner Herrschaft erheblich auf. [PARAGRAPH:1]Da Harun intellektuell, politisch und militrisch einfallsreich war, waren sein Leben und der Hof, ber den er herrschte, Gegenstand vieler Geschichten: Einige sind sachlich, die meisten gelten jedoch als frei erfunden. Ein Beispiel dafr, was bekanntermaen wahr ist, ist die Geschichte der Uhr, die zu den verschiedenen Geschenken gehrte, die Harun entzckenderweise an Karl den Groen geschickt hatte. Die Geschenke wurden von der zurckkehrenden frnkischen Mission berbracht, die 799 kam, um Harun die Freundschaft anzubieten. Karl der Groe und sein Gefolge betrachteten die Uhr als eine Beschwrung aufgrund der Gerusche, die sie ausstrahlt, und der Tricks, die sie jedes Mal zeigt, wenn eine Stunde tickt. Zu den bekanntermaen fiktionalen Werken gehrt das berhmte Buch aus Tausendundeiner Nacht, das viele Geschichten enthlt, die sich Haruns prchtiger Hofstaat und sogar Harun al-Rashid selbst ausgedacht haben. Die Familie der Barmakiden, die eine entscheidende Rolle bei der Errichtung des abbasidischen Kalifats spielte, verfiel whrend seiner Herrschaft allmhlich.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Zengid (or Zangid) dynasty was a Muslim dynasty of Turkic origin, which ruled parts of Syria and northern Iraq on behalf of the Seljuk Empire. The dynasty was founded by Imad ad-Din Zengi (or Zangi), who became the Seljuk Atabeg (governor) of Mosul in 1127. He quickly became the chief Turkish potentate in Northern Syria and Iraq, taking Aleppo from the squabbling Ortoqid emirs in 1128, and capturing the County of Edessa from the Crusaders in 1144. This latter feat made Zengi a hero in the Muslim world, but he was assassinated by a slave two years later, in 1146.[PARAGRAPH:1]On Zengi's death, his territories were divided, with Mosul and his lands in Iraq going to his eldest son Saif ad-Din Ghazi I, and Aleppo and Edessa falling to his second son, Nur ad-Din Mahmud. Nur ad-Din proved to be as competent as his father. In 1149 he defeated and killed Prince Raymond of Antioch in battle, and the next year conquered the remnants of the County of Edessa west of the Euphrates River. In 1154 he capped off these successes by his capture of Damascus from the Burid Emirs who ruled it.[PARAGRAPH:1]Now ruling from Damascus, Nur ad-Din's success continued. Another Prince of Antioch, Raynald of Chtillon was captured, and the territories of that Principality greatly reduced. In the 1160s, Nur ad-Din's attention was mostly held by a competition with the King of Jerusalem, Amalric I, for control of the Fatimid Caliphate of Egypt. Ultimately, Nur ad-Din's Kurdish general Shirkuh was successful in conquering Egypt in 1169, but Shirkuh's nephew and successor as Governor of Egypt, Saladin, rejected Nur ad-Din's control.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nur ad-Din was preparing to invade Egypt to bring Saladin under control when he unexpectedly died in 1174. His son and successor As-Salih Ismail al-Malik was only a child, and was forced to flee to Aleppo, which he ruled until 1181, when he was murdered and replaced by his relation, the Atabeg of Mosul. Saladin conquered Aleppo two years later, ending Zengid rule in Syria.[PARAGRAPH:1]Zengid princes continued to rule in Northern Iraq well into the 13th Century, ruling Mosul until 1234; their rule did not come finally to an end until 1250.

Er wurde schnell zum wichtigsten trkischen Potentaten in Nordsyrien und im Irak und eroberte 1128 Aleppo von den streitenden Ortoqid-Emiren und die Eroberung der Grafschaft Edessa von den Kreuzfahrern im Jahr 1144. Diese letztere Leistung machte Zengi zu einem Helden in der muslimischen Welt, doch zwei Jahre spter, im Jahr 1146, wurde er von einem Sklaven ermordet.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nach Zengis Tod wurden seine Gebiete zerstrt wurden geteilt, wobei Mossul und seine Lndereien im Irak an seinen ltesten Sohn Saif ad-Din Ghazi I. gingen und Aleppo und Edessa an seinen zweiten Sohn Nur ad-Din Mahmud fielen. Nur ad-Din erwies sich als ebenso kompetent wie sein Vater. Im Jahr 1149 besiegte und ttete er Prinz Raymond von Antiochia in der Schlacht und eroberte im nchsten Jahr die berreste der Grafschaft Edessa westlich des Euphrat. Im Jahr 1154 krnte er diese Erfolge mit der Eroberung von Damaskus von den buridischen Emiren, die es regierten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nur ad-Dins Erfolg, der nun von Damaskus aus regierte, setzte sich fort. Ein weiterer Frst von Antiochien, Raynald von Chtillon, wurde gefangen genommen und die Gebiete dieses Frstentums stark verkleinert. In den 1160er Jahren galt Nur ad-Dins Aufmerksamkeit hauptschlich einem Wettbewerb mit dem Knig von Jerusalem, Amalrich I., um die Kontrolle ber das fatimidische Kalifat in gypten. Letztendlich gelang es Nur ad-Dins kurdischem General Shirkuh, gypten im Jahr 1169 zu erobern, aber Shirkuhs Neffe und Nachfolger als Gouverneur von gypten, Saladin, lehnte Nur ad-Dins Kontrolle ab.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nur ad-Din bereitete sich auf eine Invasion in gypten vor Saladin unter Kontrolle zu bringen, als er 1174 unerwartet starb. Sein Sohn und Nachfolger As-Salih Ismail al-Malik war noch ein Kind und musste nach Aleppo fliehen, wo er bis 1181 regierte, als er ermordet und durch seinen Nachfolger ersetzt wurde Beziehung, der Atabeg von Mossul. Saladin eroberte Aleppo zwei Jahre spter und beendete damit die Herrschaft der Zengiden in Syrien.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Frsten der Zengiden herrschten bis weit ins 13. Jahrhundert hinein im Nordirak und regierten Mossul bis 1234; Ihre Herrschaft endete erst 1250 endgltig.

TEXT.English: [H1]Nur ad-Din Zengi[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emir of Damascus and Aleppo[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] February 1118 - 15 May 1174[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Nur ad-Din was the second son of Imad ad-Din Zengi, the Turkish atabeg of Aleppo and Mosul, who was a devoted enemy of the crusader presence in Syria. After the assassination of his father, Nur ad-Din and his older brother Saif ad-Din Ghazi I divided the kingdom amongst themselves, with Nur ad-Din governing Aleppo and Saif ad-Din Ghazi establishing himself in Mosul. Almost as soon as he began his rule, Nur ad-Din attacked the Principality of Antioch, seizing several castles in the north of Syria, while at the same time he defeated an attempt by Joscelin II to recover the County of Edessa, which had been conquered by Zengi in 1144. [PARAGRAPH:1]It was Nur ad-Din's dream to unite the various Muslim forces between the Euphrates and the Nile to make a common front against the crusaders. In 1149 Nur ad-Din has been recognized as overlord of Mosul, so that the major cities of Mosul and Aleppo were united under one man. In 1154, the emir of Damascus was overthrown, the city was annexed to Zengid territory, and all Syria was unified under the authority of Nur ad-Din, from Edessa in the north to the Hauran in the south. [PARAGRAPH:1]As there was now nothing the crusaders could do in Syria, they were forced to look to the south, and after a series of wars they took Alexandira and Cairo from the weakened Fatimids. Nur ad-Din sent Shirkuh, his Kurdish general, to restore order. Shirkuh reclaimed Egypt and was made a vizier, later succeeded by his nephew Saladin. Nur ad-Din believed that he had accomplished his goal of uniting the Muslim states, but Saladin did not wish to be subject to his authority. [PARAGRAPH:1]When Nur ad-Din was on the verge of invading Egypt in 1174, he was seized by a fever due to complications from a peritonsillar abscess, and died at the age of 59. His young son As-Salih Ismail al-Malik became his legitimate heir, and Saladin declared himself his vassal, although he really planned to unify Syria and Egypt under his own rule. He married Nur ad-Din's widow, defeated the other claimants to the throne and took power in Syria in 1185, finally realizing Nur ad-Din's dream. [PARAGRAPH:1]According to William of Tyre, although Nur ad-Din was "a mighty persecutor of the Christian name and faith," he was also "a just prince, valiant and wise, and according to the traditions of his race, a religious man." Nur ad-Din was especially religious after his illness and his pilgrimage. He considered the crusaders foreigners in Muslim territory, who had come to Outremer to plunder the land and profane its sacred places. Nevertheless, he was tolerant of the Christians who lived under his authority, aside from the Armenians of Edessa and regarded the Emperor Manuel with deep respect. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nur ad-Din also constructed universities and mosques in all the cities he controlled. These universities were principally concerned with teaching the Qur'an and Hadith. Nur ad-Din himself enjoyed to have specialists read to him from the Hadith, and his professors even awarded him a diploma in Hadith narration. He had free hospitals constructed in his cities as well, and built caravanserais on the roads for travellers and pilgrims. He held court several times a week so that people could seek justice from him against his generals, governors, or other employees who had committed some crime. In the Muslim world he remains a legendary figure of military courage, piety, and modesty. Sir Steven Runciman said that he loved, above all else, justice.

Mai 1174[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Nur ad-Din war der zweite Sohn von Imad ad-Din Zengi, dem trkischen Atabeg von Aleppo und Mosul, der ein ergebener Feind der Kreuzfahrerprsenz in Syrien war. Nach der Ermordung seines Vaters Nur ad-Din und seines lteren Bruders Saif ad-Din Ghazi teilte ich das Knigreich untereinander auf, wobei Nur ad-Din Aleppo regierte und Saif ad-Din Ghazi sich in Mossul niederlie. Fast gleich zu Beginn seiner Herrschaft griff Nur ad-Din das Frstentum Antiochia an und eroberte mehrere Burgen im Norden Syriens, whrend er gleichzeitig einen Versuch von Joscelin II., die Grafschaft Edessa zurckzugewinnen, vereitelte 1144 von Zengi erobert. [PARAGRAPH:1]Es war Nur ad-Dins Traum, die verschiedenen muslimischen Streitkrfte zwischen Euphrat und Nil zu vereinen, um eine gemeinsame Front gegen die Kreuzfahrer zu bilden. Im Jahr 1149 wurde Nur ad-Din als Oberherr von Mossul anerkannt, sodass die Grostdte Mossul und Aleppo unter einem Mann vereint wurden. Im Jahr 1154 wurde der Emir von Damaskus gestrzt, die Stadt dem Gebiet der Zengiden angegliedert und ganz Syrien von Edessa im Norden bis Hauran im Sden unter der Herrschaft von Nur ad-Din vereint. [PARAGRAPH:1]Da die Kreuzfahrer nun in Syrien nichts mehr tun konnten, waren sie gezwungen, nach Sden zu blicken, und nach einer Reihe von Kriegen eroberten sie den geschwchten Fatimiden Alexandrira und Kairo. Nur ad-Din schickte Shirkuh, seinen kurdischen General, um die Ordnung wiederherzustellen. Shirkuh eroberte gypten zurck und wurde zum Wesir ernannt, dessen Nachfolger spter sein Neffe Saladin wurde. Nur ad-Din glaubte, sein Ziel, die muslimischen Staaten zu vereinen, erreicht zu haben, doch Saladin wollte sich seiner Autoritt nicht unterwerfen. [PARAGRAPH:1]Als Nur ad-Din im Jahr 1174 kurz davor stand, in gypten einzumarschieren, wurde er aufgrund von Komplikationen aufgrund eines Peritonsillarabszesses von Fieber befallen und starb im Alter von 59 Jahren. Sein kleiner Sohn As-Salih Ismail al -Malik wurde sein legitimer Erbe und Saladin erklrte sich zu seinem Vasallen, obwohl er eigentlich vorhatte, Syrien und gypten unter seiner eigenen Herrschaft zu vereinen. Er heiratete die Witwe von Nur ad-Din, besiegte die anderen Thronanwrter und bernahm 1185 die Macht in Syrien, womit er schlielich Nur ad-Dins Traum verwirklichte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Laut Wilhelm von Tyrus war Nur ad-Din zwar ein mchtiger Verfolger des christlichen Namens und Glaubens, aber auch ein gerechter Prinz, tapfer und weise und gem den Traditionen seiner Rasse, ein religiser Mann. Nur ad-Din war nach seiner Krankheit und seiner Pilgerreise besonders religis. Er betrachtete die Kreuzfahrer als Auslnder auf muslimischem Territorium, die nach Outremer gekommen waren, um das Land zu plndern und seine heiligen Sttten zu entweihen. Dennoch war er gegenber den Christen, die neben den Armeniern von Edessa unter seiner Herrschaft lebten, tolerant und empfand groen Respekt vor Kaiser Manuel. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nur ad-Din baute auch Universitten und Moscheen in allen von ihm kontrollierten Stdten. Diese Universitten befassten sich hauptschlich mit der Lehre des Korans und der Hadithe. Nur ad-Din selbst genoss es, sich von Experten aus den Hadithen vorlesen zu lassen, und seine Professoren verliehen ihm sogar ein Diplom in Hadith-Erzhlung. Er lie auch in seinen Stdten kostenlose Krankenhuser errichten und baute an den Straen Karawansereien fr Reisende und Pilger. Er hielt mehrmals in der Woche Gericht, damit die Menschen von ihm Gerechtigkeit gegen seine Generle, Gouverneure oder andere Mitarbeiter verlangen konnten, die ein Verbrechen begangen hatten. In der muslimischen Welt bleibt er eine legendre Figur voller militrischem Mut, Frmmigkeit und Bescheidenheit. Sir Steven Runciman sagte, dass er Gerechtigkeit ber alles liebe.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Nur ad-Din Zengi[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emir of Damascus and Aleppo[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] February 1118 - 15 May 1174[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Nur ad-Din was the second son of Imad ad-Din Zengi, the Turkish atabeg of Aleppo and Mosul, who was a devoted enemy of the crusader presence in Syria. After the assassination of his father, Nur ad-Din and his older brother Saif ad-Din Ghazi I divided the kingdom amongst themselves, with Nur ad-Din governing Aleppo and Saif ad-Din Ghazi establishing himself in Mosul. Almost as soon as he began his rule, Nur ad-Din attacked the Principality of Antioch, seizing several castles in the north of Syria, while at the same time he defeated an attempt by Joscelin II to recover the County of Edessa, which had been conquered by Zengi in 1144. [PARAGRAPH:1]It was Nur ad-Din's dream to unite the various Muslim forces between the Euphrates and the Nile to make a common front against the crusaders. In 1149 Nur ad-Din has been recognized as overlord of Mosul, so that the major cities of Mosul and Aleppo were united under one man. In 1154, the emir of Damascus was overthrown, the city was annexed to Zengid territory, and all Syria was unified under the authority of Nur ad-Din, from Edessa in the north to the Hauran in the south. [PARAGRAPH:1]As there was now nothing the crusaders could do in Syria, they were forced to look to the south, and after a series of wars they took Alexandira and Cairo from the weakened Fatimids. Nur ad-Din sent Shirkuh, his Kurdish general, to restore order. Shirkuh reclaimed Egypt and was made a vizier, later succeeded by his nephew Saladin. Nur ad-Din believed that he had accomplished his goal of uniting the Muslim states, but Saladin did not wish to be subject to his authority. [PARAGRAPH:1]When Nur ad-Din was on the verge of invading Egypt in 1174, he was seized by a fever due to complications from a peritonsillar abscess, and died at the age of 59. His young son As-Salih Ismail al-Malik became his legitimate heir, and Saladin declared himself his vassal, although he really planned to unify Syria and Egypt under his own rule. He married Nur ad-Din's widow, defeated the other claimants to the throne and took power in Syria in 1185, finally realizing Nur ad-Din's dream. [PARAGRAPH:1]According to William of Tyre, although Nur ad-Din was "a mighty persecutor of the Christian name and faith," he was also "a just prince, valiant and wise, and according to the traditions of his race, a religious man." Nur ad-Din was especially religious after his illness and his pilgrimage. He considered the crusaders foreigners in Muslim territory, who had come to Outremer to plunder the land and profane its sacred places. Nevertheless, he was tolerant of the Christians who lived under his authority, aside from the Armenians of Edessa and regarded the Emperor Manuel with deep respect. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nur ad-Din also constructed universities and mosques in all the cities he controlled. These universities were principally concerned with teaching the Qur'an and Hadith. Nur ad-Din himself enjoyed to have specialists read to him from the Hadith, and his professors even awarded him a diploma in Hadith narration. He had free hospitals constructed in his cities as well, and built caravanserais on the roads for travellers and pilgrims. He held court several times a week so that people could seek justice from him against his generals, governors, or other employees who had committed some crime. In the Muslim world he remains a legendary figure of military courage, piety, and modesty. Sir Steven Runciman said that he loved, above all else, justice.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Omanis were among the first people to embrace Islam. The conversion of the Omanis is usually ascribed to Amr ibn al-As, who was sent by the prophet Muhammad around 630 AD to invite Jaifar and Abd, the joint rulers of Oman at that time, to accept the faith, in which he eventually succeeded. During the early years of the Islamic mission Oman played a major role in the Wars of Apostasy that occurred after the death of Muhammad and also took part in the great Islamic conquests by land and sea in Iraq, Persia and beyond. However, its most prominent role in this respect was through its extensive trading and seafaring activities in East Africa and Asia.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 751 Ibadi Muslims, a moderate branch of the Kharijites, established an imamate in Oman. Despite interruptions, the Ibadi imamate survived until the mid-20th century. But Oman was nonetheless conquered by several foreign powers, having been controlled by the Qarmatians between 931-932 and then again between 933-934. Between 967 and 1053, Oman was part of the domain of the Iranian Buyyids, and between 1053 and 1154, Oman was part of the Great Seljuk empire. In 1154, the indigenous Nabhani dynasty took control of Oman, and the Nabhani kings ruled Oman until 1470, with an interruption of 37 years between 1406 and 1443.[PARAGRAPH:1]Muscat was taken by the Portuguese on 1 April 1515, and was held until 26 January 1650, although the Ottomans controlled Muscat between 1550-1551 and 1581-1588. In about the year 1600, Nabhani rule was temporarily restored to Oman, although that lasted only to 1624, when fifth imamate, which is also known as the Yarubid Imamate. The latter recaptured Muscat from the Portuguese in 1650 after a colonial presence on the northeastern coast of Oman dating to 1508. The Yarubid dynasty expanded, acquiring former Portuguese colonies in East Africa and engaging in the slave trade. By 1719 dynastic succession led to the nomination of Saif ibn Sultan II. His candidacy prompted a rivalry among the ulama and a civil war between the two major tribes, the Hinawi and the Ghafiri, with the Ghafiri supporting Saif ibn Sultan II. He assumed power in 1748 after the leaders of both factions had been killed in battle, but the rivalry continued, with the factionalization working in favor of the Iranians, who occupied Muscat and Sohar until 1792, when Omanis revolted and recaptured their cities under Sultan Al-Said.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Omanis gehrten zu den ersten Menschen, die den Islam annahmen. Die Bekehrung der Omanis wird blicherweise Amr ibn al-As zugeschrieben, der um 630 n. Chr. vom Propheten Mohammed gesandt wurde, um Jaifar und 'Abd, die damaligen gemeinsamen Herrscher von Oman, einzuladen, den Glauben anzunehmen, in den er schlielich eintrat gelungen. In den frhen Jahren der islamischen Mission spielte Oman eine wichtige Rolle in den Apostasiekriegen, die nach dem Tod Mohammeds stattfanden, und beteiligte sich auch an den groen islamischen Eroberungen zu Lande und zu Wasser im Irak, in Persien und darber hinaus. Seine wichtigste Rolle in dieser Hinsicht war jedoch seine umfangreiche Handels- und Seefahrtsttigkeit in Ostafrika und Asien.[PARAGRAPH:1]Im Jahr 751 grndeten Ibadi-Muslime, ein gemigter Zweig der Kharijiten, ein Imamat im Oman. Trotz Unterbrechungen berlebte das Ibadi-Imamat bis zur Mitte des 20. Jahrhunderts. Dennoch wurde Oman von mehreren auslndischen Mchten erobert, da es zwischen 931 und 932 und dann erneut zwischen 933 und 934 von den Qarmaten kontrolliert wurde. Zwischen 967 und 1053 war Oman Teil der Herrschaft der iranischen Buyyiden (Mukramiden) und zwischen 1053 und 1154 war Oman Teil des Groen Seldschukenreiches. Im Jahr 1154 bernahm die indigene Nabhani-Dynastie die Kontrolle ber Oman, und die Nabhani-Knige regierten Oman bis 1470, mit einer Unterbrechung von 37 Jahren zwischen 1406 und 1443.[PARAGRAPH:1]Maskat wurde am 1. April 1515 von den Portugiesen eingenommen hielt bis zum 26. Januar 1650, obwohl die Osmanen Maskat zwischen 1550-1551 und 1581-1588 kontrollierten. Um das Jahr 1600 wurde die Nabhani-Herrschaft im Oman vorbergehend wiederhergestellt, obwohl dies nur bis 1624 dauerte, als das fnfte Imamat, das auch als Yarubid-Imamat bekannt ist, eingefhrt wurde. Letztere eroberten Maskat 1650 von den Portugiesen zurck, nachdem sie 1508 eine Kolonialprsenz an der Nordostkste Omans errichtet hatten. Die Yarubiden-Dynastie expandierte, erwarb ehemalige portugiesische Kolonien in Ostafrika und beteiligte sich am Sklavenhandel. Im Jahr 1719 fhrte die dynastische Nachfolge zur Ernennung von Saif ibn Sultan II. Seine Kandidatur lste eine Rivalitt unter den Ulama und einen Brgerkrieg zwischen den beiden groen Stmmen, den Hinawi und den Ghafiri, aus, wobei die Ghafiri Saif ibn Sultan II. untersttzten. Er bernahm 1748 die Macht, nachdem die Anfhrer beider Fraktionen im Kampf gettet worden waren, aber die Rivalitt ging weiter, wobei die Fraktionierung zugunsten der Iraner wirkte, die Maskat und Suhar bis 1792 besetzten, als die Omanis revoltierten und ihre Stdte unter Sultan Al-Said zurckeroberten.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Yemen is one of the oldest centers of civilization in the Near East. Its relatively fertile land and adequate rainfall in a moister climate helped sustain a stable population, a feature recognized by the ancient Greek geographer Ptolemy, who described Yemen as Eudaimon Arabia (better known in its Latin translation, Arabia Felix) meaning "fortunate Arabia" or Happy Arabia. Between the 12th century BCE and the 6th century CE, it was dominated by six successive civilizations which rivaled each other, or were allied with each other and controlled the lucrative spice trade: M'ain, Qataban, Hadhramaut, Awsan, Saba and Himyarite.[PARAGRAPH:1]Islam came to Yemen around 630 CE, during the Islamic prophet Muhammad's lifetime. Thereafter Yemen was ruled as part of Arab-Islamic caliphates, and Yemen became a province in the Islamic empire. Yemeni textiles, long recognized for their fine quality, maintained their reputation and were exported for use by the Abbasid elite, including the caliphs themselves. The products of Sana'a and Aden are especially important in the East-West textile trade.[PARAGRAPH:1]The former North Yemen came under control of Imams of various dynasties usually of the Zaidi sect, who established a theocratic political structure that survived until modern times. In 897, a Zaidi ruler, Yahya al-Hadi ila'l Haqq, founded a line of Imams, whose Shiite dynasty survived until the second half of the 20th century. Nevertheless, Yemen's medieval history is a tangled chronicle of contesting local Imams. The Fatimids of Egypt helped the Isma'ilis maintain dominance in the 11th century. Saladin annexed Yemen in 1173. The Rasulid dynasty (Turkish in origin) ruled Yemen, with Zabid as its capital, from about 1230 to the 15th century. In 1516, the Mamluks of Egypt annexed Yemen; but in the following year, the Mamluk governor surrendered to the Ottomans, and Turkish armies subsequently overran the country. They were challenged by the Zaidi Imam, Qasim the Great (r.1597-1620), and were expelled from the interior around 1630. From then until the 19th century, the Ottomans retained control only of isolated coastal areas, while the highlands generally were ruled by the Zaidi Imams.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Jemen ist eines der ltesten Zivilisationszentren im Nahen Osten. Sein relativ fruchtbares Land und ausreichende Niederschlge in einem feuchteren Klima trugen dazu bei, eine stabile Bevlkerung aufrechtzuerhalten, ein Merkmal, das der antike griechische Geograph Ptolemaios erkannte, der den Jemen als Eudaimon Arabia (besser bekannt in seiner lateinischen bersetzung Arabia Felix) beschrieb, was glckliches Arabien bedeutet Glckliches Arabien. Zwischen dem 12. Jahrhundert v. Chr. und dem 6. Jahrhundert n. Chr. wurde es von sechs aufeinanderfolgenden Zivilisationen dominiert, die miteinander konkurrierten oder miteinander verbndet waren und den lukrativen Gewrzhandel kontrollierten: M'ain, Qataban, Hadhramaut, Awsan, Saba und Himyarite. [PARAGRAPH:1]Der Islam kam um 630 n. Chr., zu Lebzeiten des islamischen Propheten Mohammed, in den Jemen. Danach wurde Jemen als Teil arabisch-islamischer Kalifate regiert und Jemen wurde eine Provinz im islamischen Reich. Jemenitische Textilien, die seit langem fr ihre hervorragende Qualitt bekannt sind, behielten ihren Ruf und wurden zur Verwendung durch die abbasidische Elite, einschlielich der Kalifen selbst, exportiert. Die Produkte von Sana'a und Aden sind im Ost-West-Textilhandel besonders wichtig.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der ehemalige Nordjemen geriet unter die Kontrolle von Imamen verschiedener Dynastien, meist der Zaidi-Sekte, die eine theokratische politische Struktur errichteten, die berlebte bis in die Neuzeit. Im Jahr 897 grndete ein Zaidi-Herrscher, Yahya al-Hadi ila'l Haqq, eine Linie von Imamen, deren schiitische Dynastie bis in die zweite Hlfte des 20. Jahrhunderts berlebte. Dennoch ist die mittelalterliche Geschichte Jemens eine verworrene Chronik konkurrierender lokaler Imame. Die Fatimiden gyptens halfen den Ismailiten im 11. Jahrhundert, ihre Vorherrschaft zu behaupten. Saladin annektierte den Jemen im Jahr 1173. Die Rasuliden-Dynastie (trkischer Herkunft) regierte den Jemen mit Zabid als Hauptstadt von etwa 1230 bis zum 15. Jahrhundert. 1516 annektierten die gyptischen Mamluken den Jemen; Doch im folgenden Jahr ergab sich der Mamluk-Gouverneur den Osmanen und trkische Armeen berrannten anschlieend das Land. Sie wurden vom zaiditischen Imam Qasim dem Groen (reg. 15971620) herausgefordert und um 1630 aus dem Landesinneren vertrieben. Von da an bis zum 19. Jahrhundert behielten die Osmanen nur die Kontrolle ber isolierte Kstengebiete, whrend dies im Hochland im Allgemeinen der Fall war regiert von den Zaidi-Imamen.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Safavids were one of the most significant ruling dynasties of Iran. They ruled the greatest Iranian empire since the Islamic conquest of Persia and established the Twelver school of Shia Islam as the official religion of their empire, marking one of the most important turning points in the history of Islam. This Shia dynasty was of mixed ancestry (Kurdish, Azerbaijani, Georgian, Greek) and ruled Iran from 1501/1502 to 1722.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Safavid dynasty had its origin in the Safaviyeh Sufi order which was established in the city of Ardabil in the Azerbaijan region of Iran. From their base in Ardabil, the Safavids established control over all of Persia and reasserted the Iranian identity of the region, thus becoming the first native dynasty since the Sassanids to establish a unified Iranian state.[PARAGRAPH:1]Safavids began to expand their religious influence when Persia was ruled by Ak Koyunlu, the White Sheep Turkmen. By this time, the bulk of the Safaviyeh followers were Turkish-speaking clans from Asia Minor and Azerbaijan, and were collectively known as Qizilbash ("Red Heads") because of their distinct red headgear. The Qizilbash were warriors, spiritual followers of Sheikh Haydar (the leader of Safaviyeh), and a source of the Safavid military and political power, up until the end of 16th century, when various Qizilbashi chiefs began warring each other. In order to solve the problem, Shah Abbas I reorganized the army and country's administration with Ghulams (slave warriors).[PARAGRAPH:1]Abbas I became the most successful Safavid ruler. Not only he centralized control over the country and the army, but he also expanded Iranian territory with Afghanistan, eastern Iraq, Bahrain and parts of Caucasus. Abbas I also supported direct trade with Europe, particularly England and The Netherlands which sought Persian carpet, silk and textiles. [PARAGRAPH:1]Subsequent rulers were not as competent and the state slowly declined in power, losing more and more provinces to Ottomans, Uzbeks and local Baloch and Pashtun tribes. Safavid state collapsed in 1722, defeated by Afghan (Pashtun) rebels. Iran itself was saved, however, as Nader Shah, a general in the Safavid army, eventually expellend the Afghans and in 1736 established himself as Shah, starting the Afsharid dynasty.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Safawiden waren eine der bedeutendsten Herrscherdynastien des Iran. Sie regierten das grte iranische Reich seit der islamischen Eroberung Persiens und etablierten die Zwlfer-Schule des schiitischen Islam als offizielle Religion ihres Reiches, was einen der wichtigsten Wendepunkte in der Geschichte des Islam markierte. Diese schiitische Dynastie war gemischter Abstammung (kurdisch, aserbaidschanisch, georgisch, griechisch) und regierte den Iran von 1501/1502 bis 1722.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Safawiden-Dynastie hatte ihren Ursprung im Safaviyeh-Sufi-Orden, der in der Stadt Ardabil gegrndet wurde in der Region Aserbaidschan im Iran. Von ihrem Sttzpunkt in Ardabil aus etablierten die Safawiden die Kontrolle ber ganz Persien und bekrftigten die iranische Identitt der Region. Damit waren sie die erste einheimische Dynastie seit den Sassaniden, die einen einheitlichen iranischen Staat grndete.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Safawiden begannen, ihre Religion auszuweiten Einfluss, als Persien von Ak Koyunlu, den Weihammel-Turkmenen, regiert wurde. Zu dieser Zeit waren die meisten Anhnger der Safaviyeh trkischsprachige Clans aus Kleinasien und Aserbaidschan und wurden aufgrund ihrer aufflligen roten Kopfbedeckung zusammenfassend als Qizilbash (Rotkpfe) bezeichnet. Die Qizilbash waren Krieger, spirituelle Anhnger von Sheikh Haydar (dem Anfhrer von Safaviyeh) und eine Quelle der militrischen und politischen Macht der Safawiden, bis zum Ende des 16. Jahrhunderts verschiedene Qizilbashi-Huptlinge begannen, sich gegenseitig zu bekriegen. Um das Problem zu lsen, organisierte Schah Abbas I. die Armee und die Landesverwaltung mit Ghulams (Sklavenkriegern) neu.[PARAGRAPH:1]Abbas I. wurde der erfolgreichste safawidische Herrscher. Er zentralisierte nicht nur die Kontrolle ber das Land und die Armee, sondern erweiterte auch das iranische Territorium um Afghanistan, den Ostirak, Bahrain und Teile des Kaukasus. Abbas I. untersttzte auch den direkten Handel mit Europa, insbesondere mit England und den Niederlanden, die nach persischen Teppichen, Seide und Textilien suchten. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nachfolgende Herrscher waren nicht so kompetent und der Staat verlor langsam an Macht und verlor immer mehr Provinzen an Osmanen, Usbeken und lokale Belutschen- und Paschtunenstmme. Der safawidische Staat brach 1722 zusammen und wurde von afghanischen (paschtunischen) Rebellen besiegt. Der Iran selbst wurde jedoch gerettet, als Nader Schah, ein General der Safawiden-Armee, schlielich die Afghanen vertrieb und sich 1736 als Schah etablierte und damit die Afschariden-Dynastie begrndete.

TEXT.English: [H1]Abbas the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Shah of Persia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] January 27, 1571 - January 19, 1629[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Shah Abbas the Great was Shah (king) of Iran, and the greatest ruler of the Safavid dynasty. He was the third son of Shah Mohammad. Abbas came to the throne during a troubled time for Iran. Under his weak-willed father, the country was riven with discord between the different factions of the Qizilbash army, who killed Abbas' mother and elder brother. Meanwhile, Iran's enemies, the Ottoman Empire and the Uzbeks, exploited this political chaos to seize territory for themselves. In 1587, one of the Qizilbash leaders, Murshid Qoli Khan, overthrew Shah Mohammed in a coup and placed the 16-year-old Abbas on the throne. But Abbas was no puppet and soon seized power for himself. He reduced the influence of the Qizilbash in the government and the military and reformed the army, enabling him to fight the Ottomans and Uzbeks and reconquer Iran's lost provinces. He also took back land from the Portuguese and the Moguls. Abbas was a great builder and moved his kingdom's capital from Qazvin to Esfahan. In his later years, the shah became suspicious of his own sons and had them killed or blinded.

TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Abbas the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Shah of Persia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] January 27, 1571 - January 19, 1629[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Shah Abbas the Great was Shah (king) of Iran, and the greatest ruler of the Safavid dynasty. He was the third son of Shah Mohammad. Abbas came to the throne during a troubled time for Iran. Under his weak-willed father, the country was riven with discord between the different factions of the Qizilbash army, who killed Abbas' mother and elder brother. Meanwhile, Iran's enemies, the Ottoman Empire and the Uzbeks, exploited this political chaos to seize territory for themselves. In 1587, one of the Qizilbash leaders, Murshid Qoli Khan, overthrew Shah Mohammed in a coup and placed the 16-year-old Abbas on the throne. But Abbas was no puppet and soon seized power for himself. He reduced the influence of the Qizilbash in the government and the military and reformed the army, enabling him to fight the Ottomans and Uzbeks and reconquer Iran's lost provinces. He also took back land from the Portuguese and the Mughals. Abbas was a great builder and moved his kingdom's capital from Qazvin to Esfahan. In his later years, the shah became suspicious of his own sons and had them killed or blinded.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Samani dynasty, also known as the Samanid Empire, or simply Samanids (819-999) was a Persian state and empire in Central Asia and Greater Khorasan. Named after its founder Saman Khuda, who converted to Sunni Islam despite being from Zoroastrian theocratic nobility. It was the first native Persian dynasty in Greater Iran and Central Asia after the collapse of the Sassanid Persian empire caused by the Arab conquest.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Samanids were a Persian state that reigned for 180 years, encompassing a territory which included Khorasan, Ray, Transoxiania, Tabaristan, Kerman, Gorgan, and west of these provinces up to Isfahan. The Samanids were descendants of Bahram Chobin, and thus descended from the House of Mihran, one of the Seven Great Houses of Iran. In governing their territory, the Samanids modeled their state organization after the Abbasids, mirroring the caliph's court and organization. They were rewarded for supporting the Abbasids in Transoxania and Khorasan, and with their established capitals located in Bukhara, Balkh, Samarkand, and Herat, they carved their kingdom after defeating the Saffarids.[PARAGRAPH:1]With their roots stemming from the city of Balkh (then, part of Greater Khorasan) the Samanids promoted the arts, giving rise to the advancement of science and literature, and thus attracted scholars such as Rudaki and Avicenna. While under Samanid control, Bukhara was a rival to Baghdad in its glory. Scholars note that the Samanids revived Persian more than the Buyids and the Saffarids, while continuing to patronize Arabic to a significant degree. Nevertheless, in a famous edict, Samanid authorities declared that "here, in this region, the language is Persian, and the kings of this realm are Persian kings."[PARAGRAPH:1]The Samanids not only revived Persian culture but they also determinedly propagated Sunni Islam. The Samanid state became a staunch patron of Islamic architecture and spread the Islamo-Persian culture deep into the heart of Central Asia. The first complete translation of the Qur'an into Persian occurred during the reign of Samanids in the 9th century. According to historians, through the zealous missionary work of Samanid rulers, as many as 30,000 tents of Turks came to profess Islam and later under the Ghaznavids higher than 55,000. The mass conversion of the Turks to Islam eventually led to a growing influence of the Ghaznavids, who would later rule the region.[PARAGRAPH:1]Another lasting contribution of the Samanids to the history of Islamic art is the pottery known as Samanid Epigraphic Ware: plates, bowls, and pitchers fired in a white slip and decorated only with calligraphy, often elegantly and rhythmically written. The Arabic phrases used in this calligraphy are generally more or less generic well wishes, or Islamic admonitions to good table manners. In 999 their realm was conquered by the Karakhanids.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Samani-Dynastie, auch bekannt als Samanidenreich oder einfach Samaniden (819-999), war ein persischer Staat und Reich in Zentralasien und im Groraum Khorasan. Benannt nach seinem Grnder Saman Khuda, der zum sunnitischen Islam konvertierte, obwohl er dem zoroastrischen theokratischen Adel angehrte. Es war die erste einheimische persische Dynastie im Groraum Iran und Zentralasien nach dem Zusammenbruch des sassanidischen Perserreiches durch die arabische Eroberung.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Samaniden waren ein persischer Staat, der 180 Jahre lang regierte und ein Gebiet umfasste, zu dem auch Khorasan gehrte , Ray, Transoxiania, Tabaristan, Kerman, Gorgan und westlich dieser Provinzen bis nach Isfahan. Die Samaniden waren Nachkommen von Bahram Chobin und stammten somit vom Haus Mihran ab, einem der sieben groen Huser Irans. Bei der Verwaltung ihres Territoriums orientierten sich die Samaniden in ihrer Staatsorganisation an den Abbasiden und spiegelten damit den Hof und die Organisation des Kalifen wider. Sie wurden dafr belohnt, dass sie die Abbasiden in Transoxanien und Chorasan untersttzten, und mit ihren etablierten Hauptstdten in Buchara, Balkh, Samarkand und Herat grndeten sie ihr Knigreich, nachdem sie die Saffariden besiegt hatten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mit ihren Wurzeln in der Stadt Balkh (damals Teil des Groraums Khorasan) frderten die Samaniden die Knste, fhrten zum Fortschritt von Wissenschaft und Literatur und zogen so Gelehrte wie Rudaki und Avicenna an. Whrend Buchara unter der Kontrolle der Samaniden stand, war es in seiner Pracht ein Rivale von Bagdad. Wissenschaftler stellen fest, dass die Samaniden das Persische strker wiederbelebten als die Buyiden und Saffariden, whrend sie das Arabische weiterhin in erheblichem Mae bevormundeten. Dennoch erklrten die samanidischen Behrden in einem berhmten Edikt: Hier, in dieser Region, ist die Sprache Persisch, und die Knige dieses Reiches sind persische Knige.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Samaniden haben nicht nur die persische Kultur wiederbelebt, sondern sie auch entschlossen propagierte den sunnitischen Islam. Der samanidische Staat wurde zu einem berzeugten Frderer der islamischen Architektur und verbreitete die islamisch-persische Kultur tief im Herzen Zentralasiens. Die erste vollstndige bersetzung des Korans ins Persische erfolgte whrend der Herrschaft der Samaniden im 9. Jahrhundert. Historikern zufolge kamen durch die eifrige Missionsarbeit der samanidischen Herrscher bis zu 30.000 Zelte von Trken, um sich zum Islam zu bekennen, und spter unter den Ghaznaviden mehr als 55.000. Die Massenkonvertierung der Trken zum Islam fhrte schlielich zu einem wachsenden Einfluss der Ghaznaviden, die spter die Region regierten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ein weiterer bleibender Beitrag der Samaniden zur Geschichte der islamischen Kunst ist die als Samanid Epigraphic Ware bekannte Keramik : Teller, Schsseln und Krge, in einem weien Schlicker gebrannt und nur mit Kalligraphie verziert, oft elegant und rhythmisch geschrieben. Die in dieser Kalligraphie verwendeten arabischen Phrasen sind im Allgemeinen mehr oder weniger allgemeine Glckwnsche oder islamische Ermahnungen zu guten Tischmanieren. Im Jahr 999 wurde ihr Reich von den Karachaniden erobert.

TEXT.English: [H1]Ismail Samani[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Amir of Khorasan[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 892-907[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Ismail ibn Ahmad also referred to as, "Amir Adil" (the Just Commander) was the Samanid amir of Transoxiana (892-907) and Khorasan (900-907). His reign saw the emergence of the Samanids as a powerful force. He was the son of Ahmad ibn Asad and a descendant of Saman Khuda, the founder of the Samanid dynasty who renounced Zoroastrianism and embraced Islam. Ismail is considered the father of the Tajik nation.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ismail was steadily spreading Samanid influence as well as solidifying his control over other areas including Kerman, Sistan and Kabul. He was successful in establishing economic and commercial development and organized a powerful army. It was said that he made his capital Bukhara into one of Islam's most glorious cities, as Ismail attracted scholars, artists, and doctors of law into the region. The first translation of the Qu'ran into Persian was completed during Samanid rule. Sunni theology greatly cultivated during Ismail's reign, as numerous mosques and madrassas were built.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 893, Ismail took the city of Talas, the capital of the Qarluq Turks. It was probably in that same year that he also brought an end to the Ustrushana dynasty. Ismail and other Samanid rulers propagated Islam amongst the inhabitants and as many as 30,000 tents of Turks came to profess Islam. During his reign he subjugated numerous regional states to the east, directly incorporating some within his boundaries and retaining the local rulers of others as vassals. Khwarazm to the north was partitioned; the southern part remained autonomous under its Afrigid rulers, while the northern part was governed by a Samanid official. Another campaign in 903 further secured the Samanid boundaries. These campaigns kept the heart of his state safe from Turkish raids, and allowed Muslim missionaries to expand their activities in the region.[PARAGRAPH:1]Even after his brother Nasr's death, Ismail's rule in Bukhara was not formally recognized by the caliph at that point. As a result, the Saffarid ruler 'Amr-i Laith himself asked the caliph for the investiture of Transoxiana. The caliph, Al-Mu'tadid however sent Ismail a letter urging him to fight Amr-i Laith and the Saffarids whom the caliph considered usurpers. According to the letter, the caliph stated that he prayed for Ismail who the caliph considered as the rightful ruler of Khorasan. The letter had a profound effect on Ismail, as he was determined to oppose the Saffarids.[PARAGRAPH:1]The two sides fought in Balkh, northern Afghanistan during the spring of 900. During battle, Ismail was significantly outnumbered as he came out with 20,000 horsemen against Amr's 70,000 strong cavalry. Ismail's horsemen were ill-equipped with most having wooden stirrups while some had no shields or lances. Amr-i Laith's cavalry on the other hand, were fully equipped with weapons and armor. Despite fierce fighting, Amr was captured as some of his troops switched sides and joined Ismail. Isma'il wished to ransom him to the Saffarids, but they refused, so he sent 'Amr to the caliph, who blamed 'Amr's conduct in the matter and then invested Isma'il with Khorasan, Tabaristan, Ray, and Isfahan.[PARAGRAPH:1]Although Isma'il continued to send gifts to the caliph, as was customary, he neither paid tribute or taxes. For all intents and purposes he was an independent ruler, although he never took any title higher than that of amir. After a long sickness Isma'il died in 907 and was succeeded by his son Ahmad.

TEXT.German: [H1]Ismail Samani[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emir von Khorasan[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Regierungszeit:[\BOLD] 892-907[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD ][NEWLINE][TAB]Ismail ibn Ahmad, auch Amir Adil (der gerechte Befehlshaber) genannt, war der samanidische Emir von Transoxiana (892907) und Khorasan (900907). Unter seiner Herrschaft entstanden die Samaniden zu einer mchtigen Macht. Er war der Sohn von Ahmad ibn Asad und ein Nachkomme von Saman Khuda, dem Grnder der Samaniden-Dynastie, der dem Zoroastrismus abschwor und den Islam annahm. Ismail gilt als Vater der tadschikischen Nation.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ismail weitete den samanidischen Einfluss stetig aus und festigte seine Kontrolle ber andere Gebiete, darunter Kerman, Sistan und Kabul. Es gelang ihm, die wirtschaftliche und kommerzielle Entwicklung voranzutreiben und eine mchtige Armee zu organisieren. Es hie, er habe seine Hauptstadt Buchara zu einer der glorreichsten Stdte des Islam gemacht, da Ismail Gelehrte, Knstler und Rechtswissenschaftler in die Region lockte. Die erste bersetzung des Korans ins Persische wurde whrend der Herrschaft der Samaniden fertiggestellt. Die sunnitische Theologie entwickelte sich whrend der Herrschaft Ismails stark, da zahlreiche Moscheen und Medresen gebaut wurden.[PARAGRAPH:1]Im Jahr 893 eroberte Ismail die Stadt Talas, die Hauptstadt der Qarluq-Trken. Vermutlich beendete er im selben Jahr auch die Ustruschanen-Dynastie. Ismail und andere samanidische Herrscher verbreiteten den Islam unter den Einwohnern und bis zu 30.000 Trken kamen, um sich zum Islam zu bekennen. Whrend seiner Herrschaft unterwarf er zahlreiche Regionalstaaten im Osten, gliederte einige direkt in seine Grenzen ein und behielt die lokalen Herrscher anderer als Vasallen. Choresmien im Norden wurde geteilt; Der sdliche Teil blieb unter seinen frostigen Herrschern autonom, whrend der nrdliche Teil von einem samanidischen Beamten regiert wurde. Ein weiterer Feldzug im Jahr 903 sicherte die Grenzen der Samaniden weiter. Diese Kampagnen schtzten das Herz seines Staates vor trkischen berfllen und ermglichten es muslimischen Missionaren, ihre Aktivitten in der Region auszuweiten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Selbst nach dem Tod seines Bruders Nasr wurde Ismails Herrschaft in Buchara zu diesem Zeitpunkt vom Kalifen nicht offiziell anerkannt. Infolgedessen bat der saffaridische Herrscher 'Amr-i Laith selbst den Kalifen um die Investitur Transoxianas. Der Kalif Al-Mu'tadid schickte Ismail jedoch einen Brief, in dem er ihn aufforderte, gegen Amr-i Laith und die Saffariden zu kmpfen, die der Kalif als Usurpatoren betrachtete. Dem Brief zufolge gab der Kalif an, dass er fr Ismail betete, den der Kalif als den rechtmigen Herrscher von Khorasan ansah. Der Brief hatte eine tiefgreifende Wirkung auf Ismail, da er entschlossen war, sich den Saffariden zu widersetzen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die beiden Seiten kmpften im Frhjahr 900 in Balkh, Nordafghanistan. Whrend der Schlacht war Ismail zahlenmig deutlich unterlegen, als er herauskam 20.000 Reiter gegen Amrs 70.000 Mann starke Kavallerie. Ismails Reiter waren schlecht ausgerstet, die meisten hatten hlzerne Steigbgel, whrend einige keine Schilde oder Lanzen hatten. Die Kavallerie von Amr-i Laith hingegen war vollstndig mit Waffen und Rstungen ausgestattet. Trotz heftiger Kmpfe wurde Amr gefangen genommen, als einige seiner Truppen die Seite wechselten und sich Ismail anschlossen. Isma'il wollte ihn von den Saffariden freikaufen, doch diese weigerten sich, und so schickte er 'Amr zum Kalifen, der 'Amrs Verhalten in dieser Angelegenheit beschuldigte und Isma'il dann mit Khorasan, Tabaristan, Ray und Isfahan betraute.[PARAGRAPH :1]Obwohl Ismail dem Kalifen wie blich weiterhin Geschenke schickte, zahlte er weder Tribut noch Steuern. Im Grunde war er ein unabhngiger Herrscher, obwohl er nie einen hheren Titel als den eines Emirs annahm. Nach langer Krankheit starb Ismail im Jahr 907 und wurde von seinem Sohn Ahmad abgelst.
