According to the letter, the caliph stated that he prayed for Ismail who the caliph considered as the rightful ruler of Khorasan. The letter had a profound effect on Ismail, as he was determined to oppose the Saffarids.[PARAGRAPH:1]The two sides fought in Balkh, northern Afghanistan during the spring of 900. During battle, Ismail was significantly outnumbered as he came out with 20,000 horsemen against Amr's 70,000 strong cavalry. Ismail's horsemen were ill-equipped with most having wooden stirrups while some had no shields or lances. Amr-i Laith's cavalry on the other hand, were fully equipped with weapons and armor. Despite fierce fighting, Amr was captured as some of his troops switched sides and joined Ismail. Isma'il wished to ransom him to the Saffarids, but they refused, so he sent 'Amr to the caliph, who blamed 'Amr's conduct in the matter and then invested Isma'il with Khorasan, Tabaristan, Ray, and Isfahan.[PARAGRAPH:1]Although Isma'il continued to send gifts to the caliph, as was customary, he neither paid tribute or taxes. For all intents and purposes he was an independent ruler, although he never took any title higher than that of amir. After a long sickness Isma'il died in 907 and was succeeded by his son Ahmad.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Ismail Samani[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Amir of Khorasan[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 892-907[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Ismail ibn Ahmad also referred to as, "Amir Adil" (the Just Commander) was the Samanid amir of Transoxiana (892-907) and Khorasan (900-907). His reign saw the emergence of the Samanids as a powerful force. He was the son of Ahmad ibn Asad and a descendant of Saman Khuda, the founder of the Samanid dynasty who renounced Zoroastrianism and embraced Islam. Ismail is considered the father of the Tajik nation.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ismail was steadily spreading Samanid influence as well as solidifying his control over other areas including Kerman, Sistan and Kabul. He was successful in establishing economic and commercial development and organized a powerful army. It was said that he made his capital Bukhara into one of Islam's most glorious cities, as Ismail attracted scholars, artists, and doctors of law into the region. The first translation of the Qu'ran into Persian was completed during Samanid rule. Sunni theology greatly cultivated during Ismail's reign, as numerous mosques and madrassas were built.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 893, Ismail took the city of Talas, the capital of the Qarluq Turks. It was probably in that same year that he also brought an end to the Ustrushana dynasty. Ismail and other Samanid rulers propagated Islam amongst the inhabitants and as many as 30,000 tents of Turks came to profess Islam. During his reign he subjugated numerous regional states to the east, directly incorporating some within his boundaries and retaining the local rulers of others as vassals. Khwarazm to the north was partitioned; the southern part remained autonomous under its Afrigid rulers, while the northern part was governed by a Samanid official. Another campaign in 903 further secured the Samanid boundaries. These campaigns kept the heart of his state safe from Turkish raids, and allowed Muslim missionaries to expand their activities in the region.[PARAGRAPH:1]Even after his brother Nasr's death, Ismail's rule in Bukhara was not formally recognized by the caliph at that point. As a result, the Saffarid ruler 'Amr-i Laith himself asked the caliph for the investiture of Transoxiana. The caliph, Al-Mu'tadid however sent Ismail a letter urging him to fight Amr-i Laith and the Saffarids whom the caliph considered usurpers. According to the letter, the caliph stated that he prayed for Ismail who the caliph considered as the rightful ruler of Khorasan. The letter had a profound effect on Ismail, as he was determined to oppose the Saffarids.[PARAGRAPH:1]The two sides fought in Balkh, northern Afghanistan during the spring of 900. During battle, Ismail was significantly outnumbered as he came out with 20,000 horsemen against Amr's 70,000 strong cavalry. Ismail's horsemen were ill-equipped with most having wooden stirrups while some had no shields or lances. Amr-i Laith's cavalry on the other hand, were fully equipped with weapons and armor. Despite fierce fighting, Amr was captured as some of his troops switched sides and joined Ismail. Isma'il wished to ransom him to the Saffarids, but they refused, so he sent 'Amr to the caliph, who blamed 'Amr's conduct in the matter and then invested Isma'il with Khorasan, Tabaristan, Ray, and Isfahan.[PARAGRAPH:1]Although Isma'il continued to send gifts to the caliph, as was customary, he neither paid tribute or taxes. For all intents and purposes he was an independent ruler, although he never took any title higher than that of amir. After a long sickness Isma'il died in 907 and was succeeded by his son Ahmad.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Great Seljuk Empire was a medieval Turko-Persian Sunni Muslim empire, originated from the Qynyq branch of Oghuz Turks that once controlled a vast area stretching from the Hindu Kush to eastern Anatolia and from Central Asia to the Persian Gulf. From their homelands near the Aral sea, the Seljuks advanced first into Khorasan and then into mainland Persia before eventually conquering eastern Anatolia.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Seljuk empire was founded by Tugrul Beg in 1037 after the efforts by the founder of the Seljuk dynasty, Seljuq Beg, back in the first quarter of the eleventh century. Seljuq Beg's father was in a higher position in the Oghuz Yabgu State, and gave his name both to the state and the dynasty. The Seljuks united the fractured political scene of the Eastern Islamic world and played a key role in the first and second crusades. Highly Persianized in culture and language, the Seljuks also played an important role in the development of the Turko-Persian tradition.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Seljuk power was at its zenith under Malikshah I, and both the Qarakhanids and Ghaznavids had to acknowledge the overlordship of the Seljuks. The Seljuk dominion was established over the ancient Sassanid domains, in Iran and Iraq, and included Anatolia as well as parts of Central Asia and modern Afghanistan. The Seljuk rule was modelled after the tribal organization brought in by the nomadic conquerors and resembled a 'family federation' or 'appanage state'. Under this organization the leading member of the paramount family assigned family members portions of his domains as autonomous appanages.[PARAGRAPH:1]When Malikshah I died in 1092, the empire split as his brother and four sons quarrelled over the apportioning of the empire among themselves. In Anatolia, Malikshah I was succeeded by Kilij Arslan I who founded the Sultanate of Rum and in Syria by his brother Tutush I. In Persia he was succeeded by his son Mahmud I whose reign was contested by his other three brothers Barkiyaruq in Iraq, Muhammad I in Baghdad and Ahmad Sanjar in Khorasan. Despite several attempts to reunite the Seljuk realms, the Crusades prevented subsequent rulers from regaining their former empire. The atabegs, such as Zengids and Artuqids, were only nominally under the Seljuk Sultan, and generally controlled Syria independently. When Ahmed Sanjar died in 1156, it fractured the empire even further and rendered the atabegs effectively independent.[PARAGRAPH:1]For a brief period, Togrul III was the Sultan of all Seljuk except for Anatolia. In 1194, however, Togrul was defeated by Takash, the Shah of Khwarezmid Empire, and the Seljuk finally collapsed. Of the former Seljuk Empire, only the Sultanate of Rum in Anatolia remained. As the dynasty declined in the middle of the thirteenth century, the Mongols invaded Anatolia in the 1260s and divided it into small emirates called the Anatolian beyliks. Eventually one of these, the Ottoman, would rise to power and conquer the rest.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Das Groe Seldschukenreich war ein mittelalterliches trkisch-persisches sunnitisch-muslimisches Reich, das aus dem Qynyq-Zweig der Oghuz-Trken entstand, der einst ein riesiges Gebiet kontrollierte, das sich vom Hindukusch bis Ostanatolien und von Zentralasien bis zum Persischen Golf erstreckte. Von ihren Heimatlndern am Aralsee aus drangen die Seldschuken zunchst nach Chorasan und dann auf das persische Festland vor, bevor sie schlielich Ostanatolien eroberten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Das Seldschukenreich wurde 1037 von Tugrul Beg nach den Bemhungen des Grnders der Seldschuken-Dynastie gegrndet , Seldschuken-Beg, im ersten Viertel des elften Jahrhunderts. Seldschuken-Begs Vater hatte eine hhere Position im Oghuz-Yabgu-Staat inne und gab sowohl dem Staat als auch der Dynastie seinen Namen. Die Seldschuken vereinten die zersplitterte politische Szene der stlichen islamischen Welt und spielten eine Schlsselrolle im ersten und zweiten Kreuzzug. Die in Kultur und Sprache stark persianisierten Seldschuken spielten auch eine wichtige Rolle bei der Entwicklung der trkisch-persischen Tradition.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die seldschukische Macht befand sich unter Malikshah I. auf ihrem Hhepunkt, und sowohl die Karachaniden als auch die Ghaznaviden mussten dies anerkennen Oberherrschaft der Seldschuken. Die Herrschaft der Seldschuken erstreckte sich ber die alten Sassanidengebiete im Iran und im Irak und umfasste Anatolien sowie Teile Zentralasiens und des modernen Afghanistans. Die seldschukische Herrschaft orientierte sich an der Stammesorganisation der nomadischen Eroberer und hnelte einem Familienbund oder einem Apanage-Staat. Im Rahmen dieser Organisation teilte das fhrende Mitglied der obersten Familie den Familienmitgliedern Teile seiner Domnen als autonome Apanages zu.[PARAGRAPH:1]Als Malikshah I. im Jahr 1092 starb, spaltete sich das Reich, da sein Bruder und seine vier Shne ber die Aufteilung des Reiches untereinander stritten. In Anatolien wurde Malikshah I. von Kilij Arslan I. abgelst, der das Sultanat Rum grndete, und in Syrien von seinem Bruder Tutusch I.. In Persien wurde er von seinem Sohn Mahmud I. abgelst, dessen Herrschaft von seinen anderen drei Brdern Barkiyaruq im Irak, Muhammad, bestritten wurde Ich in Bagdad und Ahmad Sanjar in Khorasan. Trotz mehrerer Versuche, die seldschukischen Reiche wieder zu vereinen, verhinderten die Kreuzzge, dass nachfolgende Herrscher ihr frheres Reich wiedererlangen konnten. Die Atabegs wie Zengids und Artuqids standen nur nominell unter dem seldschukischen Sultan und kontrollierten Syrien im Allgemeinen unabhngig. Als Ahmed Sanjar 1156 starb, spaltete dies das Reich noch weiter und machte die Atabegs praktisch unabhngig.[PARAGRAPH:1]Fr kurze Zeit war Togrul III. der Sultan aller Seldschuken mit Ausnahme Anatoliens. Im Jahr 1194 wurde Togrul jedoch von Takash, dem Schah des Choresm-Reiches, besiegt und die Seldschuken brachen schlielich zusammen. Vom ehemaligen Seldschukenreich blieb nur das Sultanat Rum in Anatolien brig. Als die Dynastie Mitte des 13. Jahrhunderts unterging, fielen die Mongolen in den 1260er Jahren in Anatolien ein und teilten es in kleine Emirate auf, die als anatolische Beyliks bezeichnet wurden. Schlielich wrde einer von ihnen, die Osmanen, an die Macht kommen und den Rest erobern.

TEXT.English: [H1]Alp Arslan[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan of the Great Seljuk Empire[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1029 - 15 December 1072[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Alp Arslan was the third sultan of the Seljuk dynasty and great-grandson of Seljuk, the eponym of the dynasty. He assumed the name of Muhammad bin Da'ud Chaghri when he embraced Islam, and for his military prowess, personal valour, and fighting skills he obtained the surname Alp Arslan, which means "Warrior Lion" in Turkish. [PARAGRAPH:1]He succeeded his father Chagri Begh as governor of Khorasan in 1059. When his uncle Togrul died he was succeeded by Suleiman, Alp Arslan's brother. Alp Arslan and his uncle Kutalmish both contested this succession. Alp Arslan defeated Kutalmish for the throne and succeeded on 27 April 1064 as sultan of Great Seljuk, and thus became sole monarch of Persia from the river Oxus to the Tigris. [PARAGRAPH:1]In consolidating his empire and subduing contending factions he was ably assisted by Nizam ul-Mulk, his vizier, and one of the most eminent statesmen in early Muslim history. With peace and security established in his dominions, he convoked an assembly of the states and declared his son Malik Shah I his heir and successor. With the hope of capturing Caesarea Mazaca, the capital of Cappadocia, he placed himself at the head of the Turkish cavalry, crossed the Euphrates and entered and invaded the city. He then marched into Armenia and Georgia, which he conquered in 1064. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1068, en route to Syria, Alp Arslan invaded the Byzantine Empire. After three campaigns, the Turks were defeated and driven across the Euphrates. In 1071, while at Manzikert, north of Lake Van, Alp Arslan offered peace. The offer was rejected by Emperor Romanos IV and the two forces met in the Battle of Manzikert. The Cuman mercenaries among the Byzantine forces immediately defected to the Turkish side; and, seeing this, "the Western mercenaries rode off and took no part in the battle." The Byzantines were totally routed. Emperor Romanos IV was himself taken prisoner and conducted into the presence of Alp Arslan, who treated him with generosity, and, terms of peace having been agreed to, dismissed him, loaded with presents and respectfully attended by a military guard. [PARAGRAPH:1]Alp Arslan's victories changed the balance in near Asia completely in favour of the Seljuk Turks and Sunni Muslims. While the Byzantine Empire was to continue for nearly another four centuries, and the Crusades would contest the issue for some time, the victory at Manzikert signalled the beginning of Turkish ascendancy in Anatolia. Alp Arslan's conquest of Anatolia from the Byzantines is also seen as one of the pivotal precursors to the launch of the crusades.

TEXT.German: [H1]Alp Arslan[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan des Groen Seldschukenreiches[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Gelebt:[\BOLD] 1029 - 15. Dezember 1072[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD] Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Alp Arslan war der dritte Sultan der Seldschuken-Dynastie und Urenkel von Seldschuken, dem Namensgeber der Dynastie. Als er den Islam annahm, nahm er den Namen Muhammad bin Da'ud Chaghri an und erhielt aufgrund seiner militrischen Tapferkeit, seines persnlichen Mutes und seiner Kampffhigkeiten den Nachnamen Alp Arslan, was auf Trkisch Kriegerlwe bedeutet. [PARAGRAPH:1]Er trat 1059 die Nachfolge seines Vaters Chagri Begh als Gouverneur von Khorasan an. Als sein Onkel Togrul starb, wurde er von Suleiman, dem Bruder von Alp Arslan, abgelst. Alp Arslan und sein Onkel Kutalmish bestritten beide diese Nachfolge. Alp Arslan besiegte Kutalmish und bestieg am 27. April 1064 die Thronfolge als Sultan der Groen Seldschuken und wurde somit alleiniger Monarch Persiens vom Fluss Oxus bis zum Tigris. [PARAGRAPH:1]Bei der Konsolidierung seines Reiches und der Unterwerfung konkurrierender Fraktionen wurde er von Nizam ul-Mulk, seinem Wesir und einem der bedeutendsten Staatsmnner in der frhen muslimischen Geschichte, geschickt untersttzt. Als Frieden und Sicherheit in seinen Herrschaftsgebieten herrschten, berief er eine Versammlung der Staaten ein und erklrte seinen Sohn Malik Schah I. zu seinem Erben und Nachfolger. In der Hoffnung, Caesarea Mazaca, die Hauptstadt Kappadokiens, zu erobern, stellte er sich an die Spitze der trkischen Kavallerie, berquerte den Euphrat und drang in die Stadt ein und fiel dort ein. Anschlieend marschierte er in Armenien und Georgien ein, die er 1064 eroberte. [PARAGRAPH:1]1068 fiel Alp Arslan auf dem Weg nach Syrien in das Byzantinische Reich ein. Nach drei Feldzgen wurden die Trken besiegt und ber den Euphrat vertrieben. Im Jahr 1071 bot Alp Arslan in Manzikert, nrdlich des Vansees, Frieden an. Das Angebot wurde von Kaiser Romanos IV. abgelehnt und die beiden Streitkrfte trafen in der Schlacht von Manzikert aufeinander. Die kumanischen Sldner unter den byzantinischen Streitkrften liefen sofort auf die trkische Seite ber; und als sie dies sahen, ritten die westlichen Sldner davon und beteiligten sich nicht an der Schlacht. Die Byzantiner wurden vllig in die Flucht geschlagen. Kaiser Romanos IV. wurde selbst gefangen genommen und in die Gegenwart von Alp Arslan gefhrt, der ihn grozgig behandelte und ihn, nachdem Friedensbedingungen vereinbart worden waren, mit Geschenken beladen und respektvoll von einer Militrwache begleitet entlie. [PARAGRAPH:1]Alp Arslans Siege vernderten das Gleichgewicht in Nahasien vllig zugunsten der seldschukischen Trken und sunnitischen Muslime. Whrend das Byzantinische Reich noch fast vier Jahrhunderte andauern sollte und die Kreuzzge die Frage noch eine Zeit lang bestreiten wrden, markierte der Sieg bei Manzikert den Beginn des trkischen Vormarsches in Anatolien. Alp Arslans Eroberung Anatoliens von den Byzantinern gilt auch als einer der entscheidenden Vorlufer der Kreuzzge.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Alp Arslan[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan of the Great Seljuk Empire[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1029 - 15 December 1072[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Alp Arslan was the third sultan of the Seljuk dynasty and great-grandson of Seljuk, the eponym of the dynasty. He assumed the name of Muhammad bin Da'ud Chaghri when he embraced Islam, and for his military prowess, personal valour, and fighting skills he obtained the surname Alp Arslan, which means "Warrior Lion" in Turkish. [PARAGRAPH:1]He succeeded his father Chagri Begh as governor of Khorasan in 1059. When his uncle Togrul died he was succeeded by Suleiman, Alp Arslan's brother. Alp Arslan and his uncle Kutalmish both contested this succession. Alp Arslan defeated Kutalmish for the throne and succeeded on 27 April 1064 as sultan of Great Seljuk, and thus became sole monarch of Persia from the river Oxus to the Tigris. [PARAGRAPH:1]In consolidating his empire and subduing contending factions he was ably assisted by Nizam ul-Mulk, his vizier, and one of the most eminent statesmen in early Muslim history. With peace and security established in his dominions, he convoked an assembly of the states and declared his son Malik Shah I his heir and successor. With the hope of capturing Caesarea Mazaca, the capital of Cappadocia, he placed himself at the head of the Turkish cavalry, crossed the Euphrates and entered and invaded the city. He then marched into Armenia and Georgia, which he conquered in 1064. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1068, en route to Syria, Alp Arslan invaded the Byzantine Empire. After three campaigns, the Turks were defeated and driven across the Euphrates. In 1071, while at Manzikert, north of Lake Van, Alp Arslan offered peace. The offer was rejected by Emperor Romanos IV and the two forces met in the Battle of Manzikert. The Cuman mercenaries among the Byzantine forces immediately defected to the Turkish side; and, seeing this, "the Western mercenaries rode off and took no part in the battle." The Byzantines were totally routed. Emperor Romanos IV was himself taken prisoner and conducted into the presence of Alp Arslan, who treated him with generosity, and, terms of peace having been agreed to, dismissed him, loaded with presents and respectfully attended by a military guard. [PARAGRAPH:1]Alp Arslan's victories changed the balance in near Asia completely in favour of the Seljuk Turks and Sunni Muslims. While the Byzantine Empire was to continue for nearly another four centuries, and the Crusades would contest the issue for some time, the victory at Manzikert signalled the beginning of Turkish ascendancy in Anatolia. Alp Arslan's conquest of Anatolia from the Byzantines is also seen as one of the pivotal precursors to the launch of the crusades.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Armenia has been populated since prehistoric times, and has been proposed as the site of the Biblical Garden of Eden. Armenia lies in the highlands surrounding the Biblical mountains of Ararat, upon which, as tradition states, Noah's Ark came to rest after the flood. [PARAGRAPH:1]Around 600 BC, the Kingdom of Armenia was established under the Orontid Dynasty, which existed under several local dynasties till AD 428. The kingdom reached its height between 95 - 66 BC under Tigranes the Great, becoming one of the most powerful kingdoms of its time. Throughout its history, the kingdom of Armenia enjoyed periods of independence intermitted with periods of autonomy subject to contemporary empires. Armenia's strategic location between two continents has subjected it to invasions by many peoples, including the Assyrians, Greeks, Romans, Byzantines, Arabs, Mongols, Persians, Ottoman Turks and Russians.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 301, Armenia became the first country in the world to adopt Christianity as its official state religion, while a number of Christian communities have been established in Armenia since 40 AD There had been various pagan communities before Christianity, but they were converted by an influx of Christian missionaries.[PARAGRAPH:1]After the fall of the Armenian kingdom in 428, most of Armenia was incorporated as a marzpanate within the Sassanid Empire. After the marzpanate period, Armenia emerged as an autonomous principality within the Arabic Empire, reuniting Armenian lands previously taken by the Byzantine Empire as well. The principality was ruled by the Prince of Armenia, recognized by the Caliph and the Byzantine Emperor. The Principality of Armenia lasted till 884, when it regained its independence from the weakened Arabic Empire.[PARAGRAPH:1]The reemerged Armenian kingdom was ruled by the Bagratuni dynasty, and lasted till 1045. In time, several areas of the Bagratid Armenia separated as independent kingdoms and principalities such as the Kingdom of Vaspurakan ruled by the House of Artsruni, while still recognizing the supremacy of the Bagratid kings.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1045, the Byzantine Empire conquered Bagratid Armenia. Soon, the other Armenian states fell under Byzantine control as well. The Byzantine rule was short lived, as in 1071 Seljuk Turks defeated the Byzantines and conquered Armenia at the Battle of Manzikert, establishing the Seljuk Empire. To escape death or servitude at the hands of those who had assassinated his relative, Gagik II, King of Ani, an Armenian named Roupen with some of his countrymen went into the gorges of the Taurus Mountains and then into Tarsus of Cilicia. Here the Byzantine governor of the place gave them shelter where the Armenian Kingdom of Cilicia was eventually established.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1230s Mongol Ilkhanate conquered the Zakaryan Principality, as well as the rest of Armenia. The Mongolian invasions were soon followed by those of other Central Asian tribes, which continued from 1200s till 1400s. After incessant invasions, each bringing destruction to the country, Armenia in time became weakened. In 1500s, the Ottoman Empire and Safavid Persia divided Armenia among themselves.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Armenien ist seit prhistorischen Zeiten besiedelt und wurde als Standort des biblischen Gartens Eden vorgeschlagen. Armenien liegt im Hochland rund um die biblischen Berge Ararat, auf denen der berlieferung nach die Arche Noah nach der Sintflut ruhte. [PARAGRAPH:1]Um 600 v. Chr. wurde das Knigreich Armenien unter der Orontiden-Dynastie gegrndet, das bis 428 n. Chr. unter mehreren lokalen Dynastien existierte. Das Knigreich erreichte seinen Hhepunkt zwischen 95 und 66 v. Chr. unter Tigranes dem Groen und wurde zu einem der bedeutendsten mchtige Knigreiche seiner Zeit. Im Laufe seiner Geschichte erlebte das Knigreich Armenien Perioden der Unabhngigkeit, die von Perioden der Autonomie unterbrochen wurden, die den zeitgenssischen Imperien unterworfen waren. Armeniens strategische Lage zwischen zwei Kontinenten hat dazu gefhrt, dass viele Vlker, darunter Assyrer, Griechen, Rmer, Byzantiner, Araber, Mongolen, Perser, osmanische Trken und Russen, in das Land eindrangen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Im Jahr 301 wurde Armenien das erste Land in die Welt, das Christentum als offizielle Staatsreligion anzunehmen, whrend in Armenien seit 40 n. Chr. eine Reihe christlicher Gemeinschaften gegrndet wurden. Vor dem Christentum gab es verschiedene heidnische Gemeinschaften, die jedoch durch einen Zustrom christlicher Missionare konvertiert wurden.[PARAGRAPH:1] Nach dem Fall des armenischen Knigreichs im Jahr 428 wurde der grte Teil Armeniens als Marzpanat in das Sassanidenreich eingegliedert. Nach der Marzpanat-Zeit entwickelte sich Armenien zu einem autonomen Frstentum innerhalb des Arabischen Reiches und vereinigte auch zuvor vom Byzantinischen Reich eroberte armenische Gebiete wieder. Das Frstentum wurde vom Frsten von Armenien regiert, der vom Kalifen und dem byzantinischen Kaiser anerkannt wurde. Das Frstentum Armenien bestand bis 884, als es seine Unabhngigkeit vom geschwchten Arabischen Reich wiedererlangte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Das wiedererstandene armenische Knigreich wurde von der Bagratuni-Dynastie regiert und bestand bis 1045. Mit der Zeit trennten sich mehrere Gebiete des Bagratiden-Armeniens als unabhngige Knigreiche und Frstentmer wie das Knigreich Vaspurakan, das vom Haus Artsruni regiert wird, whrend es immer noch die Vormachtstellung der bagratidischen Knige anerkennt.[PARAGRAPH:1]Im Jahr 1045 eroberte das Byzantinische Reich das bagratidische Armenien. Bald fielen auch die anderen armenischen Staaten unter byzantinische Kontrolle. Die byzantinische Herrschaft war nur von kurzer Dauer, denn 1071 besiegten seldschukische Trken die Byzantiner und eroberten Armenien in der Schlacht von Manzikert, wodurch das Seldschukenreich gegrndet wurde. Um dem Tod oder der Knechtschaft durch diejenigen zu entgehen, die seinen Verwandten, Gagik II., Knig von Ani, ermordet hatten, begab sich ein Armenier namens Roupen mit einigen seiner Landsleute in die Schluchten des Taurusgebirges und dann nach Tarsus in Kilikien. Hier gewhrte ihnen der byzantinische Gouverneur des Ortes Schutz, wo schlielich das armenische Knigreich Kilikien gegrndet wurde.[PARAGRAPH:1]In den 1230er Jahren eroberten die mongolischen Ilchane das Frstentum Zakaryan sowie den Rest Armeniens. Den mongolischen Invasionen folgten bald die Invasionen anderer zentralasiatischer Stmme, die vom 12. bis 14. Jahrhundert andauerten. Nach unaufhrlichen Invasionen, von denen jede dem Land Zerstrung brachte, wurde Armenien mit der Zeit geschwcht. Im 16. Jahrhundert teilten das Osmanische Reich und das safawidische Persien Armenien unter sich auf.

TEXT.English: [H1]Ashot I Bagratuni[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Armenia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 862 - 890[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Ashot I Bagratuni was an Armenian prince who, with Ashot II, oversaw Armenia's second golden age (862-977). He was born to Smbat the Confessor. His family, the Bagratunis, was one of the most powerful in the kingdom along with the Artsruni. Both families were struggling for power through warfare against Arab invaders. He was recognized by the Abbasid Caliph as Prince of Princes of Armenia in 862. His later crowning as King of Armenia was consented to by Abbasid Caliph al-Mu'tamid in 885, a move to prevent intrusion into the Armenian territory by Basil I Byzantine emperor, an Armenian. [PARAGRAPH:1]Thus, Ashot restored the Armenian monarchy and became Armenia's first king since 428. He secured the favor of both the Byzantines and Arabs but ultimately showed loyalty to Basil and chose to conclude an alliance with the Byzantines in 885. Ashot was not the sole Armenian prince of the region (other principalities existed in Syunik, Vaspurakan, and Taron) yet he commanded the full support of the other princes who recognized his authority in his becoming of king. With his status of king, his authority also carried over to the neighboring states of Georgia, Caucasian Albania and several of the Arab emirates. Ashot's reign was brief and upon his death in 890, he was succeeded by his son Smbat I.

TEXT.German: [H1]Aschot I. Bagratuni[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Knig von Armenien[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Regierungszeit:[\BOLD] 862 - 890[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Aschot I. Bagratuni war ein armenischer Prinz, der zusammen mit Aschot II. das zweite goldene Zeitalter Armeniens (862977) leitete. Er wurde als Sohn von Smbat dem Beichtvater geboren. Seine Familie, die Bagratunis, war neben den Artsruni eine der mchtigsten im Knigreich. Beide Familien kmpften im Krieg gegen arabische Invasoren um die Macht. Er wurde 862 vom abbasidischen Kalifen als Prinz der Frsten Armeniens anerkannt. Seine sptere Krnung zum Knig von Armenien wurde 885 vom abbasidischen Kalifen al-Mu'tamid genehmigt, ein Schritt, um das Eindringen von Basilius I. von Byzanz in das armenische Gebiet zu verhindern Kaiser, ein Armenier. [PARAGRAPH:1]So stellte Aschot die armenische Monarchie wieder her und wurde Armeniens erster Knig seit 428. Er sicherte sich die Gunst sowohl der Byzantiner als auch der Araber, zeigte aber letztendlich Loyalitt gegenber Basilius und beschloss, 885 ein Bndnis mit den Byzantinern zu schlieen. Aschot war es Er war nicht der einzige armenische Frst der Region (andere Frstentmer existierten in Syunik, Vaspurakan und Taron), doch er verfgte ber die volle Untersttzung der anderen Frsten, die seine Autoritt bei seiner Ernennung zum Knig anerkannten. Mit seinem Status als Knig bertrug sich seine Autoritt auch auf die Nachbarstaaten Georgien, das kaukasische Albanien und mehrere arabische Emirate. Ashots Herrschaft war kurz und nach seinem Tod im Jahr 890 wurde sein Sohn Smbat I. sein Nachfolger.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Khwarezmian dynasty, also known as Khwarezmids, Khwarezm-Shahs was a Persianate Sunni Muslim dynasty of Turkic origin. They ruled Greater Iran in the High Middle Ages, in the period of about 1077 to 1231, first as vassals of the Seljuks, Kara-Khitan, and later as independent rulers, up until the Mongol invasions of the 13th century. The dynasty was founded by Anush Tigin Gharchai, a former slave of the Seljuk sultans, who was appointed the governor of Khwarezm.[PARAGRAPH:1]As the Seljuk state fell into chaos, the Khwarezmids expanded their territories southward. In 1194, the last Sultan of the Great Seljuk Empire, Togrl III, was defeated and killed by the Khwarezm ruler Ala ad-Din Tekish, who also freed himself of the Kara-Khitai. In 1200, Tekish died and was succeeded by his son, Ala ad-Din Muhammad, who by 1205 conquered the remaining parts of the Great Seljuk Empire, proclaiming himself Shah. He eventually became known as the Khwarezmshah. In 1212 he defeated the Gur-Khan Kutluk and conquered the lands of the Kara-Khitai, now ruling a territory from the Syr Darya almost all the way to Baghdad, and from the Indus River to the Caspian Sea.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1218, Genghis Khan sent a trade mission to the state, but at the town of Otrar the governor, suspecting the Khan's ambassadors to be spies, confiscated their goods and executed them. Genghis Khan demanded reparations, which the Shah refused to pay. Genghis retaliated with a force of 200,000 men, launching a multi-pronged invasion. In February 1220 the Mongolian army crossed the Syr Darya, beginning the Mongol invasion of Central Asia. The Mongols stormed Bukhara, Samarkand, and the Khwarezmid capital Urgench. The Shah fled and died some weeks later on an island in the Caspian Sea.[PARAGRAPH:1]The son of Ala ad-Din Muhammad, Jalal ad-Din Mingburnu attempted to flee to India, but the Mongols caught up with him before he got there, and he was defeated at the Battle of Indus. Returning to Persia, he gathered an army and re-established a kingdom. He never consolidated his power, however, spending the rest of his days struggling against the Mongols, the Seljuk Turks of Rum, and pretenders to his own throne. Upon losing Persia to Mongols, he escaped to Caucasus, conquered Azerbaijan and parts of Georgia. He then fought Ayyubids over Armenia, and was defeated in 1230. He escaped once again to Diyarbakir, only to be murdered by an assassin hired by the Seljuks.[PARAGRAPH:1]Though the Mongols had destroyed the Khwarezmian Empire in 1220, many Khwarezmians survived by working as mercenaries in northern Iraq. Ayyubid Sultan Salih Ayyub, in Egypt, later hired their services against his uncle Salih Ismail. The Khwarezmiyyas, heading south from Iraq towards Egypt, invaded Christian-held Jerusalem along the way, on July 11, 1244. The city's citadel, the Tower of David, surrendered on August 23. This triggered a call from Europe for the Seventh Crusade, but the Crusaders would never again be successful in retaking Jerusalem. After being conquered by the Khwarezmian forces, the city stayed under Muslim control until 1917, when it was taken from the Ottomans by the British.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Choresm-Dynastie, auch bekannt als Choresmier, Choresm-Shahs, war eine persische sunnitische muslimische Dynastie trkischen Ursprungs. Sie regierten den Groraum Iran im Hochmittelalter in der Zeit von etwa 1077 bis 1231, zunchst als Vasallen der Seldschuken, Kara-Khitan, und spter als unabhngige Herrscher, bis zu den Mongoleneinfllen im 13. Jahrhundert. Die Dynastie wurde von Anush Tigin Gharchai gegrndet, einem ehemaligen Sklaven der seldschukischen Sultane, der zum Gouverneur von Choresm ernannt wurde.[PARAGRAPH:1]Als der seldschukische Staat ins Chaos geriet, dehnten die Choresmier ihre Gebiete nach Sden aus. Im Jahr 1194 wurde der letzte Sultan des Groen Seldschukenreiches, Togrl III., vom Choresm-Herrscher Ala ad-Din Tekish besiegt und gettet, der sich auch von den Kara-Khitai befreite. Im Jahr 1200 starb Tekish und wurde von seinem Sohn Ala ad-Din Muhammad abgelst, der 1205 die restlichen Teile des Groen Seldschukenreiches eroberte und sich selbst zum Schah erklrte. Er wurde schlielich als Choresmshah bekannt. Im Jahr 1212 besiegte er den Gur-Khan Kutluk und eroberte die Lnder der Kara-Khitai, die nun ein Gebiet vom Syr Darya fast bis nach Bagdad und vom Indus bis zum Kaspischen Meer beherrschten.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1218 sandte Dschingis Khan eine Handelsmission in den Staat, doch in der Stadt Otrar beschlagnahmte der Gouverneur deren Gter und lie sie hinrichten, weil er die Botschafter des Khans fr Spione hielt. Dschingis Khan forderte Wiedergutmachung, die der Schah jedoch ablehnte. Dschingis revanchierte sich mit einer Streitmacht von 200.000 Mann und startete eine vielschichtige Invasion. Im Februar 1220 berquerte die mongolische Armee den Syr Darya und begann damit die mongolische Invasion in Zentralasien. Die Mongolen strmten Buchara, Samarkand und die Choresm-Hauptstadt Urgentsch. Der Schah floh und starb einige Wochen spter auf einer Insel im Kaspischen Meer.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der Sohn von Ala ad-Din Muhammad, Jalal ad-Din Mingburnu, versuchte nach Indien zu fliehen, aber die Mongolen holten ihn vor ihm ein kam dort an und wurde in der Schlacht am Indus besiegt. Als er nach Persien zurckkehrte, stellte er eine Armee zusammen und grndete ein neues Knigreich. Er konnte seine Macht jedoch nie festigen und verbrachte den Rest seiner Tage damit, gegen die Mongolen, die seldschukischen Trken von Rum und Anwrter auf seinen eigenen Thron zu kmpfen. Nachdem er Persien an die Mongolen verloren hatte, floh er in den Kaukasus, eroberte Aserbaidschan und Teile Georgiens. Anschlieend kmpfte er gegen die Ayyubiden um Armenien und wurde 1230 besiegt. Er floh erneut nach Diyarbakir, wurde jedoch von einem von den Seldschuken angeheuerten Attentter ermordet berlebte, indem er als Sldner im Nordirak arbeitete. Der in gypten lebende ayyubidische Sultan Salih Ayyub stellte ihre Dienste spter gegen seinen Onkel Salih Ismail ein. Die Choresmiyyas, die vom Irak nach Sden Richtung gypten zogen, fielen am 11. Juli 1244 unterwegs in das von Christen gehaltene Jerusalem ein. Die Zitadelle der Stadt, der Davidsturm, kapitulierte am 23. August. Dies lste einen Aufruf Europas zum Siebten Kreuzzug aus. aber den Kreuzfahrern wrde es nie wieder gelingen, Jerusalem zurckzuerobern. Nach der Eroberung durch die Choresm-Streitkrfte blieb die Stadt bis 1917 unter muslimischer Kontrolle, als sie von den Briten den Osmanen entrissen wurde.

TEXT.English: [H1]Ala ad-Din Muhammad II[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Khwarezmshah[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 1200 - 1220[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Ala ad-Din Muhammad II was the ruler of the Khwarezmid Empire from 1200 to 1220. His father, Ala ad-Din Tekish, defeated the last Sultan of the Great Seljuk Empire Togrul III, and began expansion of the Khwarezmid territory. Ala ad-Din Muhammad continued from there, and by 1205 he had conquered all of Persia from the Seljuk Turks and in 1212 he defeated Kutluk, the Gur-Khan of the Kara Khitay (Kara-Khitan Khanate). When he had conquered all the lands from the river Jaxartes to the Persian Gulf he declared himself shah and demanded formal recognition from the caliph in Baghdad. When the caliph an-Nasir rejected his claim, Ala ad-Din Muhammad proclaimed one of his nobles caliph and marched towards Baghdad to depose an-Nasir. However, when crossing the Zagros Mountains, the shah's army was caught in a blizzard. Thousands of warriors died and with the army decimated the generals had no choice but to return home.[PARAGRAPH:1]It was in this situation that, in 1218, Genghis Khan sent his emissaries to the shah in Samarkand. The shah executed the Mongol diplomats and sent back their entourage with their heads shaved in defiance of the emerging great power, and Genghis retaliated with a force of 200,000 men that crossed the Jaxartes in 1220 and sacked the cities of Samarkand and Bukhara. Muhammad's capital, Urgench, followed in 1221. Ala ad-Din Muhammad fled and sought refuge throughout Khorasan, but died of pleurisy on an island in the Caspian Sea near the port of Abaskun some weeks later.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Shaybanids are the patrilineal descendants of Shayban (Shiban), the fifth son of Jochi and grandson of Genghis Khan. Until the mid-14th century, they acknowledged the authority of the descendants of Batu Khan and Orda Khan, such as Uzbeg Khan. The Shaybanid horde was converted to Islam in 1282 and gradually assumed the name of Uzbeks.[PARAGRAPH:1]As the lineages of Batu and Orda died out in the course of the great civil wars of the 14th century, the Shaybanids under Abu'l-Khayr Khan declared themselves the only legitimate successors to Jochi and put forward claims to the whole of his enormous ulus, which included parts of Siberia and Kazakhstan. Their rivals were the Timurids, who claimed descent from Jochi's thirteenth son by a concubine. Several decades of strife left the Timurids in control of the Great Horde and its successor states in Europe, namely, the Khanates of Kazan, Astrakhan, and Crimea.[PARAGRAPH:1]However, the Shaybanids under Muhammad Shaybani were able to wrest control of Samarkand, Bukhara and (for a time) Herat from the Timurids, establishing the Shaybanid dynasty as rulers of the independent Khanates of Bukhora and Khwarezm (Khiva).

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Shaibaniden sind die patrilinearen Nachkommen von Shaiban (Shiban), dem fnften Sohn von Jochi und Enkel von Dschingis Khan. Bis zur Mitte des 14. Jahrhunderts erkannten sie die Autoritt der Nachkommen von Batu Khan und Orda Khan an, beispielsweise Uzbeg Khan. Die Schaibaniden-Horde konvertierte 1282 zum Islam und nahm nach und nach den Namen Usbeken an.[PARAGRAPH:1]Als die Linien von Batu und Orda im Verlauf der groen Brgerkriege des 14. Jahrhunderts ausstarben, verblieben die Schaibaniden unter Abu'l -Khayr Khan erklrte sich zum einzigen legitimen Nachfolger von Jochi und erhob Ansprche auf seinen gesamten riesigen Ulus, der Teile Sibiriens und Kasachstans umfasste. Ihre Rivalen waren die Timuriden, die behaupteten, von Jochis dreizehntem Sohn und einer Konkubine abzustammen. Mehrere Jahrzehnte des Konflikts bescherten den Timuriden die Kontrolle ber die Groe Horde und ihre Nachfolgestaaten in Europa, nmlich die Khanate Kasan, Astrachan und Krim.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Shaibaniden unter Muhammad Shaibani konnten jedoch die Kontrolle ber sie erlangen Samarkand, Buchara und (zeitweise) Herat von den Timuriden, wodurch die Schaibaniden-Dynastie als Herrscher der unabhngigen Khanate Buchara und Choresm (Chiwa) etabliert wurde.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]The Shaybanids are the patrilineal descendants of Shayban (Shiban), the fifth son of Jochi and grandson of Genghis Khan. Until the mid-14th century, they acknowledged the authority of the descendants of Batu Khan and Orda Khan, such as Uzbeg Khan. The Shaybanid horde was converted to Islam in 1282 and gradually assumed the name of Uzbeks.[PARAGRAPH:1]As the lineages of Batu and Orda died out in the course of the great civil wars of the 14th century, the Shaybanids under Abu'l-Khayr Khan declared themselves the only legitimate successors to Jochi and put forward claims to the whole of his enormous ulus, which included parts of Siberia and Kazakhstan. Their rivals were the Timurids, who claimed descent from Jochi's thirteenth son by a concubine. Several decades of strife left the Timurids in control of the Great Horde and its successor states in Europe, namely, the Khanates of Kazan, Astrakhan, and Crimea.[PARAGRAPH:1]However, the Shaybanids under Muhammad Shaybani were able to wrest control of Samarkand, Bukhara and (for a time) Herat from the Timurids, establishing the Shaybanid dynasty as rulers of the independent Khanates of Bukhora and Khwarezm (Khiva).

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Fatimids were Arabs who claimed descent from Fatima, daughter of the Prophet Muhammad, and Ali, his son-in-law. They promoted the Shi'a sect of Islam and considered themselves the Prophet's rightful heirs. After establishing a base of power in Tunisia among the Berbers, Ubayd Allah proclaimed himself the first Fatimid caliph in 909 AD. He was theologically opposed to the Abbasid caliph (then in Baghdad), who represented the Sunni sect and most of the Islamic world.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Fatimids needed a commercial base stronger than what Tunisia offered if they were to achieve political success against the Baghdad caliph. They invaded Egypt several times, but it was not until 969 AD that the Fatimids conquered Egypt under their fourth caliph, al-Muiz. To celebrate this victory and to make Egypt their center of power, al-Muiz began the construction of a new capital city close by the Nile. The planet al-Qahir (Mars) was governing the sky at the time, so they named the new city al-Qahirah (Cairo). Cairo was built to a plan made by al-Muiz and it grew to become a literary center featuring the great al-Azhar mosque, university and libraries.[PARAGRAPH:1]With Egypt under their control, the Fatimids could compete commercially with Baghdad. They developed the Red Sea route as an alternative to the Persian Gulf route for trade with Asia. They also expanded their territory north into Palestine and southeast to the holy cities of Mecca and Medina, and they sent missionaries farther abroad to help spread Shia Islam. However, they neglected their original base of power in Tunisia and lost control of it to independent dynasties.[PARAGRAPH:1]Cairo prospered but the Fatimid Caliphate weakened, and most of the Egyptian population remained Sunni Muslim. After the Second Crusade in the middle of the 12th century, Christians and Muslims fought for control of Egypt's wealth. The Kurdish general Saladin, fighting under Syrian rule, took the position of vizier in Egypt around this time in defense of Egypt. He was widely praised by Muslims and Christians. Saladin replaced the Fatimid Caliphate with his own Ayyubid Sultanate after the death of Caliph al-Adid in 1171, putting fellow Kurds in positions of power and allying Egypt once again with the Abbasid Caliphate.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Fatimiden waren Araber, die behaupteten, von Fatima, der Tochter des Propheten Mohammed, und Ali, seinem Schwiegersohn, abzustammen. Sie frderten die schiitische Sekte des Islam und betrachteten sich als rechtmige Erben des Propheten. Nachdem er in Tunesien unter den Berbern eine Machtbasis aufgebaut hatte, erklrte sich Ubayd Allah im Jahr 909 n. Chr. zum ersten fatimidischen Kalifen. Er war theologisch gegen den abbasidischen Kalifen (damals in Bagdad), der die sunnitische Sekte und den grten Teil der islamischen Welt vertrat.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Fatimiden brauchten eine kommerzielle Basis, die strker war als die, die Tunesien bot, wenn sie gegen sie politischen Erfolg erzielen wollten der Kalif von Bagdad. Sie fielen mehrmals in gypten ein, aber erst 969 n. Chr. eroberten die Fatimiden gypten unter ihrem vierten Kalifen, al-Muiz. Um diesen Sieg zu feiern und gypten zu seinem Machtzentrum zu machen, begann al-Muiz mit dem Bau einer neuen Hauptstadt in der Nhe des Nils. Der Planet al-Qahir (Mars) regierte zu dieser Zeit den Himmel, daher nannten sie die neue Stadt al-Qahirah (Kairo). Kairo wurde nach einem Plan von al-Muiz erbaut und entwickelte sich zu einem literarischen Zentrum mit der groen al-Azhar-Moschee, einer Universitt und Bibliotheken.[PARAGRAPH:1]Da gypten unter ihrer Kontrolle war, konnten die Fatimiden kommerziell mit Bagdad konkurrieren. Sie entwickelten die Route ber das Rote Meer als Alternative zur Route ber den Persischen Golf fr den Handel mit Asien. Sie dehnten ihr Territorium auch nach Norden nach Palstina und nach Sdosten bis zu den heiligen Stdten Mekka und Medina aus und schickten Missionare weiter ins Ausland, um bei der Verbreitung des schiitischen Islam zu helfen. Sie vernachlssigten jedoch ihre ursprngliche Machtbasis in Tunesien und verloren die Kontrolle darber an unabhngige Dynastien.[PARAGRAPH:1]Kairo florierte, aber das Fatimiden-Kalifat wurde schwcher und der Groteil der gyptischen Bevlkerung blieb sunnitischer Muslim. Nach dem Zweiten Kreuzzug Mitte des 12. Jahrhunderts kmpften Christen und Muslime um die Kontrolle ber den Reichtum gyptens. Der kurdische General Salah ad-Din (Saladin), der unter syrischer Herrschaft kmpfte, bernahm um diese Zeit die Position des Wesirs in gypten zur Verteidigung gyptens. Er wurde von Muslimen und Christen weithin gelobt. Nach dem Tod des Kalifen al-Adid im Jahr 1171 ersetzte Salah ad-Din das Fatimiden-Kalifat durch sein eigenes Ayyubiden-Sultanat, brachte seine Kurden in Machtpositionen und verbndete gypten erneut mit dem Abbasiden-Kalifat.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Ayyubids were a Sunni Muslim dynasty of Kurdish origin, centered in Cairo and Damascus that ruled much of the Middle East during the 12th and 13th centuries CE. The Ayyubid family, under the brothers Ayyub and Shirkuh, originally served as soldiers for the Zengids until they gradually gained independence from them under Saladin, Ayyub's son. In 1171, Saladin proclaimed himself sultan of Egypt after dissolving the Fatimid Caliphate upon the death of al-Adid. The Ayyubids spent the next decade launching conquests throughout the region and by 1183, the Ayyubid state included Egypt, Syria, northern Mesopotamia, the Hejaz, Yemen, and the North African coast up to the borders of modern-day Tunisia. Most of the Kingdom of Jerusalem, consisting of Palestine and Transjordan fell to the Ayyubids after their victory at the Battle of Hattin in 1187. However, the Crusaders regained control of Palestine's coastline in the 1190s.[PARAGRAPH:1]After the death of Saladin, his sons contested control over the empire, but Saladin's brother al-Adil eventually established himself as sultan in 1200. In the 1230s, the Ayyubid rulers of Syria attempted to assert their independence from Egypt and remained divided until Egyptian sultan as-Salih Ayyub restored Ayyubid unity by taking over most of Syria, excluding Aleppo, by 1247. By then, local Muslim dynasties had driven out the Ayyubids from Yemen, the Hejaz, and parts of Mesopotamia. After repelling a Crusader invasion of the Nile Delta, as-Salih Ayyub's Mamluk generals overthrew al-Mu'azzam Turanshah who succeeded Ayyub after his death in 1250. This effectively ended Ayyubid power in Egypt and a number of attempts by the rulers of Syria, led by an-Nasir Yusuf of Aleppo, to recover it failed. In 1260, the Mongols sacked Aleppo and wrested control of what remained of the Ayyubid territories soon after. The Mamluks, who forced out the Mongols after the destruction of the Ayyubid dynasty, maintained the Ayyubid principality of Hama until deposing its last ruler in 1341.[PARAGRAPH:1]During their relatively short-lived tenure, the Ayyubids ushered in an era of economic prosperity in the lands they ruled and the facilities and patronage provided by the Ayyubids led to a resurgence in intellectual activity in the Islamic world. This period was also marked by an Ayyubid process of vigorously strengthening Sunni Muslim dominance in the region by constructing numerous madrasas in their major cities.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Ayyubiden waren eine sunnitisch-muslimische Dynastie kurdischer Herkunft mit Sitz in Kairo und Damaskus, die im 12. und 13. Jahrhundert n. Chr. einen Groteil des Nahen Ostens beherrschte. Die Ayyubid-Familie unter den Brdern Ayyub und Shirkuh diente ursprnglich als Soldaten fr die Zengiden, bis sie unter Saladin, Ayyubs Sohn, nach und nach die Unabhngigkeit von ihnen erlangten. Im Jahr 1171 proklamierte Saladin sich selbst zum Sultan von gypten, nachdem er nach dem Tod von al-Adid das Fatimiden-Kalifat aufgelst hatte. Die Ayyubiden verbrachten das nchste Jahrzehnt damit, Eroberungen in der gesamten Region zu starten, und 1183 umfasste der Ayyubidenstaat gypten, Syrien, Nordmesopotamien, den Hedschas, Jemen und die nordafrikanische Kste bis zu den Grenzen des heutigen Tunesien. Der grte Teil des Knigreichs Jerusalem, bestehend aus Palstina und Transjordanien, fiel nach ihrem Sieg in der Schlacht von Hattin im Jahr 1187 an die Ayyubiden. In den 1190er Jahren erlangten die Kreuzfahrer jedoch die Kontrolle ber die Kste Palstinas zurck.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nach dem Tod von Saladin Seine Shne bestritten die Kontrolle ber das Reich, aber Saladins Bruder al-Adil etablierte sich schlielich im Jahr 1200 als Sultan. In den 1230er Jahren versuchten die Ayyubiden-Herrscher Syriens, ihre Unabhngigkeit von gypten durchzusetzen, und blieben geteilt, bis der gyptische Sultan as-Salih Ayyub sie wiederherstellte Einheit der Ayyubiden durch die bernahme des grten Teils Syriens, mit Ausnahme von Aleppo, bis 1247. Zu diesem Zeitpunkt hatten lokale muslimische Dynastien die Ayyubiden aus dem Jemen, dem Hedschas und Teilen Mesopotamiens vertrieben. Nachdem die mamlukischen Generle von as-Salih Ayyub eine Invasion der Kreuzfahrer im Nildelta abgewehrt hatten, strzten sie al-Mu'azzam Turanshah, der Ayyub nach seinem Tod im Jahr 1250 folgte. Dies beendete effektiv die Macht der Ayyubiden in gypten und eine Reihe von Versuchen der Herrscher Syriens, Unter der Fhrung von an-Nasir Yusuf aus Aleppo scheiterte die Wiederherstellung. Im Jahr 1260 plnderten die Mongolen Aleppo und entrissen kurz darauf die Kontrolle ber die verbliebenen ayyubidischen Gebiete. Die Mamluken, die die Mongolen nach der Zerstrung der Ayyubid-Dynastie vertrieben, behielten das Ayyubid-Frstentum Hama bis zur Absetzung seines letzten Herrschers im Jahr 1341.[PARAGRAPH:1]Whrend ihrer relativ kurzlebigen Amtszeit leiteten die Ayyubiden eine ra ein Der wirtschaftliche Wohlstand in den von ihnen beherrschten Lndern und die von den Ayyubiden bereitgestellten Einrichtungen und Schirmherrschaften fhrten zu einem Wiederaufleben der intellektuellen Aktivitt in der islamischen Welt. Diese Zeit war auch von einem ayyubidischen Prozess geprgt, der die sunnitisch-muslimische Dominanz in der Region durch den Bau zahlreicher Madrasas in ihren Grostdten energisch strkte.

After repelling a Crusader invasion of the Nile Delta, as-Salih Ayyub's Mamluk generals overthrew al-Mu'azzam Turanshah who succeeded Ayyub after his death in 1250. This effectively ended Ayyubid power in Egypt and a number of attempts by the rulers of Syria, led by an-Nasir Yusuf of Aleppo, to recover it failed. In 1260, the Mongols sacked Aleppo and wrested control of what remained of the Ayyubid territories soon after. The Mamluks, who forced out the Mongols after the destruction of the Ayyubid dynasty, maintained the Ayyubid principality of Hama until deposing its last ruler in 1341.[PARAGRAPH:1]During their relatively short-lived tenure, the Ayyubids ushered in an era of economic prosperity in the lands they ruled and the facilities and patronage provided by the Ayyubids led to a resurgence in intellectual activity in the Islamic world. This period was also marked by an Ayyubid process of vigorously strengthening Sunni Muslim dominance in the region by constructing numerous madrasas in their major cities.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A mamluk was a slave soldier who converted to Islam and served the Muslim caliphs and the Ayyubid sultans during the Middle Ages. Over time, they became a powerful military caste often defeating the Crusaders. On more than one occasion, they seized power for themselves; for example, ruling Egypt in the Mamluk Sultanate from 1250-1517.[PARAGRAPH:1]The first mamluks served the Abbasid caliphs at the end of the 9th century Baghdad. The Mamluk system was an evolution of a previous system, the Ghulam system, invented by the Caliph al-Mu'tasim, in which Turkish prisoners of war became the caliphal guard. This system ended in disaster in the 860s with the murder of four caliphs in a row, and the Mamluk system was created on its ruins. The main difference was that the Mamluks were captured as children and then trained and moulded within the Islamic world to ensure their loyalty to their masters. The Abbasids "recruited" them mainly from areas near the Caucasus (mainly Circassian and Georgian) in later periods, and in the 13th-14th centuries from areas north of the Black Sea (mainly Turkic, most of whom were Kipchak Turks), as well as boys from East Slav populations. Those captured were of non-Muslim origin.[PARAGRAPH:1]After mamluks had converted to Islam, many were trained as cavalry soldiers. Mamluks had to follow the dictates of furusiyya, a code that included values such as courage and generosity, and also cavalry tactics, horsemanship, archery and treatment of wounds, etc.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mamluks lived within their garrisons and mainly spent their time with each other. Their entertainments included sporting events such as archery competitions and presentations of mounted combat skills at least twice a week. The intensive and rigorous training of each new recruit helped ensure continuity of mamluk practices.[PARAGRAPH:1]In June 1249, the Seventh Crusade under Louis IX of France landed in Egypt and took Damietta. The Egyptian troops retreated at first. When the Egyptian sultan As-Salih Ayyub died, the power passed briefly to his son Turanshah and then his favorite wife Shajar Al-Durr. She took control with mamluk support and launched a counterattack. Troops of the Bahri commander Baibars defeated Louis's troops. The king delayed his retreat too long and was captured by the Mamluks in March 1250, and agreed to a ransom of 400,000 livres. Political pressure for a male leader made Shajar marry the mamluk commander Aybak; he was later killed in his bath, and in the power struggle that ensued vice-regent Qutuz took over. He formally founded the first Mamluk sultanate and the Bahri dynasty.[PARAGRAPH:1]When the Mongol troops of Hulagu Khan sacked Baghdad in 1258 and advanced towards Syria, Mamluk Emir Baibars left Damascus to Cairo where he was welcomed by Sultan Qutuz. After taking Damascus, Hulagu demanded that Qutuz surrender Egypt but Qutuz had Hulegu's envoys killed and, with Baibars' help, mobilized his troops. Although Hulegu had to leave for the East when great Khan Mngke died in action against the Southern Song, he left his lieutenant, the Christian Kitbuqa, in charge. Qutuz drew the Mongol army into an ambush near the Orontes River, routed them at the Battle of Ain Jalut and captured and executed Kitbuqa.[PARAGRAPH:1]After this great triumph, Qutuz was assassinated by conspiring Mamluks. It was said that Baibars, who seized power, was involved in the assassination. In the following centuries power was often transferred this way: the average reign of a mamluk ruler was seven years.[PARAGRAPH:1]The mamluks defeated the Mongols a second time in Homs in 1260 and began to drive them back east. In the process they consolidated their power over Syria, fortified the area, formed mail routes, and formed diplomatic connections between the local princes. Baibars's troops attacked Acre in 1263, captured Caesaria in 1265, and massacred the inhabitants of Antioch in 1268.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Mamluk Sultanate survived until 1517, when it was conquered by the Ottoman Empire. The institution of the mamluks continued under the Ottomans, although not in the same form as under the Sultanate.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Mamluke war ein Sklavensoldat, der zum Islam konvertierte und im Mittelalter den muslimischen Kalifen und den Ayyubiden-Sultanen diente. Im Laufe der Zeit entwickelten sie sich zu einer mchtigen Militrkaste, die hufig die Kreuzfahrer besiegte. Mehr als einmal ergriffen sie die Macht; Zum Beispiel herrschten sie von 1250 bis 1517 im Mamluken-Sultanat ber gypten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die ersten Mamluken dienten den abbasidischen Kalifen Ende des 9. Jahrhunderts in Bagdad. Das Mamluk-System war eine Weiterentwicklung eines frheren Systems, des Ghulam-Systems, das vom Kalifen al-Mu'tasim erfunden wurde und in dem trkische Kriegsgefangene die Kalifenwache bernahmen. Dieses System endete in den 860er Jahren mit der Ermordung von vier Kalifen in Folge in einer Katastrophe, und auf seinen Ruinen entstand das Mamluk-System. Der Hauptunterschied bestand darin, dass die Mamluken als Kinder gefangen genommen und dann in der islamischen Welt ausgebildet und geformt wurden, um ihre Loyalitt gegenber ihren Herren sicherzustellen. Die Abbasiden "rekrutierten" sie in spteren Perioden hauptschlich aus Gebieten in der Nhe des Kaukasus (hauptschlich Tscherkessen und Georgier) und im 13.-14. Jahrhundert auch aus Gebieten nrdlich des Schwarzen Meeres (hauptschlich Trken, von denen die meisten Kiptschak-Trken waren). als Jungen aus ostslawischen Bevlkerungsgruppen. Die Gefangenen waren nichtmuslimischer Herkunft.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nachdem die Mamluken zum Islam konvertiert waren, wurden viele zu Kavalleriesoldaten ausgebildet. Mamluken mussten den Geboten der Furusiyya folgen, einem Kodex, der Werte wie Mut und Grozgigkeit, aber auch Kavallerietaktiken, Reitkunst, Bogenschieen und Wundbehandlung usw. umfasste.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mamluken lebten in ihren Garnisonen und verbrachten hauptschlich ihre Zeit miteinander. Zu ihren Unterhaltungsmglichkeiten gehrten mindestens zweimal pro Woche Sportveranstaltungen wie Bogenschieen-Wettbewerbe und Vorfhrungen berittener Kampfknste. Die intensive und strenge Ausbildung jedes neuen Rekruten trug dazu bei, die Kontinuitt der Mamluk-Praktiken sicherzustellen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Im Juni 1249 landete der Siebte Kreuzzug unter Ludwig IX. von Frankreich in gypten und eroberte Damietta. Die gyptischen Truppen zogen sich zunchst zurck. Als der gyptische Sultan As-Salih Ayyub starb, ging die Macht kurzzeitig auf seinen Sohn Turanshah und dann auf seine Lieblingsfrau Shajar Al-Durr ber. Mit Untersttzung der Mamluken bernahm sie die Kontrolle und startete einen Gegenangriff. Truppen des Bahri-Kommandanten Baibars besiegten Ludwigs Truppen. Der Knig verzgerte seinen Rckzug zu lange, wurde im Mrz 1250 von den Mamluken gefangen genommen und stimmte einem Lsegeld von 400.000 Livres zu. Politischer Druck fr einen mnnlichen Anfhrer veranlasste Shajar, den Mamluk-Kommandanten Aybak zu heiraten; Spter wurde er in seinem Bad gettet und im darauf folgenden Machtkampf bernahm Vizeregent Qutuz die Macht. Er grndete offiziell das erste mamlukische Sultanat und die Bahri-Dynastie.[PARAGRAPH:1]Als die mongolischen Truppen von Hulagu Khan 1258 Bagdad plnderten und nach Syrien vordrangen, verlie der mamlukische Emir Baibars Damaskus und ging nach Kairo, wo er von Sultan Qutuz begrt wurde. Nach der Einnahme von Damaskus verlangte Hulagu von Qutuz die bergabe gyptens, doch Qutuz lie Hulegus Gesandte tten und mobilisierte mit Baibars' Hilfe seine Truppen. Obwohl Hulegu in den Osten aufbrechen musste, als der groe Khan Mngke im Kampf gegen die Southern Song starb, berlie er seinem Leutnant, dem Christen Kitbuqa, die Fhrung. Qutuz zog die mongolische Armee in einen Hinterhalt in der Nhe des Orontes-Flusses, schlug sie in der Schlacht von Ain Jalut in die Flucht und eroberte und hingerichtete Kitbuqa.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nach diesem groen Triumph wurde Qutuz von verschworenen Mamluken ermordet. Es hie, Baibars, der die Macht bernommen hatte, sei an dem Attentat beteiligt gewesen. In den folgenden Jahrhunderten wurde die Macht oft auf diese Weise bertragen: Die durchschnittliche Regierungszeit eines mamlukischen Herrschers betrug sieben Jahre.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Mamluken besiegten die Mongolen 1260 in Homs ein zweites Mal und begannen, sie nach Osten zurckzudrngen. Dabei festigten sie ihre Macht ber Syrien, befestigten das Gebiet, richteten Postwege ein und stellten diplomatische Verbindungen zwischen den rtlichen Frsten her. Baibars' Truppen griffen 1263 Acre an, eroberten 1265 Caesaria und massakrierten 1268 die Einwohner von Antiochia.[PARAGRAPH:1]Das Mamluken-Sultanat berlebte bis 1517, als es vom Osmanischen Reich erobert wurde. Die Institution der Mamluken blieb unter den Osmanen bestehen, wenn auch nicht in der gleichen Form wie unter dem Sultanat.

TEXT.English: [H1]Baibars[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Mamluk Sultan of Egypt and Syria[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c. 1223 - July 1, 1277[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Baibars was a commander of the Mamluks in around 1250, when he defeated the Seventh Crusade of Louis IX of France. He was still a commander under Sultan Qutuz at the Battle of Ain Jalut in 1260 when he decisively defeated the Mongols. After the battle Sultan Qutuz was assassinated while on a hunting expedition. It was said that Baibars was involved in the assassination because he expected to be rewarded with the governorship of Aleppo for his military success; but Qutuz, fearing his ambition, refused to give such a post and disappointed him. Baibars succeeded Qutuz as Sultan of Egypt. [PARAGRAPH:1]His reign marked the start of an age of Mamluk dominance in the Eastern Mediterranean and solidified the durability of their military system. He managed to pave the way for the end of the Crusader presence in Syria and to unite Egypt and Syria into one powerful state that was able to fend off threats from both Crusaders and Mongols. As Sultan, Baibars also engaged in a combination of diplomacy and military action which allowed the Mamluks to greatly expand their empire.

TEXT.German: [H1]Baibars[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Mamluken-Sultan von gypten und Syrien[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] ca. 1223 - 1. Juli 1277[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Baibars war um 1250 ein Kommandeur der Mamluken, als er den Siebten Kreuzzug Ludwigs IX. von Frankreich besiegte. Er war immer noch Kommandeur unter Sultan Qutuz in der Schlacht von Ain Jalut im Jahr 1260, als er die Mongolen entscheidend besiegte. Nach der Schlacht wurde Sultan Qutuz whrend einer Jagdexpedition ermordet. Es hie, Baibars sei an dem Attentat beteiligt gewesen, weil er erwartete, fr seinen militrischen Erfolg mit dem Gouverneursposten von Aleppo belohnt zu werden; aber Qutuz, der seinen Ehrgeiz frchtete, weigerte sich, einen solchen Posten zu vergeben und enttuschte ihn. Baibars trat die Nachfolge von Qutuz als Sultan von gypten an. [PARAGRAPH:1]Seine Herrschaft markierte den Beginn eines Zeitalters der Mamluken-Dominanz im stlichen Mittelmeerraum und festigte die Bestndigkeit ihres Militrsystems. Es gelang ihm, den Weg fr das Ende der Kreuzfahrerprsenz in Syrien zu ebnen und gypten und Syrien zu einem mchtigen Staat zu vereinen, der in der Lage war, Bedrohungen sowohl durch Kreuzfahrer als auch durch Mongolen abzuwehren. Als Sultan beteiligte sich Baibars auch an einer Kombination aus Diplomatie und militrischen Aktionen, die es den Mamluken ermglichte, ihr Reich erheblich zu erweitern.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The province of Sindh and the people inhabiting the region had been designated after the river known in as the Sindhus (Indus) River. Home to the ancient Indus Valley Civilization, in the Middle Ages it saw the arrival of Islam, becoming the easternmost province of the Umayyad, and later Abbasid Caliphate. The Umayyad conqueror, Muhammad bin Qasim, built the city of Mansura as his capital. At the port city of Daybul most of the Bawarij embraced Islam and become known as Sindhi Sailors; they became famous for their skills in navigation, geography and languages. In fact, they inspired the One Thousand and One Nights character Sindbad the Sailor.[PARAGRAPH:1]Direct Arab rule ended in 998 with the ascension of the local Soomra Dynasty, and they were the first local Sindhi Muslims to translate the Quran into the Sindhi language. The Soomros controlled Sindh directly as vassals the Abbasids from 1026 to 1351. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Soomros were one of the first Sindhi tribes to convert to Islam and they were known to the Arabs as the Al-Sumrah. They were taught Cavalry skills by the Arabs, and were renowned masters at riding the Arabian Horse and Camel, they created a network in Sindh which eventually facilitated their rule centered at Mansura. They often fought Hindu rebellions and raiders. [PARAGRAPH:1]Sultan Mahmud of Ghazni, challenged the Soomro Dynasty and besieged Mansura. The city was conquered, and the severely weakened Soomros moved their capital to Tharri, from which they continued to rule until complete decline in the 14th century. [PARAGRAPH:1]Independent Sultanate of Sindh made a return in 1339 with the ascension of the Samma dynasty, with Thatta as its capital. Sammas' state lasted till the early 16th century, when it collapsed after series of Mongol invasions. Afterwards, Sindh became a province of the Mogul Empire.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Provinz Sindh und die Menschen, die in der Region leben, wurden nach dem Fluss benannt, der frher als Sindhus (Indus) bekannt ist. Als Heimat der alten Indus-Tal-Zivilisation erlebte sie im Mittelalter die Ankunft des Islam und wurde zur stlichsten Provinz der Umayyaden und spter zum Abbasiden-Kalifat. Der Eroberer der Umayyaden, Muhammad bin Qasim, baute die Stadt Mansura als seine Hauptstadt. In der Hafenstadt Daybul konvertierten die meisten Bawarij zum Islam und wurden als Sindhi-Seeleute bekannt; Sie wurden berhmt fr ihre Fhigkeiten in Navigation, Geographie und Sprachen. Tatschlich inspirierten sie die Figur Sindbad der Seemann aus Tausendundeiner Nacht.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die direkte arabische Herrschaft endete 998 mit dem Aufstieg der lokalen Soomra-Dynastie, und sie waren die ersten lokalen Sindhi-Muslime, die den Koran ins bersetzten Sindhi-Sprache. Die Soomros kontrollierten Sindh direkt als Vasallen der Abbasiden von 1026 bis 1351. [PARAGRAPH:1]Die Soomros waren einer der ersten Sindhi-Stmme, die zum Islam konvertierten, und sie waren bei den Arabern als Al-Sumrah bekannt. Ihnen wurden von den Arabern Kavalleriefhigkeiten beigebracht, und sie waren berhmte Meister im Reiten des arabischen Pferdes und Kamels. Sie schufen ein Netzwerk in Sindh, das schlielich ihre Herrschaft mit Sitz in Mansura erleichterte. Sie kmpften oft gegen hinduistische Aufstnde und Ruber. [PARAGRAPH:1]Sultan Mahmud von Ghazni forderte die Soomro-Dynastie heraus und belagerte Mansura. Die Stadt wurde erobert und die stark geschwchten Soomros verlegten ihre Hauptstadt nach Tharri, von wo aus sie bis zum vlligen Niedergang im 14. Jahrhundert weiterherrschten. [PARAGRAPH:1]Das unabhngige Sultanat Sindh kehrte 1339 mit dem Aufstieg der Samma-Dynastie zurck, mit Thatta als Hauptstadt. Der Staat von Sammas bestand bis zum Beginn des 16. Jahrhunderts, als er nach einer Reihe mongolischer Invasionen zusammenbrach. Danach wurde Sindh eine Provinz des Mogulreichs.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Gujarat is a historical region and a modern state that played an important role in the economic history of India. Gujarat's coastal cities served as ports and trading centres in the Maurya and Gupta empires. After the fall of the Gupta empire in the 6th century, Gujarat flourished as an independent Hindu kingdom. The Arab rulers of Sindh sacked it in 770. A branch of the Pratihara clan ruled Gujarat after the 8th century. In 775 the first Parsi (Zoroastrian) refugees arrived in Gujarat from Iran.[PARAGRAPH:1]Between the 9th and 13th century, Gujarat became a flourishing kingdom under the Solankis, a Hindu Agnivanshi Rajput clan of Gurjar stock, descended from 6th century Badami Chalukyas. In Gujarat, Anhilwara (modern Siddhpur Patan) served as their capital. Anhilwara became one of the largest cities in India, with population estimated at 100,000 in the year 1000. The Solankis were patrons of the great seaside temple of Shiva at Somnath Patan in Kathiawar; Bhima Dev helped rebuild the temple after it was sacked by Mahmud of Ghazni in 1026. At its greatest extent, under Siddhraj Jaisinh, the Solanki kingdom included Gujarat, southern Rajputana and Malwa. Their power declined in 13th century, and in 1297 Gujarat was conquered by Delhi Sultanate.

TEXT.English: [H1]Siddhraj Jaisingh[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Solanki King of Gujarat[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1094 - 1143[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]The one name that stands out in the Solanki dynasty is Siddhraj Jaisingh. After ascending the throne in Anhilwara (Patan), he conquered Saurashtra, Kachchh, Malwa and south Gujarat. He gave shelter to many scholars of different religions and castes, and thus, during his reign, Anhilwara flourished in education, religion and commerce. [PARAGRAPH:1]The popular conception of Siddhraj mixes greatness and medieval callousness. One of the most prominent legends of the Gujarat bards is woven round the siege of Junagadh by Siddhraj Jaisingh. Siddhraj wanted to marry the princess Ranakdevi, but his vassal, Ra Khengar, the Chief of Junagadh, married her before he could do so. The enraged Siddharaj attacked the mountain-fortress of Junagadh. It fell after Ra Khengar's nephews betrayed him. Ranakdevi refused Siddharaj's advances for marriage after he had killed her husband and two sons. She was forcibly brought to Wadhwan where she committed the ritual of Sati at this place to protect her honour.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Chauhans, who were feudatories to the powerful Gurjara Pratihara empire during 8-10th c., later asserted their independence from the Gurjara Pratiharas, and in the early eleventh century, the Sakhambari king Ajaya-Raja founded the city of Ajayameru (Ajmer) in the southern part of their kingdom, and in the mid twelfth century, his successor Vigraharaja enlarged the state, captured Dhilika (the ancient name of Delhi) from the Tomaras and annexed some of their territory along the Yamuna River, including Haryana and Delhi. In 12th century the Chauhans dominated Delhi, Ajmer and Ranthambhore. They were also prominent at Godwar in the southwest of Rajputana, and at Hadoti (Bundi and Kota) in the east. Chauhans adopted a political policy that saw them indulge largely in campaigns against the Chalukyas and the Muslim invaders.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Chauhan kingdom became the leading state and a powerful kingdom in Northern India under King Prithviraj III (1165-1192), also known as Prithvi Raj Chauhan or Rai Pithora. Prithviraj III has become famous in folk tales and historical literature as the Chauhan king of Delhi who resisted and repelled the invasion by Muhammad of Ghor at the first Battle of Tarain in 1191. Armies from other Rajput kingdoms, including Mewar, assisted him. The Chauhan kingdom collapsed after Prithviraj was defeated by Muhammad of Ghor in 1192 at the Second Battle of Tarain.

Jahrhundert grndete der Sakhambari-Knig Ajaya-Raja die Stadt Ajayameru ( Ajmer) im sdlichen Teil ihres Knigreichs, und Mitte des 12. Jahrhunderts vergrerte sein Nachfolger Vigraharaja den Staat, eroberte Dhilika (der alte Name Delhis) von den Tomaras und annektierte einen Teil ihres Territoriums entlang des Yamuna-Flusses, darunter Haryana und Delhi. Im 12. Jahrhundert dominierten die Chauhans Delhi, Ajmer und Ranthambhore. Sie waren auch in Godwar im Sdwesten von Rajputana und in Hadoti (Bundi und Kota) im Osten prominent. Die Chauhans verfolgten eine politische Politik, die dazu fhrte, dass sie sich weitgehend Feldzgen gegen die Chalukyas und die muslimischen Invasoren widmeten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Das Chauhan-Knigreich wurde auch unter Knig Prithviraj III. (1165-1192) zum fhrenden Staat und mchtigen Knigreich in Nordindien bekannt als Prithvi Raj Chauhan oder Rai Pithora. Prithviraj III ist in Volksmrchen und in der historischen Literatur als Chauhan-Knig von Delhi berhmt geworden, der der Invasion von Muhammad von Ghor in der ersten Schlacht von Tarain im Jahr 1191 Widerstand leistete und diese abwehrte. Armeen aus anderen Rajput-Knigreichen, darunter Mewar, untersttzten ihn. Das Chauhan-Knigreich brach zusammen, nachdem Prithviraj 1192 in der zweiten Schlacht von Tarain von Muhammad von Ghor besiegt wurde.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]The Chauhans, who were feudatories to the powerful Gurjara Pratihara empire during 8-10th c., later asserted their independence from the Gurjara Pratiharas, and in the early eleventh century, the Sakhambari king Ajaya-Raja founded the city of Ajayameru (Ajmer) in the southern part of their kingdom, and in the mid twelfth century, his successor Vigraharaja enlarged the state, captured Dhilika (the ancient name of Delhi) from the Tomaras and annexed some of their territory along the Yamuna River, including Haryana and Delhi. In 12th century the Chauhans dominated Delhi, Ajmer and Ranthambhore. They were also prominent at Godwar in the southwest of Rajputana, and at Hadoti (Bundi and Kota) in the east. Chauhans adopted a political policy that saw them indulge largely in campaigns against the Chalukyas and the Muslim invaders.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Chauhan kingdom became the leading state and a powerful kingdom in Northern India under King Prithviraj III (1165-1192), also known as Prithvi Raj Chauhan or Rai Pithora. Prithviraj III has become famous in folk tales and historical literature as the Chauhan king of Delhi who resisted and repelled the invasion by Muhammad of Ghor at the first Battle of Tarain in 1191. Armies from other Rajput kingdoms, including Mewar, assisted him. The Chauhan kingdom collapsed after Prithviraj was defeated by Muhammad of Ghor in 1192 at the Second Battle of Tarain.

TEXT.English: [H1]Prithvi Raj III[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Rajput King of Ajmer and Delhi[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1166 - 1192[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Prithvi Raj Chauhan belonged to the Agnikula clan of Rajput Kshatriyas. He was the last independent Hindu king to sit upon the throne of Delhi. He succeeded to the throne in 1169 CE at the age of 20, and ruled from the twin capitals of Ajmer and Delhi, which he received from his maternal grand-father Ballal Sen of the Sen Dynasty in Bengal. He controlled much of present-day Rajasthan and Haryana, and unified the Rajputs against Muslim invasions. His elopement with Samyukta (Sanyogita), the daughter of Jai Chandra Rathod, the Gahadvala king of Kannauj, in 1175, is a popular romantic tale in India, and is one of the subjects of the Prithviraj Raso, an epic poem composed by Prithviraj's court poet and friend, Chand Bardai. [PARAGRAPH:1]Prithvi Raj defeated the Muslim ruler Sultan Shahabuddin Muhammad Ghori in the First Battle of Tarain in 1191 CE. Ghori attacked for a second time next year, and Prithvi Raj was defeated and captured at the Second Battle of Tarain in 1192 CE. Prithvi Raj was taken to Ghazna and executed. After his defeat, Delhi came under the control of Muslim rulers.

Prithvi Raj wurde nach Ghazna gebracht und hingerichtet. Nach seiner Niederlage geriet Delhi unter die Kontrolle muslimischer Herrscher.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Malwa is a region in west-central northern India occupying a plateau of volcanic origin in the western part of the state of Madhya Pradesh. Although political borders have fluctuated throughout history, the region has developed its own distinct culture and language. [PARAGRAPH:1]From the mid-tenth century, Malwa was ruled by the Paramara clan of Rajputs, who established a capital at Dhar. King Bhoja, who ruled from about 1010 to 1060, was known as the great polymath philosopher-king of medieval India; his extensive writings cover philosophy, poetry, medicine, veterinary science, phonetics, yoga, and archery. Under his rule Malwa became an intellectual centre of India. Bhoj also founded the city of Bhopal (Bhojpal) to secure the eastern part of his kingdom. His successors ruled until about 1200, when Malwa was conquered by the Delhi Sultanate.

Obwohl die politischen Grenzen im Laufe der Geschichte schwankten, hat die Region ihre eigene Kultur und Sprache entwickelt. [PARAGRAPH:1]Ab der Mitte des zehnten Jahrhunderts wurde Malwa vom Paramara-Clan der Rajputen regiert, der in Dhar eine Hauptstadt errichtete. Unter seiner Herrschaft wurde Malwa zu einem intellektuellen Zentrum Indiens. Bhoj grndete auch die Stadt Bhopal (Bhojpal), um den stlichen Teil seines Knigreichs zu sichern. Seine Nachfolger regierten bis etwa 1200, als Malwa vom Sultanat Delhi erobert wurde.

TEXT.English: [H1]Bhoja I[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Rajput King of Malwa[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c. 1000 - 1050[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Bhoja was from the Paramara dynasty, who ruled the Malwa region from the mid-tenth century to about 1285. His extensive writings cover philosophy, poetry, medicine, veterinary science, phonetics, yoga, and archery. Under his rule, Malwa and its capital Dhara Nagari (Dhar) became one of the chief intellectual centres of India. King Bhoja, together with the Solanki king Bhima of Gujarat (Anhilwara), rebuilt the temple at Somnath between 1026 and 1042 after it was sacked by Mahmud of Ghazni in 1024. Bhoja also founded the city of Bhopal, which is named after him, to secure the eastern frontier of his kingdom.
