TEXT.English: [TAB]The Ghorids were a medieval (12th to 13th century) Muslim dynasty of Iranian origin in Khorasan that was centered in Ghor (now a province in Afghanistan). At its zenith, their empire stretched over a vast area that included the whole of modern Afghanistan, the eastern parts of Iran and the northern section of the Indian subcontinent, as far as Delhi.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ghorids were bounded to Ghaznavids and Seljuks almost 150 years before 1148. Beginning in the mid-1100s, Ghor expressed its independence from the Ghaznavid Empire. In 1149 the Ghaznavid ruler Bahram Shah poisoned a local Ghorid leader, Qutb ud-Din, who had taken refuge in the city of Ghazna after a family quarrel. In revenge, the Ghorid chief Ala-ud-Din Husayn sacked the city of Ghazna and put it into fire for seven days and seven nights. It earned him the title of Jahansuz, meaning "the world burner". The Ghaznavids retook the city with Seljuk help, but lost it to Oghuz Turk freebooters.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1173, Shahabuddin Muhammad Ghori reconquered the city of Ghazna and assisted his brother Ghiyasuddin - to whom he was a loyal subordinate - in his contest with Khwarezmid Empire for the lordship of Khorasan. Shahabuddin Ghori captured Multan and Uch in 1175 and annexed the Ghaznavid principality of Lahore in 1186. After the death of his brother Ghiyas-ud-Din in 1202, he became the successor of his empire and ruled until his assassination in 1206 near Jhelum (in modern-day Pakistan). A confused struggle then ensued among the remaining Ghorid leaders, and the Khwarezmids were able to take over the Ghorids' lands west of Indus in about 1215. Though the Ghorids' empire was short-lived, Shahabuddin Ghori's conquests strengthened the foundations of Muslim rule in India. The lands east of Indus passed to one of Shahabuddin's Ghulam slaves, Qutb-ud-din Aibak. This state, known as Delhi Sultanate, eventually expanded to cover nearly all of Hindustan, and lasted until Mogul Empire replaced it in 16th century.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Ghoriden waren eine mittelalterliche (12. bis 13. Jahrhundert) muslimische Dynastie iranischer Herkunft in Khorasan, deren Zentrum in Ghor (heute eine Provinz in Afghanistan) lag. Auf seinem Hhepunkt erstreckte sich ihr Reich ber ein riesiges Gebiet, das das gesamte moderne Afghanistan, die stlichen Teile des Iran und den nrdlichen Teil des indischen Subkontinents bis nach Delhi umfasste.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ghoriden waren an Ghaznaviden und Seldschuken gebunden fast 150 Jahre vor 1148. Ab Mitte des 11. Jahrhunderts drckte Ghor seine Unabhngigkeit vom Ghaznawidenreich aus. Im Jahr 1149 vergiftete der Ghaznawiden-Herrscher Bahram Schah einen rtlichen Ghoridenfhrer, Qutb ud-Din, der nach einem Familienstreit in der Stadt Ghazna Zuflucht gesucht hatte. Aus Rache plnderte der Ghoridenhuptling Ala-ud-Din Husayn die Stadt Ghazna und steckte sie sieben Tage und sieben Nchte lang in Brand. Dies brachte ihm den Titel Jahansuz ein, was "der Weltbrenner" bedeutet. Die Ghaznaviden eroberten die Stadt mit seldschukischer Hilfe zurck, verloren sie jedoch an oghusisch-trkische Freibeuter.[PARAGRAPH:1]Im Jahr 1173 eroberte Shahabuddin Muhammad Ghori die Stadt Ghazna zurck und untersttzte seinen Bruder Ghiyasuddin - dem er ein treuer Untergebener war - in seinem Kampf mit dem Khwarezmid-Reich fr die Herrschaft von Khorasan. Shahabuddin Ghori eroberte 1175 Multan und Uch und annektierte 1186 das Ghaznawiden-Frstentum Lahore. Nach dem Tod seines Bruders Ghiyas-ud-Din im Jahr 1202 wurde er Nachfolger seines Reiches und regierte bis zu seiner Ermordung im Jahr 1206 in der Nhe von Jhelum (im Jahr 1975). das heutige Pakistan). Anschlieend kam es zu einem verwirrenden Kampf zwischen den verbliebenen Anfhrern der Ghoriden, und die Khwarezmiden konnten um 1215 das Land der Ghoriden westlich von Indus bernehmen. Obwohl das Reich der Ghoriden nur von kurzer Dauer war, strkten Shahabuddin Ghoris Eroberungen die Grundlagen der muslimischen Herrschaft Indien. Das Land stlich von Indus ging an einen von Shahabuddins Ghulam-Sklaven, Qutb-ud-din Aibak, ber. Dieser Staat, bekannt als Sultanat Delhi, dehnte sich schlielich auf fast ganz Hindustan aus und bestand, bis ihn das Mogulreich im 16. Jahrhundert ablste.

A confused struggle then ensued among the remaining Ghorid leaders, and the Khwarezmids were able to take over the Ghorids' lands west of Indus in about 1215. Though the Ghorids' empire was short-lived, Shahabuddin Ghori's conquests strengthened the foundations of Muslim rule in India. The lands east of Indus passed to one of Shahabuddin's Ghulam slaves, Qutb-ud-din Aibak. This state, known as Delhi Sultanate, eventually expanded to cover nearly all of Hindustan, and lasted until Mughal Empire replaced it in 16th century.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]The Ghorids were a medieval (12th to 13th century) Muslim dynasty of Iranian origin in Khorasan that was centered in Ghor (now a province in Afghanistan). At its zenith, their empire stretched over a vast area that included the whole of modern Afghanistan, the eastern parts of Iran and the northern section of the Indian subcontinent, as far as Delhi.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ghorids were bounded to Ghaznavids and Seljuks almost 150 years before 1148. Beginning in the mid-1100s, Ghor expressed its independence from the Ghaznavid Empire. In 1149 the Ghaznavid ruler Bahram Shah poisoned a local Ghorid leader, Qutb ud-Din, who had taken refuge in the city of Ghazna after a family quarrel. In revenge, the Ghorid chief Ala-ud-Din Husayn sacked the city of Ghazna and put it into fire for seven days and seven nights. It earned him the title of Jahansuz, meaning "the world burner". The Ghaznavids retook the city with Seljuk help, but lost it to Oghuz Turk freebooters.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1173, Shahabuddin Muhammad Ghori reconquered the city of Ghazna and assisted his brother Ghiyasuddin - to whom he was a loyal subordinate - in his contest with Khwarezmid Empire for the lordship of Khorasan. Das heutige Pakistan).[PARAGRAPH:1]Dann kam es zu einem verwirrten Kampf zwischen den verbleibenden Ghuridenfhrern, und die Khwarezmiden konnten das Reich der Ghuriden um 1215 bernehmen. TEXT.English: [TAB]During the Delhi Sultanate, several Turkic and Afghan dynasties ruled from Delhi, including the Mamluk dynasty (1206-90), the Khilji dynasty (1290-1320), the Tughlaq dynasty (1320-1413), the Sayyid dynasty (1414-51), and the Lodi dynasty (1451-1526). [PARAGRAPH:1]The sultanate started when Qutb-ud-din Aibak, a slave appointed as the governor of Delhi by Muhammad Ghori, started an independent rule after the death of his master. Aibak began the construction of Qutub Minar, which was completed by Iltutmish, his successor and son-in-law. [PARAGRAPH:1]For most of its history, the Delhi Sultanate stretched over all of Northern Hindustan. At its greatest extent, under the Tughlaqs controlled all of the subcontinent except Tamil Nadu and some areas in Rajputana. Perhaps the greatest contribution of the Sultanate was its temporary success in insulating the subcontinent from the potential devastation of the Mongol invasion from Central Asia in the thirteenth century. However, the invasion of Tamerlane in 1398 significantly weakened the Delhi Sultanate. [PARAGRAPH:1]The sultanate revived briefly under the Lodis, but the last Lodi ruler, Ibrahim Lodi was greatly disliked by his court and subjects. Upon the death of his father Sikander Lodi, he quashed a brief rebellion led by some of his nobles who wanted his younger brother Jalal Khan to be the Sultan. After seizing the throne by having Jalal Khan murdered, he never really did succeed in pacifying his nobles. Subsequently Daulat Khan, the governor of Punjab and Alam Khan, his uncle, sent an invitation to Babur, the ruler of Kabul to invade Delhi. [PARAGRAPH:1]The first Battle of Panipat (April 1526) was fought between the forces of Babur and the Delhi Sultanate. Ibrahim Lodi was killed on the battlefield. By way of superior generalship, vast experience in warfare, effective strategy, and appropriate use of artillery, Babur won the First battle of Panipat and subsequently occupied Agra and Delhi. The new Mogul dynasty was to rule India for another 300 years.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Whrend des Sultanats Delhi regierten mehrere trkische und afghanische Dynastien von Delhi aus, darunter die Mamluk-Dynastie (1206-90), die Khilji-Dynastie (1290-1320), die Tughlaq-Dynastie (1320-1413) und die Sayyid-Dynastie (1414). -51) und der Lodi-Dynastie (1451-1526). [PARAGRAPH:1]Das Sultanat begann, als Qutb-ud-din Aibak, ein von Muhammad Ghori zum Gouverneur von Delhi ernannter Sklave, nach dem Tod seines Herrn eine unabhngige Herrschaft begann. Aibak begann mit dem Bau von Qutb Minar, der von Iltutmish, seinem Nachfolger und Schwiegersohn, fertiggestellt wurde. [PARAGRAPH:1]Whrend des grten Teils seiner Geschichte erstreckte sich das Sultanat Delhi ber ganz Nord-Hindustan. In ihrer grten Ausdehnung kontrollierten die Tughlaqs den gesamten Subkontinent mit Ausnahme von Tamil Nadu und einigen Gebieten in Rajputana. Der vielleicht grte Beitrag des Sultanats war sein vorbergehender Erfolg, den Subkontinent vor der mglichen Verwstung der mongolischen Invasion aus Zentralasien im 13. Jahrhundert zu schtzen. Die Invasion von Timur im Jahr 1398 schwchte das Sultanat Delhi jedoch erheblich. [PARAGRAPH:1]Das Sultanat erwachte unter den Lodis kurzzeitig wieder zum Leben, aber der letzte Lodi-Herrscher, Ibrahim Lodi, war bei seinem Hof und seinen Untertanen uerst unbeliebt. Nach dem Tod seines Vaters Sikander Lodi schlug er einen kurzen Aufstand einiger seiner Adligen nieder, die seinen jngeren Bruder Jalal Khan zum Sultan machen wollten. Nachdem er den Thron durch die Ermordung Jalal Khans bestiegen hatte, gelang es ihm nie wirklich, seine Adligen zu besnftigen. Anschlieend sandten Daulat Khan, der Gouverneur von Punjab, und Alam Khan, sein Onkel, eine Einladung an Babur, den Herrscher von Kabul, in Delhi einzumarschieren. [PARAGRAPH:1]Die erste Schlacht von Panipat (April 1526) wurde zwischen den Streitkrften von Babur und dem Sultanat Delhi ausgetragen. Ibrahim Lodi wurde auf dem Schlachtfeld gettet. Durch berlegene Feldherrschaft, groe Erfahrung in der Kriegsfhrung, effektive Strategie und angemessenen Einsatz der Artillerie gewann Babur die erste Schlacht von Panipat und besetzte anschlieend Agra und Delhi. Die neue Mogul-Dynastie sollte Indien weitere 300 Jahre lang regieren.

TEXT.English: [H1]Qutb-ud-din Aibak[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan of Delhi[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 1206 - 1210[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Qutb-ud-din Aibak (lit. "Axis of the Faith") was a Turkic king of Northwest India who ruled from his capital in Delhi where he built the Qutb Minar and the Quwwat al-Islam mosque. He was of Turkic descent from central Asia, the first Sultan of Delhi and founder of the Slave dynasty (also known as the Ghulam dynasty) of India. [PARAGRAPH:1]Qutbuddin was born somewhere in the area of what is today known as Afghanistan. While still a child he was captured and sold as a slave. He received good education in many subjects, was fluent and Persian and Arabic. He also received training in archery and horsemanship. When his master died, he was sold to a slave merchant and then finally purchased by the great General Shahabuddin Muhammad Ghori, then governor of Ghazni. [PARAGRAPH:1]Starting with his native Ghori, Shahabuddin Ghori proved to be a distinguished personality of the history and managed to establish control over most of present-day Afghanistan, Pakistan and northern India. Under his command, Qutbuddin conquered Delhi in 1193 after the victory in the Battles of Tarain. As a governor of northern India, Aibak established the first verifiable Muslim administration through collection of state taxes and distribution of land and revenues to the nobles under his charge, as well as governance based on a mixture of locally elected representation and nominated administrators. [PARAGRAPH:1]Upon Sultan Ghori's death in 1206, Qutbuddin, after a brief power struggle, succeeded in establishing himself as ruler of the kingdom in Afghanistan, Pakistan, and northern India; Shahabuddin Muhammad's Central Asian possessions had been captured by none other than the Mongol warlord, Genghis Khan. [PARAGRAPH:1]Rather than attacking other kingdoms, Qutbuddin concentrated on the development of the existing empire. Therefore, although his formal tenure as ruler was only four years, he managed to consolidate the administrative system that was established by his predecessor and master Shahabuddin Ghori. Qutbuddin initially ruled his empire from Lahore but later moved the capital to Delhi; he is therefore considered the first Muslim ruler of South Asia. [PARAGRAPH:1]Qutbuddin ruled for only four years, from 1206 to 1210 AD. He died in an accident while playing polo in Lahore.

TEXT.German: [H1]Qutb-ud-din Aibak[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan von Delhi[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Regierungszeit:[\BOLD] 1206 - 1210[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund :[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Qutb-ud-din Aibak (wrtlich "Achse des Glaubens") war ein trkischer Knig von Nordwestindien, der von seiner Hauptstadt Delhi aus regierte, wo er den Qutb Minar und den Quwwat errichtete al-Islam-Moschee. Er war trkischer Abstammung aus Zentralasien, der erste Sultan von Delhi und Grnder der Sklavendynastie (auch bekannt als Ghulam-Dynastie) Indiens. [PARAGRAPH:1]Qutbuddin wurde irgendwo in der Gegend geboren, die heute als Afghanistan bekannt ist. Noch als Kind wurde er gefangen genommen und als Sklave verkauft. Er erhielt in vielen Fchern eine gute Ausbildung, sprach flieend Persisch und Arabisch. Auerdem erhielt er eine Ausbildung im Bogenschieen und Reiten. Als sein Herr starb, wurde er an einen Sklavenhndler verkauft und schlielich vom groen General Shahabuddin Muhammad Ghori, dem damaligen Gouverneur von Ghazni, gekauft. [PARAGRAPH:1]Beginnend mit seinem Heimatland Ghori erwies sich Shahabuddin Ghori als herausragende Persnlichkeit der Geschichte und schaffte es, die Kontrolle ber den grten Teil des heutigen Afghanistan, Pakistan und Nordindien zu erlangen. Unter seinem Kommando eroberte Qutbuddin 1193 Delhi nach dem Sieg in den Schlachten von Tarain. Als Gouverneur Nordindiens etablierte Aibak die erste nachweisbare muslimische Verwaltung durch die Erhebung staatlicher Steuern und die Verteilung von Land und Einnahmen an die ihm unterstellten Adligen sowie eine Regierungsfhrung, die auf einer Mischung aus lokal gewhlten Vertretern und ernannten Administratoren basierte. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nach dem Tod von Sultan Ghori im Jahr 1206 gelang es Qutbuddin nach einem kurzen Machtkampf, sich als Herrscher des Knigreichs in Afghanistan, Pakistan und Nordindien zu etablieren; Die zentralasiatischen Besitztmer von Shahabuddin Muhammad waren von keinem Geringeren als dem mongolischen Kriegsherrn Dschingis Khan erobert worden. [PARAGRAPH:1]Anstatt andere Knigreiche anzugreifen, konzentrierte sich Qutbuddin auf die Entwicklung des bestehenden Reiches. Daher gelang es ihm, obwohl seine formelle Amtszeit als Herrscher nur vier Jahre dauerte, das von seinem Vorgnger und Meister Shahabuddin Ghori eingerichtete Verwaltungssystem zu konsolidieren. Qutbuddin regierte sein Reich zunchst von Lahore aus, verlegte die Hauptstadt jedoch spter nach Delhi. er gilt daher als der erste muslimische Herrscher Sdasiens. [PARAGRAPH:1]Qutbuddin regierte nur vier Jahre lang, von 1206 bis 1210 n. Chr. Er starb bei einem Unfall beim Polospielen in Lahore.

When his master died, he was sold to a slave merchant and then finally purchased by the great General Shahabuddin Muhammad Ghori, then governor of Ghazni. [PARAGRAPH:1]Starting with his native Ghori, Shahabuddin Ghori proved to be a distinguished personality of the history and managed to establish control over most of present-day Afghanistan, Pakistan and northern India. Under his command, Qutbuddin conquered Delhi in 1193 after the victory in the Battles of Tarain. As a governor of northern India, Aibak established the first verifiable Muslim administration through collection of state taxes and distribution of land and revenues to the nobles under his charge, as well as governance based on a mixture of locally elected representation and nominated administrators. [PARAGRAPH:1]Upon Sultan Ghori's death in 1206, Qutbuddin, after a brief power struggle, succeeded in establishing himself as ruler of the kingdom in Afghanistan, Pakistan, and northern India; Shahabuddin Muhammad's Central Asian possessions had been captured by none other than the Mongol warlord, Genghis Khan. [PARAGRAPH:1]Rather than attacking other kingdoms, Qutbuddin concentrated on the development of the existing empire. Therefore, although his formal tenure as ruler was only four years, he managed to consolidate the administrative system that was established by his predecessor and master Shahabuddin Ghori. Qutbuddin initially ruled his empire from Lahore but later moved the capital to Delhi; he is therefore considered the first Muslim ruler of South Asia. [PARAGRAPH:1]Qutbuddin ruled for only four years, from 1206 to 1210 AD. He died in an accident while playing polo in Lahore.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Ghaznavids were a Turko-Persian Muslim dynasty of Turkic mamluk origin which existed from 975 to 1187 and ruled much of Persia, Transoxiana, and the northern parts of the Indian subcontinent. The Ghaznavid state was centered in Ghazni, a city in present Afghanistan. Due to the political and cultural influence of their predecessors - that of the Persian Samanid Empire - the originally Turkic Ghaznavids became thoroughly Persianized.[PARAGRAPH:1]The dynasty was founded by Sebuktigin upon his succession to rule of territories centered around the city of Ghazni from his father-in-law, Alp Tigin, a break-away ex-general of the Samanid sultans. Sebuktigin's son, Sultan Mahmud, expanded the empire in the region that stretched from the Oxus river to the Indus Valley and the Indian Ocean. The Indian kingdoms of Nagarkot, Thanesar, Kannauj, Gwalior, and Ujjain were all conquered and left in the hands of Hindu, Jain and Buddhist kings as vassal states. The later invasions of Mahmud were specifically directed to temple towns as Indian temples were depositories of great wealth and the economic and ideological centers of gravity for the Hindus. Destroying them would destroy the willpower of the Hindus attacking the Empire since Mahmud never kept a permanent presence in the subcontinent.[PARAGRAPH:1]Under the reign of Mas'ud I it experienced major territorial losses. It lost its western territories to the Seljuks in the Battle of Dandanaqan resulting in a restriction of its holdings to what is now Afghanistan, as well as Balochistan and the Punjab. In 1151, Sultan Bahram Shah lost Ghazni to Ala'uddin Hussain of Ghor and the capital was moved to Lahore until its subsequent capture by the Ghorids in 1186.

TEXT.English: [H1]Shams-uddin Muhammad Kurt I[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Malik of the Kurt Dynasty[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 13th century[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Shams-uddin Muhammad was the second malik of the Kurt dynasty. He was the son of Rukn-uddin Kurt I and a Ghurid princess.[PARAGRAPH:1]Shams-uddin succeeded his father in 1245, and quickly seized Herat. He then submitted as a vassal to the Mongols, who accepted him as a local ruler. The following year he joined the Mongols under Sali Noyan in an invasion of India, and remained there for a time. During his stay in India he met the Sufi Saint Baha-ud-din Zakariya at Multan in 1247-8. Later he visited the newly crowned Mongol ruler Mngke Khan in Mongolia, who gave him much of Greater Khorasan, and possibly land as far as the Indus.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1263-4, after having subdued Sistan, he visited Hulagu Khan, and three years later his successor Abaqa Khan, whom he accompanied on his campaign against Derbent and Baku. He again visited Abaqa Khan, accompanied by Shams-uddin the Sahib Diwan, in 1276-7, but this time the formerly good opinion of Abaqa in respect to him seems to have changed to one of suspicion, which led to his death. He was poisoned in January of 1278, by means of a watermelon given to him while he was in the bath at Tabriz. Abaqa Khan even had his body buried in chains at Jam. He was then succeeded by his son Rukn-uddin Kurt II.
TEXT.French: [H1]Abu Mansur Sabuktigin[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Founder of the Ghaznavid Empire[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 942 - 997[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Abu Mansur Sabuktigin is generally regarded by historians as the founder of the Ghaznavid Empire. He was a former slave and later son-in-law of Alptigin who actually seized Ghazni in a political fallout for the throne of the Samanids.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sabuktigin grew up in the court circles of Alptigin and was conferred the titles of Amir ul-Umra ("Chief of the Nobles"), and Wakil-e Mutlak ("Representative"). He was then heavily involved in the defence of Ghaznis independence for the next 15 years as Alptigin's his general. Upon Alptigin's death in 975, both Sabuktigin and Alptigin's son Abu Ishaq went to Bokhara to mend fences with the Samanids. Mansur I of Samanid then officially conferred upon Abu Ishaq the governorship of Ghazni and acknowledged Sabuktigin as the heir. Abu Ishaq died soon after in 977 and Sabuktigin succeeded him to the governorship of Ghazni and married Alptigin's daughter.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 977 he marched against Toghan, who had opposed his succession. Toghan fled to Bust, so Sabuktigin marched upon it and captured Kandahar and its surrounding area. This prompted the Shahi prince Jayapala to launch a pre-emptive strike at Ghazni. Despite the Jayapala amassing approximately 100,000 troops for the battle, Sabuktigin was soundly victorious. The battle was fought at Laghman (near Kabul) and the Jayapala was forced to pay a large tribute. He defaulted upon this, imprisoned Sabuktigin's collectors, and assembled an army allied with forces from the kingdoms of Delhi, Ajmer, Kalinjar, and Kannauj which was defeated at the banks of the Neelum. Sabuktigin then annexed Afghanistan and Peshawar, and all land west of the Neelum.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 994 he was involved in aiding Nuh II of the Samanids against internal uprisings and defeated the rebels at Balkh and then to Nishapur, thereby earning for himself the title of Nasir ud-Din ("Hero of the Faith") and for his son Mahmud the title of Governor of Khorasan and Saif ud-Dawlah ("Sword of the State").[PARAGRAPH:1]Sabuktigin had increased upon Alptigin's domains by extending his domain north to Balkh, west to Kandahar and Khorasan, and east to the Indus River; he was eventually recognized by the Caliph in Baghdad as governor of his dominions.

TEXT.English: [H1]Mubariz al-Din Muhammad[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Founder of the Muzaffarid Dynasty[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1301 - 1363[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Mubariz al-Din Muhammad was born to a family of Arab origin which settled in Khurasan during the Islamic conquest. He was the son of Sharaf al-Din Muzaffar, a servant of the Ilkhanids, and on his father's death in 1314 Mubariz inherited his offices.[PARAGRAPH:1]He lived at the court of Ilkhanid ruler ljait until the latter's death. After ljait's death, Mubariz al-Din left for Maibud, and in 1319 he captured Yazd from Hajji Shah ibn Yusuf Shah, thus putting an end to Atabeg rule there. Some time later, the people of Sistan rebelled against the Ilkhanids, and Mubariz al-Din was ordered to subdue the province, which he did. However, the province rebelled again, and Mubariz al-Din was forced to return. He reportedly fought the rebels in 21 battles until the province was finally subdued.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the wake of declining Ilkhanate authority in central Iran following the death of Abu Sa'id, Mubariz al-Din declared independence from the Ilkhanids. In 1339 or 1340 he invaded the province of Kirman and seized it from its Mongol governor, Kutb al-Din ibn Nasir. Kutb al-Din was able to retake the province after receiving aid from the Kartid dynasty of Herat, but Mubariz al-Din permanently gained control of Kirman in late 1340. The city of Bam was besieged and conquered a few years after this.[PARAGRAPH:1]After the conquest of Kirman, Mubariz al-Din became a rival of the neighboring Injuids, who controlled Shiraz and Isfahan. The Injuid Abu Esshaq unsuccessfully besieged Yazd from 1350-1351, after which his fortunes declined rapidly. During the same year, he sent an army to Kirman, which was defeated by Mubariz al-Din. In 1353, Mubariz al-Din captured Shiraz from Abu Esshaq. Abu Esshaq managed to escape to Isfahan, but Mubariz al-Din pursued him, took the city and executed the Injuid ruler. The Muzaffarids were now the strongest power in central Iran, and Shiraz was made their capital. Mubariz al-Din was known as a cruel ruler, however, and in 1358 his son Shah Shuja blinded and imprisoned him. He died in prison in 1363.

He was then heavily involved in the defence of Ghaznis independence for the next 15 years as Alptigin's his general. Upon Alptigin's death in 975, both Sabuktigin and Alptigin's son Abu Ishaq went to Bokhara to mend fences with the Samanids. Mansur I of Samanid then officially conferred upon Abu Ishaq the governorship of Ghazni and acknowledged Sabuktigin as the heir. Abu Ishaq died soon after in 977 and Sabuktigin succeeded him to the governorship of Ghazni and married Alptigin's daughter.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 977 he marched against Toghan, who had opposed his succession. Toghan fled to Bust, so Sabuktigin marched upon it and captured Kandahar and its surrounding area. This prompted the Shahi prince Jayapala to launch a pre-emptive strike at Ghazni. Despite the Jayapala amassing approximately 100,000 troops for the battle, Sabuktigin was soundly victorious. The battle was fought at Laghman (near Kabul) and the Jayapala was forced to pay a large tribute. He defaulted upon this, imprisoned Sabuktigin's collectors, and assembled an army allied with forces from the kingdoms of Delhi, Ajmer, Kalinjar, and Kannauj which was defeated at the banks of the Neelum. Sabuktigin then annexed Afghanistan and Peshawar, and all land west of the Neelum.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 994 he was involved in aiding Nuh II of the Samanids against internal uprisings and defeated the rebels at Balkh and then to Nishapur, thereby earning for himself the title of Nasir ud-Din ("Hero of the Faith") and for his son Mahmud the title of Governor of Khorasan and Saif ud-Dawlah ("Sword of the State").[PARAGRAPH:1]Sabuktigin had increased upon Alptigin's domains by extending his domain north to Balkh, west to Kandahar and Khorasan, and east to the Indus River; he was eventually recognized by the Caliph in Baghdad as governor of his dominions.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Kara Koyunlu or Qara Qoyunlu, also called the Black Sheep Turkomans, were a Muslim Oghuz Turkic monarchy that ruled over the territory comprising present-day Azerbaijan, Georgia, Armenia, northwestern Iran, eastern Turkey, and northeastern Iraq from about 1374 to 1468. [PARAGRAPH:1]Early in their history, the Kara Koyunlu Turkomans at one point had their capital in Herat in modern-day Afghanistan. They were later vassals of the Jalairid Sultanate in Baghdad and Tabriz from about 1375, when the leader of their preeminent tribe ruled over Mosul. However, they rebelled against the Jalairids, and secured their independence from the dynasty with the conquest of Tabriz by Qara Yusuf. In 1400, Timur defeated the Kara Koyunlu, and Qara Yusuf fled to Egypt, seeking refuge with the Mamluk Sultanate. He gathered an army, and by 1406 had taken back Tabriz. In 1410, the Kara Koyunlu under Qara Yusuf captured Baghdad. The installation of a subsidiary Kara Koyunlu line there hastened the downfall of the Jalairids they had once served.[PARAGRAPH:1]When Shahrukh Mirza of the Timurids died in 1447, the Kara Koyunlu under Jahan Shah annexed portions of Iraq and the eastern coast of the Arabian Peninsula as well as Timurid-controlled western Iran. Though much territory was gained during his rule, Jahan Shah's reign was troubled by his rebellious sons and the virtually autonomous rulers of Baghdad, whom he expelled in 1464. In 1466, Jahan Shah attempted to take Diyarbakir from the Aq Qoyunlu ("White Sheep Turkomans"), however, this was a catastrophic failure resulting in Jahan Shah's death and the collapse of Kara Koyunlu control of the Middle East. By 1468, at their height under Uzun Hasan (1452-1478), The Ak Koyunlu had defeated the Kara Koyunlu and conquered Iraq, Azerbaijan, and western Iran.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Ghaznavids were a Turko-Persian Muslim dynasty of Turkic mamluk origin which existed from 975 to 1187 and ruled much of Persia, Transoxiana, and the northern parts of the Indian subcontinent. The Ghaznavid state was centered in Ghazni, a city in present Afghanistan. Due to the political and cultural influence of their predecessors - that of the Persian Samanid Empire - the originally Turkic Ghaznavids became thoroughly Persianized.[PARAGRAPH:1]The dynasty was founded by Sebuktigin upon his succession to rule of territories centered around the city of Ghazni from his father-in-law, Alp Tigin, a break-away ex-general of the Samanid sultans. Sebuktigin's son, Sultan Mahmud, expanded the empire in the region that stretched from the Oxus river to the Indus Valley and the Indian Ocean. The Indian kingdoms of Nagarkot, Thanesar, Kannauj, Gwalior, and Ujjain were all conquered and left in the hands of Hindu, Jain and Buddhist kings as vassal states. The later invasions of Mahmud were specifically directed to temple towns as Indian temples were depositories of great wealth and the economic and ideological centers of gravity for the Hindus. Destroying them would destroy the willpower of the Hindus attacking the Empire since Mahmud never kept a permanent presence in the subcontinent.[PARAGRAPH:1]Under the reign of Mas'ud I it experienced major territorial losses. It lost its western territories to the Seljuks in the Battle of Dandanaqan resulting in a restriction of its holdings to what is now Afghanistan, as well as Balochistan and the Punjab. In 1151, Sultan Bahram Shah lost Ghazni to Ala'uddin Hussain of Ghor and the capital was moved to Lahore until its subsequent capture by the Ghorids in 1186.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Muzaffarid dynasty was a Persian dynasty of Arab origin which came to power in Iran following the breakup of the Ilkhanate. At their zenith, they ruled a kingdom comprising Iranian Azerbaijan, Central Persia, and Persian Iraq. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Muzaffarids were originally from Arabia and settled in Khorasan at the beginning of Caliphal rule there. They stayed in Khorasan until the Mongol invasion of that province, at which point they fled to Yazd. Serving under the Il-Khans, they gained prominence when Sharaf al-Din Muzaffar was made governor of Maibud. He was tasked with crushing the robber-bands that were roaming around the country. Sharaf al-Din's son, Mubariz al-Din Muhammad, was brought up at the Il-Khan's court but returned to Maibud upon the death of the Il-Khan ljeit. In around 1319, he overthrew the atabeg of Yazd and was subsequently recognized as governor of the city by the central Il-Khan government. Following this he began fighting against the Neguderis, a Mongol tribal group. He managed to face this crisis with a minimum of loss.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the wake of decling Il-Khan authority in central Iran following the death of Abu Sa'id, Mubariz al-Din continued to carry out his expansionist policy. He first took Kerman, then Shiraz in 1350, and Isfahan in 1354, in the process putting to death the last of the Inju clan which had formerly held the area, Sheikh Abu Ishaq. With the destruction of Injuid authority, the Muzaffarids were the strongest power in central Iran, and Shiraz was made their capital. Mubariz al-Din was known as a cruel ruler, however, and soon afterwards in 1358, his son Shah Shoja blinded and imprisoned him. A temporary reconciliation was reached, but it failed to last and he died, again in prison, in 1363.[PARAGRAPH:1]Shah Shoja proved to be a less tyrannical figure than his father, but he was constantly fighting with his brothers, leading to a long period of instability. Despite this, his lengthy reign saw the kingdom reach the zenith of its power, eventually stretching from Balochistan to Arran. On his deathbed, Shah Shoja wrote a letter to Timur, who was then campaigning in Azerbaijan, in which he pledged his sons' loyalty to the conqueror. However, when Zain Al-Abidin succeeded his father, he quickly ignored the declaration of loyalty. Timur therefore marched into Muzaffarid lands, coming to Isfahan, where the governor gave him control of the city. But a local rebellion killed any goodwill that Timur had, resulting in a slaughter of the populace. Zain Al-Abidin attempted to flee from Shiraz but was imprisoned by his cousin Shah Mansur. When Timur took the city, the various Muzaffarid princes went to Shiraz to declare their loyalty, whereupon Timur restored them to their positions and returned to Transoxiana.[PARAGRAPH:1]Unfortunately, the Muzaffarids soon began to resume their local feuding. Timur took note of these events, and decided in 1392 that a campaign against Shah Mansur was in order. Shah Mansur gained the Sarbadar Muluk as his ally, who was sent to defend Kashan and the Muzaffarid northern front. By March 1393, Timur had advanced down to Shushtar and Dizful, installing a Sarbadar governor there. Shah Mansur fled Shiraz, but then turned around and met Timur's forces. With an army weakened by desertions, he fought bravely but was forced to retreat. Attempting to reach Shiraz, he was captured by forces of prince Shah Rukh and was decapitated. The other Muzaffarid princes then again swore alliegence to Timur. They were received honorably by the conqueror, but on May 22 in Qumisha they were executed. Only Zain al-Abidin and Sultan Shibli survived the purge; they were sent to Samarkand, and the governance of the Muzaffarid provinces was turned over to more trustworthy individuals.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Kurt dynasty, also known as the Kartids, was a Sunni Muslim dynasty of Tajik origin that ruled over a large part of Khorasan during the 13th and 14th centuries. Ruling from their capital at Herat, they were at first subordinates of Sultan Abul-Fateh Ghiyasuddin Muhammad bin Sam, Sultan of the Ghurid Empire, to whom they were related. Later they ruled as vassal princes within the Mongol Empire, accompanying the Mongols on campaigns in India and the Caucasus. Upon the fragmentation of the Ilkhanate in 1335, Mu'izz-uddin Husayn ibn Ghiyath-uddin worked to expand his principality.[PARAGRAPH:1]Four years after Mu'izz-uddin Husayn ibn Ghiyath-uddin's ascension, the Ilkhan Abu Sa'id Bahadur Khan died, after which the Ilkhanate quickly fragmented. Mu'izz-uddin Husayn, for his part, allied with Togha Temr, a claimant to the Ilkhanid throne, and paid tribute to him. Up until his death, Mu'izz-uddin Husayn's main concern was the neighboring Sarbadars, centered in Sabzavar. As the Sarbadars were the enemies of Togha Temr, they considered the Kurts a threat and then invaded. When the Kurts and Sarbadars met at the Battle of Zava on 18 July 1342, disunity within the Sarbadar army allowed the Kurts to emerge victorious. Thereafter, Mu'izz-uddin Husayn undertook several successful campaigns against the Chagatai Mongols to the northeast. During this time, he took a young Timur into his service.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1349, while Togha Temr was still alive, Mu'izz-uddin Husayn stopped paying tribute to him, and ruled as an independent Sultan. Togha Temr's murder in 1353 by the Sarbadars ended that potential threat. Sometime around 1358, however, the Chagatai amir Qazaghan invaded Khurasan and sacked Herat. As he was returning home, Qazaghan was assassinated, allowing Mu'izz-uddin Husayn to reestablish his authority. Another campaign by the Sarbadars against Mu'izz-uddin Husayn in 1362 was aborted due to their internal disunity. Shortly afterwards, the Kurt leader welcomed Shia dervishes fleeing from the Sarbadar ruler Ali-yi Mu'ayyad, who had killed their leader during the aborted campaign. In the meantime, however, relations with Timur became tense when the Kurts launched a raid into his territory. Upon Mu'izz-uddin Husayn's death in 1370, his son Ghiyas-uddin Pir 'Ali inherited most of the Kurt lands, except for Sarakhs and a portion of Quhistan, which Ghiyas-uddin's stepbrother Malik Muhammad ibn Mu'izz-uddin gained.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ghiyas-uddin Pir 'Ali, a grandson of Togha Temr through his mother Sultan Khatun, attempted to destabilize the Sarbadars by stirring up refugee dervishes within his country. 'Ali-yi Mu'ayyad countered by conspiring with Malik Muhammad. When Ghiyas-uddin Pir 'Ali attempted to remove Malik Muhammad, 'Ali-yi Mu'ayyad flanked his army and forced him to abort the campaign. The Sarbadars, however, soon suffered a period of internal strife, and Ghiyas-uddin Pir 'Ali took advantage of this by seizing the city of Nishapur around 1375 or 1376. In the meantime, both Ghiyas-uddin Pir 'Ali and Malik Muhammad had asked for the assistance of Timur: the former had sent an embassy to him, while the latter had appeared before Timur in person to request asylum, having been driven out of Sarakhs. Timur responded to Ghiyas-uddin Pir 'Ali by proposing a marriage between his niece Sevinj Qutluq Agha and the Kurt ruler's son Pir Muhammad ibn Ghiyas-uddin, which took place in Samarkand around 1376.[PARAGRAPH:1]Later, Timur invited Ghiyas-uddin Pir 'Ali to a council, so that the latter could submit to him, but when the Kurt attempted to avoid coming by claiming he had to deal with the Shias in Nishapur, Timur decided to invade. He was encouraged by many Khurasanis and the shaikhs of Jam, who had convinced many of the Kurt dignitaries to welcome Timur as the latter neared Herat. The city fell in April 1381; its fortifications were dismantled, theologians and scholars were deported to Timurid territory, a high tribute was enacted, and Ghiyas-uddin Pir 'Ali and his son were carried off to Samarkand. Ghiyas-uddin Pir 'Ali was made Timur's vassal, until he supported a rebellion in 1382 by the maliks of Herat. Ghiyas-uddin Pir 'Ali and his family were executed around 1383, and Timur's son Miran Shah destroyed the revolt. That same year, a new uprising led by a Shaikh Da'ud-i Khitatai in Isfizar was quickly put down. The remaining Kurts were murdered by Miran Shah at a banquet in 1396. The Kurts therefore came to an end, having been the victims of Timur's first Persian campaign.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Ghaznavids were a Turko-Persian Muslim dynasty of Turkic mamluk origin which existed from 975 to 1187 and ruled much of Persia, Transoxiana, and the northern parts of the Indian subcontinent. The Ghaznavid state was centered in Ghazni, a city in present Afghanistan. Due to the political and cultural influence of their predecessors - that of the Persian Samanid Empire - the originally Turkic Ghaznavids became thoroughly Persianized.[PARAGRAPH:1]The dynasty was founded by Sebuktigin upon his succession to rule of territories centered around the city of Ghazni from his father-in-law, Alp Tigin, a break-away ex-general of the Samanid sultans. Sebuktigin's son, Sultan Mahmud, expanded the empire in the region that stretched from the Oxus river to the Indus Valley and the Indian Ocean. The Indian kingdoms of Nagarkot, Thanesar, Kannauj, Gwalior, and Ujjain were all conquered and left in the hands of Hindu, Jain and Buddhist kings as vassal states. The later invasions of Mahmud were specifically directed to temple towns as Indian temples were depositories of great wealth and the economic and ideological centers of gravity for the Hindus. Destroying them would destroy the willpower of the Hindus attacking the Empire since Mahmud never kept a permanent presence in the subcontinent.[PARAGRAPH:1]Under the reign of Mas'ud I it experienced major territorial losses. It lost its western territories to the Seljuks in the Battle of Dandanaqan resulting in a restriction of its holdings to what is now Afghanistan, as well as Balochistan and the Punjab. In 1151, Sultan Bahram Shah lost Ghazni to Ala'uddin Hussain of Ghor and the capital was moved to Lahore until its subsequent capture by the Ghorids in 1186.

TEXT.English: [H1]Abu Mansur Sabuktigin[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Founder of the Ghaznavid Empire[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 942 - 997[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Abu Mansur Sabuktigin is generally regarded by historians as the founder of the Ghaznavid Empire. He was a former slave and later son-in-law of Alptigin who actually seized Ghazni in a political fallout for the throne of the Samanids.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sabuktigin grew up in the court circles of Alptigin and was conferred the titles of Amir ul-Umra ("Chief of the Nobles"), and Wakil-e Mutlak ("Representative"). He was then heavily involved in the defence of Ghaznis independence for the next 15 years as Alptigin's his general. Upon Alptigin's death in 975, both Sabuktigin and Alptigin's son Abu Ishaq went to Bokhara to mend fences with the Samanids. Mansur I of Samanid then officially conferred upon Abu Ishaq the governorship of Ghazni and acknowledged Sabuktigin as the heir. Abu Ishaq died soon after in 977 and Sabuktigin succeeded him to the governorship of Ghazni and married Alptigin's daughter.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 977 he marched against Toghan, who had opposed his succession. Toghan fled to Bust, so Sabuktigin marched upon it and captured Kandahar and its surrounding area. This prompted the Shahi prince Jayapala to launch a pre-emptive strike at Ghazni. Despite the Jayapala amassing approximately 100,000 troops for the battle, Sabuktigin was soundly victorious. The battle was fought at Laghman (near Kabul) and the Jayapala was forced to pay a large tribute. He defaulted upon this, imprisoned Sabuktigin's collectors, and assembled an army allied with forces from the kingdoms of Delhi, Ajmer, Kalinjar, and Kannauj which was defeated at the banks of the Neelum. Sabuktigin then annexed Afghanistan and Peshawar, and all land west of the Neelum.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 994 he was involved in aiding Nuh II of the Samanids against internal uprisings and defeated the rebels at Balkh and then to Nishapur, thereby earning for himself the title of Nasir ud-Din ("Hero of the Faith") and for his son Mahmud the title of Governor of Khorasan and Saif ud-Dawlah ("Sword of the State").[PARAGRAPH:1]Sabuktigin had increased upon Alptigin's domains by extending his domain north to Balkh, west to Kandahar and Khorasan, and east to the Indus River; he was eventually recognized by the Caliph in Baghdad as governor of his dominions.

TEXT.German: [H1]Abu Mansur Sabuktigin[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Grnder des Ghaznawiden-Reiches[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 942 - 997[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund: [\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Abu Mansur Sabuktigin wird von Historikern allgemein als Grnder des Ghaznawiden-Reiches angesehen. Er war ein ehemaliger Sklave und spterer Schwiegersohn von Alptigin, der tatschlich Ghazni in einem politischen Streit um den Thron der Samaniden eroberte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sabuktigin wuchs in den Hofkreisen von Alptigin auf und erhielt den Titel Amir ul-Umra ("Oberhaupt der Adligen") und Wakil-e Mutlak ("Vertreter"). Anschlieend war er fr die nchsten 15 Jahre als sein General Alptigins mageblich an der Verteidigung der Unabhngigkeit Ghaznis beteiligt. Nach Alptigins Tod im Jahr 975 gingen sowohl Sabuktigin als auch Alptigins Sohn Abu Ishaq nach Buchara, um mit den Samaniden Zune auszubessern. Mansur I. von Samanid bertrug daraufhin offiziell Abu Ishaq die Gouverneurswrde von Ghazni und erkannte Sabuktigin als Erben an. Abu Ishaq starb kurz darauf im Jahr 977 und Sabuktigin folgte ihm als Gouverneur von Ghazni nach und heiratete Alptigins Tochter.[PARAGRAPH:1]Im Jahr 977 marschierte er gegen Toghan, der sich seiner Nachfolge widersetzt hatte. Toghan floh nach Bust, also marschierte Sabuktigin dorthin und eroberte Kandahar und seine Umgebung. Dies veranlasste den Shahi-Prinzen Jayapala, einen Prventivschlag gegen Ghazni zu starten. Obwohl Jayapala etwa 100.000 Soldaten fr die Schlacht zusammenzog, war Sabuktigin ein klarer Sieger. Die Schlacht wurde bei Laghman (in der Nhe von Kabul) ausgetragen und der Jayapala musste einen hohen Tribut zahlen. Er versumte dies, sperrte Sabuktigins Sammler ein und stellte eine Armee zusammen, die mit Truppen aus den Knigreichen Delhi, Ajmer, Kalinjar und Kannauj verbndet war, die an den Ufern des Neelum besiegt wurde. Sabuktigin annektierte dann Afghanistan und Peshawar sowie das gesamte Land westlich des Neelum.[PARAGRAPH:1]Im Jahr 994 war er an der Untersttzung von Nuh II. der Samaniden gegen interne Aufstnde beteiligt und besiegte die Rebellen bei Balkh und dann bei Nishapur, wodurch er seinen Lebensunterhalt verdiente den Titel Nasir ud-Din ("Held des Glaubens") und fr seinen Sohn Mahmud den Titel Gouverneur von Khorasan und Saif ud-Dawlah ("Schwert des Staates").[PARAGRAPH:1]Sabuktigin war gegenber Alptigin aufgestiegen Gebiete, indem er sein Herrschaftsgebiet nrdlich bis Balkh, westlich bis Kandahar und Khorasan und stlich bis zum Indus ausdehnte; Er wurde schlielich vom Kalifen in Bagdad als Gouverneur seines Herrschaftsbereichs anerkannt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Ak Koyunlu or Aq Qoyunlu, also called the White Sheep Turkomans, was an Oghuz Turkic tribal federation, that ruled parts of present-day Eastern Turkey, Armenia, Azerbaijan, northern Iraq, and Iran from 1378 to 1508.[PARAGRAPH:1]According to Byzantine chronicles, the Ak Koyunlu were present in eastern Anatolia since at least 1340, and most of their leaders, including the dynasty's founder, Uzun Hassan, married Byzantine princesses. Ak Koyunlu Turkomans first acquired land in 1402, when Tamerlane granted them all of Diyarbakir, in present-day Turkey. For a long time, the Ak Koyunlu were unable to expand their territory, as the rival Kara Koyunlu kept them at bay. However, this changed with the rule of Uzun Hassan who defeated the Black Sheep Turkoman leader, Jahan Shah, in 1467.[PARAGRAPH:1]After the defeat of a Timurid leader, Abu Sai'd, Uzun Hassan was able to take Baghdad, along with territories around the Persian Gulf. He expanded into Iran as far east as Khorasan. However, around this time, the Ottoman Empire sought to expand eastwards, a serious threat that forced the Ak Koyunlu into an alliance with the Qaramanids of central Anatolia. As early as 1464, Uzun Hassan had requested military aid from one of the Ottoman Empire's strongest enemies, Venice, however, despite Venetian promises, this aid never arrived, and as a result, Uzun Hassan was defeated by the Ottomans at Tercan in 1473, though this did not destroy the Ak Koyunlus. When Uzun Hassan died early in 1478, he was succeeded by his son Khalil Mirza (Sultan Khalil), but he was defeated by a confederation under his younger brother Ya'qub at the Battle of Khoy in July.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ya'qub, who reigned from 1478 to 1490, sustained the dynasty for a while longer. However, during the first four years of his reign there were seven pretenders to the throne that had to be put down. Following Ya'qub's death civl war again erupted, the Ak Koyunlus destroyed themselves from within, and they ceased to be a threat to their neighbours.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Safavids, who were Shi'ites, began to undermine the allegiance of many Ak Koyunlu, particularly Sunnis. The Safavids and the Ak Koyunlu met in battle at Nakhichevan in 1501, and the Safavid leader Ismail I forced the Ak Koyunlu to withdraw. In his retreat from the Safavids, the Ak Koyunlu leader Alwand destroyed an autonomous Ak Koyunlu state in Mardin. The last Ak Koyunlu leader, Murad, brother of Alwand, was also defeated by the same Safavid leader. Though Murad briefly established himself in Baghdad in 1508, he soon withdrew back to Diyar Bakr, signalling the end of the Ak Koyunlu rule.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Ak Koyunlu oder Aq Qoyunlu, auch die Turkmenen der Weien Hammeln genannt, waren ein trkischer Stammesverband der Oghusen, der von 1378 bis 1508 Teile der heutigen Osttrkei, Armenien, Aserbaidschan, den Nordirak und den Iran regierte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Byzantinischen Chroniken zufolge lebten die Ak Koyunlu seit mindestens 1340 in Ostanatolien, und die meisten ihrer Anfhrer, darunter der Grnder der Dynastie, Uzun Hassan, heirateten byzantinische Prinzessinnen. Ak-Koyunlu-Turkmenen erwarben erstmals 1402 Land, als Timur ihnen ganz Diyarbakir in der heutigen Trkei bertrug. Die Ak Koyunlu konnten ihr Territorium lange Zeit nicht erweitern, da der Rivale Kara Koyunlu sie in Schach hielt. Dies nderte sich jedoch mit der Herrschaft von Uzun Hassan, der 1467 den turkmenischen Anfhrer der Schwarzen Hammel, Jahan Shah, besiegte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nach der Niederlage eines timuridischen Anfhrers, Abu Sai'd, konnte Uzun Hassan Bagdad einnehmen. zusammen mit Gebieten rund um den Persischen Golf. Er expandierte in den Iran bis nach Khorasan. Ungefhr zu dieser Zeit versuchte das Osmanische Reich jedoch, sich nach Osten auszudehnen, eine ernsthafte Bedrohung, die die Ak Koyunlu zu einem Bndnis mit den Qaramaniden Zentralanatoliens zwang. Bereits 1464 hatte Uzun Hassan einen der strksten Feinde des Osmanischen Reiches, Venedig, um militrische Hilfe gebeten. Doch trotz venezianischer Versprechungen kam diese Hilfe nie an und in der Folge wurde Uzun Hassan 1473 bei Tercan von den Osmanen besiegt. obwohl dies die Ak Koyunlus nicht zerstrte. Als Uzun Hassan Anfang 1478 starb, wurde sein Sohn Khalil Mirza (Sultan Khalil) sein Nachfolger, doch er wurde von einer Konfderation unter seinem jngeren Bruder Ya'qub in der Schlacht von Khoy im Juli besiegt.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ya' Qub, der von 1478 bis 1490 regierte, hielt die Dynastie noch eine Weile aufrecht. Allerdings gab es in den ersten vier Jahren seiner Herrschaft sieben Thronprtendenten, die niedergeschlagen werden mussten. Nach Ya'qubs Tod brach erneut ein Brgerkrieg aus, die Ak Koyunlus zerstrten sich von innen heraus und stellten keine Bedrohung mehr fr ihre Nachbarn dar.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Safawiden, die Schiiten waren, begannen, die Treue vieler zu untergraben Ak Koyunlu, insbesondere Sunniten. Die Safawiden und die Ak Koyunlu trafen 1501 in der Schlacht bei Nachitschewan aufeinander, und der Safawidenfhrer Ismail I. zwang die Ak Koyunlu zum Rckzug. Auf seinem Rckzug vor den Safaviden zerstrte der Anfhrer der Ak-Koyunlu, Alwand, einen autonomen Staat der Ak-Koyunlu in Mardin. Der letzte Ak-Koyunlu-Anfhrer, Murad, Bruder von Alwand, wurde ebenfalls von demselben Safawiden-Anfhrer besiegt. Obwohl Murad sich 1508 kurzzeitig in Bagdad niederlie, zog er sich bald nach Diyar Bakr zurck, was das Ende der Ak-Koyunlu-Herrschaft bedeutete.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]The Ak Koyunlu or Aq Qoyunlu, also called the White Sheep Turkomans, was an Oghuz Turkic tribal federation, that ruled parts of present-day Eastern Turkey, Armenia, Azerbaijan, northern Iraq, and Iran from 1378 to 1508.[PARAGRAPH:1]According to Byzantine chronicles, the Ak Koyunlu were present in eastern Anatolia since at least 1340, and most of their leaders, including the dynasty's founder, Uzun Hassan, married Byzantine princesses. Ak Koyunlu Turkomans first acquired land in 1402, when Tamerlane granted them all of Diyarbakir, in present-day Turkey. For a long time, the Ak Koyunlu were unable to expand their territory, as the rival Kara Koyunlu kept them at bay. However, this changed with the rule of Uzun Hassan who defeated the Black Sheep Turkoman leader, Jahan Shah, in 1467.[PARAGRAPH:1]After the defeat of a Timurid leader, Abu Sai'd, Uzun Hassan was able to take Baghdad, along with territories around the Persian Gulf. He expanded into Iran as far east as Khorasan. However, around this time, the Ottoman Empire sought to expand eastwards, a serious threat that forced the Ak Koyunlu into an alliance with the Qaramanids of central Anatolia. As early as 1464, Uzun Hassan had requested military aid from one of the Ottoman Empire's strongest enemies, Venice, however, despite Venetian promises, this aid never arrived, and as a result, Uzun Hassan was defeated by the Ottomans at Tercan in 1473, though this did not destroy the Ak Koyunlus. When Uzun Hassan died early in 1478, he was succeeded by his son Khalil Mirza (Sultan Khalil), but he was defeated by a confederation under his younger brother Ya'qub at the Battle of Khoy in July.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ya'qub, who reigned from 1478 to 1490, sustained the dynasty for a while longer. However, during the first four years of his reign there were seven pretenders to the throne that had to be put down. Following Ya'qub's death civl war again erupted, the Ak Koyunlus destroyed themselves from within, and they ceased to be a threat to their neighbours.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Safavids, who were Shi'ites, began to undermine the allegiance of many Ak Koyunlu, particularly Sunnis. The Safavids and the Ak Koyunlu met in battle at Nakhichevan in 1501, and the Safavid leader Ismail I forced the Ak Koyunlu to withdraw. In his retreat from the Safavids, the Ak Koyunlu leader Alwand destroyed an autonomous Ak Koyunlu state in Mardin. The last Ak Koyunlu leader, Murad, brother of Alwand, was also defeated by the same Safavid leader. Though Murad briefly established himself in Baghdad in 1508, he soon withdrew back to Diyar Bakr, signalling the end of the Ak Koyunlu rule.

TEXT.English: [H1]Qara Iskander[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ruler of the Black Sheep Turkmen[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 1420 - 1436[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]He was the third son of Qara Yusuf, and a full brother of Ispend. He was appointed to be a wali of Kirkuk, and his first recorded appearance was in 1416, when he defeated Qara Osman during a siege of Erzincan.[PARAGRAPH:1]Qara Yusuf's death in 1420 left his sons Ispend bin Yusuf, Iskander, Jahan Shah, and Abu Sa'id fighting over the succession. The Sa'dlu tribe, one of the main sub-tribes of the Kara Koyunlu, declared Ispend as the their new chief. Abu Sa'id had to flee and Jahan Shah went to Baghdad. Iskander was supported by his brother Shah Muhammad, who was governing Baghdad at that time. Iskandar was crowned on 2 July 1421, and soon found himself fighting the Ak Koyunlu who were invading from the west, whom he subsequently defeated. The Timurid Shah Rukh took advantage of the divided state of the Kara Koyunlu and invaded their land, battling the forces of Iskander and Ispend at Yakhsi and eking out a victory after a ruse. He then briefly occupied Azerbaijan and Armenia before withdrawing once more to Khorasan, after which Ispend quickly re-occupied Nakhchivan and Tabriz. However, Iskander followed and fought with him, taking the city and establishing himself as sole ruler of the Kara Koyunlu.[PARAGRAPH:1]He quickly made punitive expeditions against local rulers, firstly defeating and killing Kurdish emir Malik Muhammad. In 1425 the brothers of Shirvanshah Khalilullah I revolted, and Qara Iskander used this as an opportunity to lay waste to and raid the region. Later he made another punitive expedition on Khwaja Yusuf, a governor of Soltaniyeh appointed by Shahrukh in 1428. In 1431 Qara Iskander marched on his rebellious brother Abu Sa'id and killed him. After years of local turmoil and further conflict with the Timurids, in 1436 Shah Rukh once again installed a Timurid governor in Tabriz, this time Qara Iskander's brother Jahan Shah. Iskander marched on Tabriz but was defeated by Jahan Shah at Sufiyan, having been betrayed by some of his emirs. He then fled and took refuge in the castle of Alinja. Jahan Shah besieged the castle, and during the siege Iskander was murdered by his own son. Jahan Shah was coronated in 1438.
TEXT.French: [H1]Uzun Hassan[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan of the White Sheep Turkmen[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c. 1423 - January 6, 1478[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Kara Yuluk Osman, Uzun Hassan's great-grandfather, was appointed by Timur as a governor of Diyarbakir (in modern-day Turkey), with the cities of Erzincan, Mardin, Roha (or Urfa), and Sivas. Uzun Hassan was able to expand this territory once he defeated Jahan Shah, prince of the rival Kara Koyunlu, or Black Sheep Turkmen federation, in 1467.[PARAGRAPH:1]Convinced by his Venetian allies, Uzun Hassan then attacked the Ottoman Empire, meeting them in battle near Erzincan in 1471 and at Tercan in 1473. Hassan successful at first, but there were no simultaneous attack by any of the western powers. He was defeated by Mehmed II at the battle of Otluk Beli in the late summer of 1473.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Timurids, were a Persianate Central Asian Sunni Muslim dynasty of originally Turko-Mongol descent whose empire included the whole of Central Asia, Iran, modern Afghanistan, as well as large parts of Pakistan, India, Mesopotamia, Anatolia and the Caucasus. It was founded by the militant conqueror Tamerlane in the 14th century.[PARAGRAPH:1]Tamerlane conquered large parts of Transoxiana and Khorasan from 1363 onwards with various alliances, and was recognized as ruler over them in 1370. Acting officially in the name of the Mongolian Chagatai ulus, he subjugated Transoxania and Khwarazm in the years that followed and began a campaign westwards in 1380. By 1389 he had removed the Kartids from Herat and advanced into mainland Persia from 1382. In 1394/95 he triumphed over the Golden Horde and enforced his sovereignty in the Caucasus, in 1398 subjugated Multan and Dipalpur in modern day Pakistan and in modern day India left Delhi in such ruin that it is said for two months "not a bird moved wing in the city". In 1400/01 conquered Aleppo, Damascus and eastern Anatolia, in 1401 destroyed Baghdad and in 1402 triumphed over the Ottomans at Ankara. An estimated 17 million people may have died from his conquests. Due to the fact that the Persian cities were desolated by previous wars, the seat of Persian culture was now in Samarkand and Herat. These cities became the center of the Timurid renaissance.[PARAGRAPH:1]After the death of Tamerlane, his empire broke into two halves and suffered from constant internal fighting between various members of the dynasty. In 1501-1510, most of the former empire was overrun by the Uzbeks. After losing Farghana, the Timurid prince Babur invaded India and founded the Mogul Empire, which ruled most of the Indian subcontinent until the early 18th century.

TEXT.English: [H1]Tamerlane[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Amir of the Timurid Empire[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 8 April 1336 - 18 February 1405[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Tamerlane, known as Timur-e Lang (Timur the Lame) in Turkish, was a fourteenth-century conqueror of Western, South and Central Asia, founder of the Timurid Empire and Timurid dynasty (13701405) in Central Asia, and great great grandfather of Babur, the founder of the Mogul Dynasty, which survived until 1857 as the Mogul Empire in India.[PARAGRAPH:1]Born into the Turco-Mongol Barlas tribe who ruled in Central Asia, Tamerlane was in his lifetime a controversial figure, and remains so today. He sought to restore the Mongol Empire, yet his heaviest blow was against the Muslim Tatar Golden Horde. He was more at home in an urban environment than on the steppe. He styled himself a ghazi yet some Muslim states, for example the Ottoman Empire, were severely affected by his wars. A great patron of the arts, his campaigns also caused vast destruction. Tamerlane told the qadis of Aleppo, during the sack of that newly conquered city, "I am not a man of blood; and God is my witness that in all my wars I have never been the aggressor, and that my enemies have always been the authors of their own calamity."[PARAGRAPH:1]Tamerlane's military talents were unique. Urheber ihres eigenen Unglcks."[PARAGRAPH:1]Timurs militrische Talente waren einzigartig. TEXT.English: [TAB]The Mogul Empire was an Indian-Islamic imperial power that ruled a large portion of the Indian subcontinent which began in 1526, invaded and ruled most of South Asia by the late 17th and early 18th centuries by forming alliance with Indian Maharaja, and ended in the mid-19th century. The Mogul Emperors were descendants of the Timurids, and at the height of their power around 1700, they controlled most of the Indian Subcontinent. The Mogul Empire extended from Bengal in the east to Balochistan in the west, from Kashmir in the north to the Kaveri basin in the south. Its population at that time has been estimated as between 110 and 130 million, over a territory of over 4 million sq.km (1.5 million square miles).[PARAGRAPH:1]The "classic period" of the Empire started in 1556 with the accession of Jalaluddin Mohammad Akbar, better known as Akbar the Great. It ended with the death of Emperor Aurangzeb in 1707, although the Empire continued for another 150 years. During this period, the Empire was marked by a highly centralized administration connecting the different regions. All the significant monuments of the Moguls, their most visible legacy, date to this period which was characterised by the expansion of Persian cultural influence in the Indian subcontinent, with brilliant literary, artistic and architectural results.[PARAGRAPH:1]Following 1725 the empire declined rapidly, weakened by wars of succession, agrarian crises fueling local revolts, the growth of religious intolerance, the rise of the Maratha, Durrani, and Sikh empires and finally British colonialism. The last king, Bahadur Zafar Shah II, whose rule was restricted to the city of Delhi, was imprisoned and exiled by the British after the Indian Rebellion of 1857.[PARAGRAPH:1]The name Mogul is derived from the original homelands of the Timurids, the Central Asian steppes once conquered by Genghis Khan and hence known as Moghulistan, "Land of Mongols". Although early Moguls spoke the Chagatai language and maintained Turko-Mongol practices, they were essentially Persianized. They transferred the Persian literature and culture to India, thus forming the base for the Indo-Persian culture.

Jahrhundert den grten Teil Sdasiens eroberte und beherrschte, indem sie ein Bndnis mit dem indischen Maharadscha schloss endete Mitte des 19. Jahrhunderts. Die Mogulkaiser waren Nachkommen der Timuriden und kontrollierten auf dem Hhepunkt ihrer Macht um 1700 den grten Teil des indischen Subkontinents - von Bengalen im Osten bis Belutschistan im Westen, Kaschmir im Norden bis zum Kaveri-Becken im Sden . Die damalige Bevlkerung wurde auf 110 bis 130 Millionen geschtzt, auf einem Gebiet von ber 4 Millionen Quadratkilometern (1,5 Millionen Quadratmeilen).[PARAGRAPH:1]Die "klassische Periode" des Imperiums begann im Jahr 1556 mit der Thronbesteigung von Jalaluddin Mohammad Akbar, besser bekannt als Akbar der Groe. Es endete mit dem Tod von Kaiser Aurangzeb im Jahr 1707, obwohl das Reich noch weitere 150 Jahre bestand. In dieser Zeit war das Reich durch eine stark zentralisierte Verwaltung gekennzeichnet, die die verschiedenen Regionen verband. Alle bedeutenden Denkmler der Moguln, ihr sichtbarstes Erbe, stammen aus dieser Zeit, die durch die Ausweitung des persischen kulturellen Einflusses auf dem indischen Subkontinent gekennzeichnet war, mit brillanten literarischen, knstlerischen und architektonischen Ergebnissen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nach 1725 wurde das Reich gegrndet verfiel rapide, geschwcht durch Erbfolgekriege, Agrarkrisen, die lokale Aufstnde anheizten, das Anwachsen religiser Intoleranz, den Aufstieg der Maratha-, Durrani- und Sikh-Reiche und schlielich den britischen Kolonialismus. Der letzte Knig, Bahadur Zafar Shah II., dessen Herrschaft auf die Stadt Delhi beschrnkt war, wurde nach dem indischen Aufstand von 1857 von den Briten inhaftiert und verbannt.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der Name Mughal leitet sich von den ursprnglichen Heimatlndern der Timuriden ab , die zentralasiatischen Steppen, die einst von Dschingis Khan erobert wurden und daher als Moghulistan, "Land der Mongolen", bekannt sind. Obwohl die frhen Moguln die Chagatai-Sprache sprachen und trkisch-mongolische Praktiken beibehielten, wurden sie im Wesentlichen persianisiert. Sie bertrugen die persische Literatur und Kultur nach Indien und bildeten so die Grundlage fr die indo-persische Kultur.

TEXT.English: [H1]Akbar the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Mogul Emperor of India[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 23 November 1542 - 27 October 1605[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Jalaluddin Muhammad Akbar was of Timurid descent; the son of Humayun, and the grandson of the Zaheeruudin Muhammad Babur, the legendary ruler who founded the Mogul dynasty in India. At the end of his reign in 1605 the Mogul empire covered most of the northern and central India and was one of the most powerful empires of the age. [PARAGRAPH:1]Akbar, widely considered as one of the greatest and the most influential personalities of the world history, was thirteen years old when he ascended the Imperial Mogul throne in Delhi, following the death of his father Naseeruddin Muahmmad Humayun. During his reign, he eliminated military threats from the powerful Pashtun descendants of Sher Shah Suri, and at the Second Battle of Panipat he defeated the newly self-declared Hindu king Hemu. It took him nearly two more decades to consolidate his power and bring parts of northern and central India into his realm. The emperor solidified his rule by pursuing diplomacy with the powerful Rajput caste, and by admitting Rajput princesses in his harem. [PARAGRAPH:1]Akbar's reign significantly influenced art and culture in the region. Akbar took a great interest in painting, and had the walls of his palaces adorned with murals. Besides encouraging the development of the Mogul school, he also patronised the European style of painting. He was fond of literature, and had several Sanskrit works translated into Persian, apart from getting many Persian works illustrated by painters from his court. Akbar began a series of religious debates where Muslim scholars would debate religious matters with Sikhs, Hindus, Carvaka atheists, Jews, and Portuguese Roman Catholic Jesuits. He had an intolerant attitude towards Hindus and the other religions during the early years of his reign, but he exercised great tolerance after he began marriage alliances with Rajput princesses. He founded a religious cult, the Din-i-Ilahi (Divine Faith), but it amounted only to a form of personality cult for Akbar, and quickly dissolved after his death.

Er liebte Literatur und lie mehrere Sanskrit-Werke ins Persische bersetzen, auerdem lie er viele persische Werke von Malern seines Hofes illustrieren. In den ersten Jahren seiner Herrschaft hatte er eine intolerante Haltung gegenber Hindus und anderen Religionen, doch nachdem er Ehebndnisse mit Rajput-Prinzessinnen geschlossen hatte, zeigte er groe Toleranz. Er grndete einen religisen Kult, den Din-i-Ilahi (Gttlicher Glaube), der jedoch fr Akbar nur eine Form des Personenkults darstellte und sich nach seinem Tod schnell auflste.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Akbar the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Mughal Emperor of India[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 23 November 1542 - 27 October 1605[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Jalaluddin Muhammad Akbar was of Timurid descent; the son of Humayun, and the grandson of the Zaheeruudin Muhammad Babur, the legendary ruler who founded the Mughal dynasty in India. At the end of his reign in 1605 the Mughal empire covered most of the northern and central India and was one of the most powerful empires of the age. [PARAGRAPH:1]Akbar, widely considered as one of the greatest and the most influential personalities of the world history, was thirteen years old when he ascended the Imperial Mughal throne in Delhi, following the death of his father Naseeruddin Muahmmad Humayun. During his reign, he eliminated military threats from the powerful Pashtun descendants of Sher Shah Suri, and at the Second Battle of Panipat he defeated the newly self-declared Hindu king Hemu. It took him nearly two more decades to consolidate his power and bring parts of northern and central India into his realm. The emperor solidified his rule by pursuing diplomacy with the powerful Rajput caste, and by admitting Rajput princesses in his harem. [PARAGRAPH:1]Akbar's reign significantly influenced art and culture in the region. Akbar took a great interest in painting, and had the walls of his palaces adorned with murals. Besides encouraging the development of the Mughal school, he also patronised the European style of painting. He was fond of literature, and had several Sanskrit works translated into Persian, apart from getting many Persian works illustrated by painters from his court. Akbar began a series of religious debates where Muslim scholars would debate religious matters with Sikhs, Hindus, Carvaka atheists, Jews, and Portuguese Roman Catholic Jesuits. He had an intolerant attitude towards Hindus and the other religions during the early years of his reign, but he exercised great tolerance after he began marriage alliances with Rajput princesses. He founded a religious cult, the Din-i-Ilahi (Divine Faith), but it amounted only to a form of personality cult for Akbar, and quickly dissolved after his death.

TEXT.English: [H1]Afonso de Albuquerque[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Governor of Portuguese India, Viceroy and Duke of Goa[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1453 - December 16, 1515[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Afonso de Albuquerque was a Portuguese fidalgo, or nobleman, an admiral whose military and administrative activities as second governor of Portuguese India conquered and established the Portuguese colonial empire in the Indian Ocean. He is generally considered a world conquest military genius, given his successful strategy: he attempted to close all the Indian ocean naval passages to the Atlantic, Red Sea, Persian Gulf, and to the Pacific, transforming it into a Portuguese mare clausum established over the Turkish power and their Muslim and Hindu allies. He was responsible for building numerous fortresses to defend key strategic positions and establishing a net of diplomatic relations. Shortly before his death he was awarded viceroy and "Duke of Goa" by king Manuel I of Portugal, becoming the first Portuguese duke not from the royal family, and the first Portuguese title landed overseas. For some time he was known as The Terrible, The Great, The Caesar of the East, Lion of the Seas and as The Portuguese Mars.

TEXT.German: [H1]Afonso de Albuquerque[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Gouverneur von Portugiesisch-Indien, Vizeknig und Herzog von Goa[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Gelebt:[\BOLD] 1453 - 16. Dezember 1515[PARAGRAPH :2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Afonso de Albuquerque war ein portugiesischer Fidalgo oder Adliger, ein Admiral, dessen militrische und administrative Aktivitten als zweiter Gouverneur von Portugiesisch-Indien das portugiesische Kolonialreich eroberten und grndeten der Indische Ozean. Aufgrund seiner erfolgreichen Strategie gilt er allgemein als militrisches Genie der Welteroberung: Er versuchte, alle Seepassagen des Indischen Ozeans zum Atlantik, zum Roten Meer, zum Persischen Golf und zum Pazifik zu sperren und sie in ein ber dem Indischen Ozean errichtetes portugiesisches Mare Clausum umzuwandeln Die trkische Macht und ihre muslimischen und hinduistischen Verbndeten. Er war fr den Bau zahlreicher Festungen zur Verteidigung wichtiger strategischer Positionen und den Aufbau eines Netzes diplomatischer Beziehungen verantwortlich. Kurz vor seinem Tod wurde er von Knig Manuel I. von Portugal zum Vizeknig und "Herzog von Goa" ernannt und war damit der erste portugiesische Herzog, der nicht der kniglichen Familie angehrte, und der erste portugiesische Titel landete im Ausland. Eine Zeit lang war er als "Der Schreckliche", "Der Groe", "Der Csar des Ostens", "Lwe der Meere" und als "Der portugiesische Mars" bekannt.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Sultanate of Rûm was the continuation of the Great Seljuq Empire in Anatolia, in direct lineage from 1077 to 1307. At its height the sultanate stretched across central Anatolia from the Antalya-Alanya shoreline on the Mediterranean coast to the territory of Sinop on the Black Sea. In the east, the sultanate absorbed other Turkish states and reached Lake Van. Its westernmost limit was near Denizli and the gates of the Aegean basin.[PARAGRAPH:1]The term "Rûm" comes from the Arabic word for the Roman Empire. The Seljuks called the lands of their sultanate Rum because it had been established on territory long considered "Roman", i.e. Byzantine, by Muslim armies.[PARAGRAPH:1]The sultanate prospered, particularly during the late 12th and early 13th centuries when it took from the Byzantines key ports on the Mediterranean and Black Sea coasts. Within Anatolia the Seljuks fostered trade through a program of caravanserai (han) building, which facilitated the flow of goods from Iran and Central Asia to the ports. Especially strong trade ties with the Genoese formed during this period. The increased wealth allowed the sultanate to absorb other Turkish states that had been established in eastern Anatolia after the Battle of Manzikert: the Danishmends, the Mengcek, the Saltuklu, and the Artuklu. Seljuk sultans successfully bore the brunt of the Crusades but in 1243 succumbed to the advancing Mongols. The Seljuks became vassals of the Mongols, and despite the efforts of shrewd administrators to preserve the state's integrity, the power of the sultanate disintegrated during the second half of the 13th century and had disappeared completely by the first decade of the 14th.[PARAGRAPH:1]In its final decades, the territory of the Seljuk Sultanate of Rûm saw the emergence of a number of small principalities or beyliks, among which that of the Osmanoglu, known later as the Ottomans, rose to dominance.

Auf seinem Hhepunkt erstreckte sich das Sultanat ber Zentralanatolien von der Kste Antalya-Alanya an der Mittelmeerkste bis das Gebiet von Sinop am Schwarzen Meer. Die Seldschuken nannten die Lndereien ihres Sultanats Rum, weil es von muslimischen Armeen auf einem Gebiet errichtet worden war, das lange Zeit als "rmisch", d von den byzantinischen Schlsselhfen an der Mittelmeer- und Schwarzmeerkste. Innerhalb Anatoliens frderten die Seldschuken den Handel durch ein Programm zum Bau von Karawansereien (Han), das den Warenfluss aus dem Iran und Zentralasien zu den Hfen erleichterte. In dieser Zeit entstanden besonders starke Handelsbeziehungen mit den Genuesen. Der gestiegene Reichtum ermglichte es dem Sultanat, andere trkische Staaten zu absorbieren, die nach der Schlacht von Manzikert in Ostanatolien gegrndet worden waren: die Danishmends, die Mengcek, die Saltuklu und die Artuklu. Die Seldschuken wurden zu Vasallen der Mongolen, und trotz der Bemhungen kluger Administratoren, die Integritt des Staates zu bewahren, zerfiel die Macht des Sultanats in der zweiten Hlfte des 13. Jahrhunderts und war im ersten Jahrzehnt des 14. Jahrhunderts vollstndig verschwunden.[PARAGRAPH: 1]In den letzten Jahrzehnten entstanden auf dem Gebiet des seldschukischen Sultanats Rim eine Reihe kleiner Frstentmer oder Beyliks, unter denen das der Osmanoglu, spter als Osmanen bekannt, zur Vorherrschaft gelangte.

TEXT.English: [H1]Kilij Arslan I[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Seljuk Sultan of Rûm[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] c. 1092 - 1107[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Kilij Arslan was the Seljuk Sultan of Rûm from 1092 until his death in 1107. He ruled the Sultanate during the time of the First Crusade and thus faced the brunt of the entire attack. He also re-established the Sultanate of Rum after the death of Malik Shah I of Great Seljuk and soundly defeated the Crusaders in three separate battles during the Crusade of 1101 which arose as a well-managed response to the First Crusade.[PARAGRAPH:1]After the crusades he moved towards the east taking Harran, and Diyarbakr. In 1107 he conquered Mosul, but he was defeated by Emir Jawali al-Saqawu for Mehmed I of Great Seljuk supported by the Ortoqids and Fakhr al-Mulk Radwan of Aleppo at the Battle of Mosul. Kilij Arslan died in his capital.

TEXT.German: [H1]Kilij Arslan I.[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Seldschukischer Sultan von Rûm[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Regierungszeit:[\BOLD] c. 1092 - 1107[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Kilij Arslan war von 1092 bis zu seinem Tod im Jahr 1107 der seldschukische Sultan von Ram. Er regierte zu dieser Zeit das Sultanat des Ersten Kreuzzugs und war somit der Hauptlast des gesamten Angriffs ausgesetzt. Er grndete auch das Sultanat Rum nach dem Tod von Malik Schah I. von Gro-Seldschuken wieder und besiegte die Kreuzfahrer in drei getrennten Schlachten whrend des Kreuzzugs von 1101, der eine gut gefhrte Reaktion auf den Ersten Kreuzzug darstellte.[ABSATZ:1 ]Nach den Kreuzzgen zog er nach Osten und nahm Harran und Diyarbakr ein. 1107 eroberte er Mossul, wurde jedoch von Emir Jawali al-Saqawu fr Mehmed I. von Gro-Seldschuken besiegt, der von den Ortoqiden und Fakhr al-Mulk Radwan von Aleppo in der Schlacht von Mossul untersttzt wurde. Kilij Arslan starb in seiner Hauptstadt.
