TEXT.English: [TAB]Beylik of Karaman or Karamanoglu, also called the Karamanid Dynasty or the Karamanids, was an Anatolian beylik state centered in south-central Anatolia, around the present-day Karaman Province. From the 13th century until its fall in 1487, Karamanoglu was one of the most powerful states in Anatolia.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Karamanids traced their ancestry back to Hoca Sadeddin and his son Nure Sufi, who emigrated from Azerbaijan to Sivas. He moved from there to the western Taurus Mountains, near the town of Larende, where he worked as a woodcutter. Nure Sufi's son, Kerimeddin Karaman Bey, gained a tenuous control over the mountainous parts of Cilicia in the middle of the 13th century. A persistent but spurious legend, however, claims that the Seljuk Sultan of Rum, Kayqubad I instead established Karaman in these lands. [PARAGRAPH:1]Karaman expanded his territories by capturing castles in Ermenek, Mut, Eregli, Gulnar, Mer and Silifke. As a reward for this expansion of Seljuk territory, the sultan Kilij Arslan IV gave the town of Larende (now Karaman in honor of the dynasty) to the Karamanoglu. Despite several blows from the Seljuks and Mongols, Karamanoglu continued to increase their power and influence, largely aided by the Mamluks of Egypt, especially during the reign of Baybars. Karamanoglu captured Konya on two occasions in the beginning of the 14th century, but were driven out the first time by emir Chupan, the Ilkhanid governor for Anatolia, and the second time by Emir Chupan's son and successor Timurtash. An expansion of Karamanoglu power occurred after the fall of the Ilkhanids. A second expansion coincided with Karamanoglu Alaeddin Ali Bey's marriage to Nefise Sultan, the daughter of the Ottoman sultan Murad II, the first important contact between the two dynasties.[PARAGRAPH:1]As Ottoman power expanded into the Balkans, Aleaddin Ali Bey captured the city of Beysehir, which had been an Ottoman city. However, it did not take much time for the Ottomans to react and march on Konya, the capital city of Karamanids. A treaty between the two kingdoms was made and peace existed until the reign of Bayezid I.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the Crusade of Varna against the Ottomans in 1443-4, Karamanid Ibrahim Bey marched on Ankara and Kutahya, destroying both cities. In the meantime, the Ottoman sultan Murad II was returning from Rumelia with a victory against the Hungarian Crusaders. Like all other Islamic emirates in Anatolia, the Karamanids were accused of treason. Hence, Ibrahim Bey accepted all Ottoman terms. The Karamanid state was eventually terminated by the Ottomans in 1487, as the power of their Egyptian allies was declining.

Jahrhunderts zweimal, wurde jedoch beim ersten Mal von Emir Chupan, dem Gouverneur der Ilchaniden fr Anatolien, und beim zweiten Mal von Emir Chupans Sohn und Nachfolger Timurtasch vertrieben. TEXT.English: [TAB]The Kingdom of Jerusalem was a Christian kingdom established in the Levant in 1099 after the First Crusade. It lasted nearly two hundred years, from 1099 until 1291 when the last remaining possession, Acre, was destroyed by the Mamluks.[PARAGRAPH:1]At first the kingdom was little more than a loose collection of towns and cities captured during the crusade. Later kings expanded its size so that at its height in the mid-12th century, the kingdom roughly encompassed the territory of modern-day Israel, Lebanon, and the Palestinian territories. It extended from Lebanon in the north to the Sinai Desert in the south, and into modern Jordan and Syria in the east. There were attempts to expand the kingdom into Fatimid Egypt. Its kings held a certain amount of authority over the other crusader states: Tripoli, Antioch, and Edessa.[PARAGRAPH:1]Many customs and institutions were imported from the crusaders' original homelands in Western Europe, and there were close familial and political connections with the West throughout the kingdom's existence. As a relatively minor kingdom it often lacked financial and military support from Europe. The kingdom had closer ties to the neighbouring Kingdom of Armenia and the Byzantine Empire, from which it inherited oriental qualities, as well as being influenced by pre-existing Eastern institutions. Socially, the Frankish inhabitants were dominant and the Muslims and eastern Christians were a marginalized lower class.[PARAGRAPH:1]At first the Muslim world held little concern for the fledgling kingdom, but as the 12th century progressed, the kingdom's Muslim neighbours were united by Nur ad-Din Zangi and Saladin, who vigorously began to recapture lost territory. Jerusalem itself was lost to Saladin in 1187, and by the 13th century the Kingdom was reduced to a few cities along the Mediterranean coast. In this period, the kingdom, sometimes referred to as the "Kingdom of Acre", was ruled by the Lusignan dynasty of the crusader Kingdom of Cyprus, and ties were strengthened with Tripoli, Antioch, and Armenia. The kingdom was soon increasingly dominated by the Italian city-states of Venice and Genoa, as well as the imperial ambitions of the Holy Roman Emperors. The kingdom became little more than a pawn in the politics and warfare of the Ayyubid and Mamluk dynasties in Egypt, as well as the Khwarezmian and Mongol invaders. The Mamluk sultans Baibars and al-Ashraf Khalil eventually reconquered all the remaining crusader strongholds, culminating in the destruction of Acre in 1291.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Das Knigreich Jerusalem war ein christliches Knigreich, das 1099 nach dem Ersten Kreuzzug in der Levante gegrndet wurde. Es dauerte fast zweihundert Jahre, von 1099 bis 1291, als der letzte verbleibende Besitz, Acre, von den Mamluken zerstrt wurde.[PARAGRAPH:1]Zuerst war das Knigreich kaum mehr als eine lose Ansammlung von Stdten, die whrend des Kreuzzugs erobert wurden. Sptere Knige erweiterten seine Gre, so dass das Knigreich auf seinem Hhepunkt in der Mitte des 12. Jahrhunderts ungefhr das Gebiet des heutigen Israel, des Libanon und der palstinensischen Gebiete umfasste. Es erstreckte sich vom Libanon im Norden bis zur Sinai-Wste im Sden und bis in das heutige Jordanien und Syrien im Osten. Es gab Versuche, das Knigreich nach dem fatimidischen gypten auszudehnen. Seine Knige hatten ein gewisses Ma an Autoritt ber die anderen Kreuzfahrerstaaten: Tripolis, Antiochia und Edessa.[PARAGRAPH:1]Viele Bruche und Institutionen wurden aus den ursprnglichen Heimatlndern der Kreuzfahrer in Westeuropa importiert, und es gab enge familire und politische Verbindungen mit dem Westen whrend der gesamten Existenz des Knigreichs. Als relativ kleines Knigreich fehlte es oft an finanzieller und militrischer Untersttzung aus Europa. Das Knigreich hatte engere Beziehungen zum benachbarten Knigreich Armenien und zum Byzantinischen Reich, von denen es orientalische Qualitten erbte und von bereits bestehenden stlichen Institutionen beeinflusst wurde. Gesellschaftlich dominierten die frnkischen Einwohner und die Muslime und stlichen Christen bildeten eine marginalisierte Unterschicht.[PARAGRAPH:1]Zuerst kmmerte sich die muslimische Welt wenig um das junge Knigreich, aber im Laufe des 12. Jahrhunderts vereinten sich die muslimischen Nachbarn des Knigreichs von Nur ad-Din Zangi und Saladin, die energisch damit begannen, verlorenes Territorium zurckzuerobern. Jerusalem selbst ging 1187 an Saladin verloren und im 13. Jahrhundert wurde das Knigreich auf wenige Stdte entlang der Mittelmeerkste reduziert. In dieser Zeit wurde das Knigreich, das manchmal auch als "Knigreich Akko" bezeichnet wird, von der Lusignan-Dynastie des Kreuzfahrerknigreichs Zypern regiert, und die Beziehungen zu Tripolis, Antiochia und Armenien wurden gestrkt. Das Knigreich wurde bald zunehmend von den italienischen Stadtstaaten Venedig und Genua sowie den imperialen Ambitionen der Kaiser des Heiligen Rmischen Reiches dominiert. Das Knigreich wurde kaum mehr als eine Schachfigur in der Politik und Kriegsfhrung der Ayyubiden- und Mamluken-Dynastien in gypten sowie der Khwarezm- und Mongolen-Invasoren. Die Mamluk-Sultane Baibars und al-Ashraf Khalil eroberten schlielich alle verbliebenen Kreuzfahrerhochburgen zurck, was 1291 in der Zerstrung von Acre gipfelte.

TEXT.English: [H1]Baldwin I of Jerusalem[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Count of Edessa and King of Jerusalem[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c. 1058 - 2 April 1118[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Baldwin was one of the leaders of the First Crusade, who became the first Count of Edessa and then the second ruler and first titled King of Jerusalem. He was the brother of Godfrey of Bouillon, who was the first ruler of the crusader state of Jerusalem, although he refused the title of 'king' which Baldwin accepted. [PARAGRAPH:1]Baldwin joined the First Crusade in 1096 with his brothers Godfrey and Eustace III of Boulogne, selling much of his property to the church in order to pay for his expenses. Baldwin accompanied his brothers as far as Heraclea in Asia Minor, where he broke away from the main body of the crusaders to march into Cilicia. He briefly occupied Tarsus and Turbessel, then was adopted by Thoros of Edessa, becoming Thoros' son and successor. When Thoros was assassinated in March of 1098, Baldwin became the first count of Edessa, although it is unknown if he played any role in the assassination. He ruled the county until 1100, marrying Arda, the daughter of Thoros, and acted as an ambassador between the crusaders and Armenians. [PARAGRAPH:1]After the death of Baldwin's brother Godfrey in 1100, he was crowned the first king of Jerusalem and quickly began expanding his territory. In 1101 he captured Arsuf and Caesarea, with assistance from a Genoese fleet. In return the Genoese were granted trading quarters in these towns, and an archbishopric was established in Caesarea. In 1103 Baldwin besieged Acre, without success as it was relieved by an Egyptian fleet. In 1104 however Baldwin was assisted by a Genoese fleet and Acre was captured. In 1105 another battle was fought at Ramlah and Baldwin was victorious here as well. In 1110 Beirut was added to the territory of Jerusalem, again with help from the Genoese. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1113 Baldwin faced a large invasion by the combined forces of Toghtekin of Damascus and Aksunk-ur of Mosul, and though the kingdom was on the brink of destruction Baldwin was assisted by troops from Antioch and new arrivals of European pilgrims at the Battle of Al-Sannabra. In 1113 he also married Adelaide del Vasto; he had abandoned his Armenian wife Arda in 1108, on the pretext that she had been unfaithful, or, according to Guibert of Nogent, because she had been raped by pirates on the way to Jerusalem. It is more likely however that she was simply politically useless in Jerusalem, which had no Armenian population. Technically the marriage to Adelaide was bigamous because Arda was still alive in a monastery in Jerusalem, and it would later cause many problems both for Baldwin and Patriarch Arnulf, who had sanctioned it. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1115 he led an expedition into Transjordan and built the castle of Montreal. The Syrian Christians who lived in the area were invited to settle in Jerusalem to replenish the population, which had been mostly massacred in 1099. In 1117 he built the castle of Scandalion near Tyre, which was still in Muslim hands. At this point the army in the Kingdom of Jerusalem consisted of only 6,000 men, including 1,000 knights but it was augmented with 5,000 turcopoles. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1117 Baldwin fell ill. He was convinced that the sickness was due to his bigamous marriage to Adelaide, and in response Adelaide was sent back to Sicily, much to her disgust. Baldwin recovered, however, and in 1118 he marched into Egypt and plundered Farama. Then he fell ill again and died on the way back to Jerusalem. Fulcher of Chartres says "The Franks wept, the Syrians, and even the Saracens who saw it grieved also." His cousin Baldwin of Bourcq was chosen as his successor, although the kingdom was also offered to Eustace III, who did not want it.

In 1101 he captured Arsuf and Caesarea, with assistance from a Genoese fleet. In return the Genoese were granted trading quarters in these towns, and an archbishopric was established in Caesarea. In 1103 Baldwin besieged Acre, without success as it was relieved by an Egyptian fleet. In 1104 however Baldwin was assisted by a Genoese fleet and Acre was captured. In 1105 another battle was fought at Ramlah and Baldwin was victorious here as well. In 1110 Beirut was added to the territory of Jerusalem, again with help from the Genoese. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1113 Baldwin faced a large invasion by the combined forces of Toghtekin of Damascus and Aksunk-ur of Mosul, and though the kingdom was on the brink of destruction Baldwin was assisted by troops from Antioch and new arrivals of European pilgrims at the Battle of Al-Sannabra. In 1113 he also married Adelaide del Vasto; he had abandoned his Armenian wife Arda in 1108, on the pretext that she had been unfaithful, or, according to Guibert of Nogent, because she had been raped by pirates on the way to Jerusalem. It is more likely however that she was simply politically useless in Jerusalem, which had no Armenian population. Technically the marriage to Adelaide was bigamous because Arda was still alive in a monastery in Jerusalem, and it would later cause many problems both for Baldwin and Patriarch Arnulf, who had sanctioned it. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1115 he led an expedition into Transjordan and built the castle of Montreal. The Syrian Christians who lived in the area were invited to settle in Jerusalem to replenish the population, which had been mostly massacred in 1099. In 1117 he built the castle of Scandalion near Tyre, which was still in Muslim hands. At this point the army in the Kingdom of Jerusalem consisted of only 6,000 men, including 1,000 knights but it was augmented with 5,000 turcopoles. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 1117 Baldwin fell ill. He was convinced that the sickness was due to his bigamous marriage to Adelaide, and in response Adelaide was sent back to Sicily, much to her disgust. Baldwin recovered, however, and in 1118 he marched into Egypt and plundered Farama. Then he fell ill again and died on the way back to Jerusalem. Fulcher of Chartres says "The Franks wept, the Syrians, and even the Saracens who saw it grieved also." His cousin Baldwin of Bourcq was chosen as his successor, although the kingdom was also offered to Eustace III, who did not want it.
TEXT.German: [H1]Baldwin I. von Jerusalem[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Graf von Edessa und Knig von Jerusalem[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] ca. 1058 - 2. April 1118[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Baldwin war einer der Anfhrer des Ersten Kreuzzugs, der der erste Graf von Edessa und dann der zweite und erste Herrscher wurde mit dem Titel "Knig von Jerusalem". Er war der Bruder von Gottfried von Bouillon, dem ersten Herrscher des Kreuzfahrerstaates Jerusalem, obwohl er den Titel "Knig" ablehnte, den Baldwin akzeptierte. [PARAGRAPH:1]Baldwin schloss sich 1096 mit seinen Brdern Godfrey und Eustace III von Boulogne dem Ersten Kreuzzug an und verkaufte einen Groteil seines Eigentums an die Kirche, um seine Ausgaben zu bezahlen. Balduin begleitete seine Brder bis nach Herakleia in Kleinasien, wo er sich von der Hauptmacht der Kreuzfahrer lste, um nach Kilikien zu marschieren. Er besetzte kurzzeitig Tarsus und Turbessel, wurde dann von Thoros von Edessa adoptiert und wurde Thoros' Sohn und Nachfolger. Als Thoros im Mrz 1098 ermordet wurde, wurde Balduin der erste Graf von Edessa, obwohl nicht bekannt ist, ob er bei dem Attentat eine Rolle spielte. Er regierte die Grafschaft bis 1100, heiratete Arda, die Tochter von Thoros, und fungierte als Botschafter zwischen den Kreuzfahrern und den Armeniern. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nach dem Tod von Baldwins Bruder Godfrey im Jahr 1100 wurde er zum ersten Knig von Jerusalem gekrnt und begann schnell, sein Territorium zu erweitern. Im Jahr 1101 eroberte er mit Untersttzung einer genuesischen Flotte Arsuf und Csarea. Im Gegenzug erhielten die Genueser Handelsquartiere in diesen Stdten und in Csarea wurde ein Erzbistum errichtet. Im Jahr 1103 belagerte Balduin Acre erfolglos, da es von einer gyptischen Flotte abgelst wurde. Im Jahr 1104 wurde Balduin jedoch von einer genuesischen Flotte untersttzt und Acre wurde erobert. Im Jahr 1105 kam es zu einer weiteren Schlacht bei Ramlah und Balduin siegte auch hier. Im Jahr 1110 wurde Beirut, wiederum mit Hilfe der Genueser, dem Gebiet Jerusalems angegliedert. [PARAGRAPH:1]Im Jahr 1113 sah sich Balduin einer groen Invasion durch die vereinten Streitkrfte von Toghtekin von Damaskus und Aksunk-ur von Mossul gegenber, und obwohl das Knigreich am Rande der Zerstrung stand, wurde Balduin von Truppen aus Antiochia und Neuankmmlingen europischer Pilger untersttzt in der Schlacht von Al-Sannabra. Im Jahr 1113 heiratete er auch Adelaide del Vasto; Er hatte seine armenische Frau Arda 1108 unter dem Vorwand verlassen, sie sei untreu gewesen, oder, laut Guibert von Nogent, weil sie auf dem Weg nach Jerusalem von Piraten vergewaltigt worden sei. Es ist jedoch wahrscheinlicher, dass sie in Jerusalem, wo es keine armenische Bevlkerung gab, einfach politisch nutzlos war. Technisch gesehen war die Ehe mit Adelaide bigam, da Arda noch in einem Kloster in Jerusalem lebte, und sie wrde spter sowohl fr Balduin als auch fr Patriarch Arnulf, der sie genehmigt hatte, viele Probleme bereiten. [PARAGRAPH:1]Im Jahr 1115 leitete er eine Expedition nach Transjordanien und baute die Burg von Montreal. Die in der Gegend lebenden syrischen Christen wurden eingeladen, sich in Jerusalem niederzulassen, um die Bevlkerung wieder aufzufllen, die 1099 grtenteils massakriert worden war. 1117 baute er die Burg Skandalion in der Nhe von Tyrus, die noch in muslimischer Hand war. Zu diesem Zeitpunkt bestand die Armee im Knigreich Jerusalem nur aus 6.000 Mann, darunter 1.000 Ritter, wurde aber durch 5.000 Turcopoles verstrkt. [PARAGRAPH:1]Im Jahr 1117 wurde Balduin krank. Er war berzeugt, dass die Krankheit auf seine bigamische Ehe mit Adelaide zurckzufhren war, und als Reaktion darauf wurde Adelaide zu ihrem groen Ekel nach Sizilien zurckgeschickt. Balduin erholte sich jedoch und marschierte 1118 in gypten ein und plnderte Farama. Dann wurde er erneut krank und starb auf dem Rckweg nach Jerusalem. Fulcher von Chartres sagt: "Die Franken weinten, die Syrer und sogar die Sarazenen, die es sahen, waren ebenfalls betrbt." Sein Cousin Balduin von Bourcq wurde zu seinem Nachfolger gewhlt, obwohl das Knigreich auch Eustachius III. angeboten wurde, der es nicht wollte.

TEXT.English: [H1]Guy of Lusignan[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Jerusalem and Cyprus[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c. 1150 - 18 July 1194[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Guy of Lusignan was a Poitevin knight, son of Hugh VIII of the Lusignan dynasty. He was king of the crusader state of Jerusalem from 1186 to 1192 by right of marriage to Sibylla of Jerusalem, and of Cyprus from 1192 to 1194. Having arrived in the Holy Land (where his brother Amalric was already prominent) at an unknown date, Guy was hastily married to Sibylla in 1180 to prevent a political incident within the kingdom. As Baldwin's health deteriorated, Guy was appointed regent of Jerusalem; at Sibylla's succession to the throne in 1186 she gave the crown to Guy as her king-consort. Guy's reign was marked by increased hostilities with the Ayyubids ruled by Saladin, culminating in the disastrous Battle of Hattin in July 1187 - during which Guy was captured - and the fall of Jerusalem itself three months later. [PARAGRAPH:1]Following a year of imprisonment in Damascus, Guy was released by Saladin. After being denied entry to Tyre, one of the last crusader strongholds, by Conrad of Montferrat, Guy besieged Acre in 1189. The siege developed into a rallying point for the Third Crusade, led by Philip Augustus of France and Sibylla's first cousin once-removed, Richard the Lionheart. Guy entered a bitter row with Conrad over the kingship of Jerusalem; despite Richard's support for Guy, Conrad was elected king by the nobility of the kingdom. Conrad was assassinated by the Hashshashin days after the election; Richard's and Guy's involvement in the incident is suspected, but unproven. Nevertheless, Guy was compensated for the dispossession of his crown by being given lordship of Cyprus in 1192, which Richard had annexed from the Byzantine Empire en route to the Levant. Guy ruled the Kingdom of Cyprus until his death in 1194, when he was succeeded by his brother Amalric.

TEXT.German: [H1]Guy de Lusignan[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Knig von Jerusalem und Zypern[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] ca. 1150 - 18. Juli 1194[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Guy von Lusignan war ein Poitevin-Ritter, Sohn von Hugo VIII. aus der Lusignan-Dynastie. Er war von 1186 bis 1192 Knig des Kreuzfahrerstaates Jerusalem aufgrund der Heirat mit Sibylla von Jerusalem und von 1192 bis 1194 Knig von Zypern. Zu einem unbekannten Zeitpunkt im Heiligen Land angekommen (wo sein Bruder Amalrich bereits prominent war), Guy heiratete 1180 berstrzt Sibylla, um einen politischen Zwischenfall im Knigreich zu verhindern. Als sich Baldwins Gesundheitszustand verschlechterte, wurde Guy zum Regenten von Jerusalem ernannt; Bei Sibyllas Thronfolge im Jahr 1186 schenkte sie Guy die Krone als ihrem Knigsgemahl. Guys Regierungszeit war von zunehmenden Feindseligkeiten mit den von Saladin regierten Ayyubiden geprgt, die in der verheerenden Schlacht von Hattin im Juli 1187 - in der Guy gefangen genommen wurde - und dem Fall Jerusalems selbst drei Monate spter ihren Hhepunkt fanden. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nach einem Jahr Haft in Damaskus wurde Guy von Saladin freigelassen. Nachdem ihm Konrad von Montferrat den Zutritt zu Tyros, einer der letzten Kreuzfahrerhochburgen, verweigert hatte, belagerte Guy 1189 Acre. Die Belagerung entwickelte sich zu einem Sammelpunkt fr den Dritten Kreuzzug, angefhrt von Philipp Augustus von Frankreich und Sibyllas Cousin ersten Grades, der einst vertrieben worden war , Richard Lwenherz. Guy geriet mit Konrad in einen erbitterten Streit um das Knigtum von Jerusalem; Trotz Richards Untersttzung fr Guy wurde Conrad vom Adel des Knigreichs zum Knig gewhlt. Conrad wurde wenige Tage nach der Wahl von den Hashshashin ermordet; Die Beteiligung von Richard und Guy an dem Vorfall wird vermutet, ist jedoch nicht bewiesen. Dennoch wurde Guy fr die Enteignung seiner Krone entschdigt, indem er 1192 die Herrschaft ber Zypern erhielt, das Richard auf dem Weg in die Levante vom Byzantinischen Reich annektiert hatte. Guy regierte das Knigreich Zypern bis zu seinem Tod im Jahr 1194, als sein Bruder Amalric seine Nachfolge antrat.

TEXT.English: [TAB]While Baldwin of Boulogne and Tancred headed east from Asia Minor to set up the County of Edessa, the main army of the First Crusade continued south to besiege Antioch. Bohemond of Taranto led the siege, beginning in October, 1097. With over four hundred towers, the city was almost impenetrable. The siege lasted throughout the winter, with much suffering among the Crusaders, who were often forced to eat their own horses, or, as legend has it, the bodies of their fellow Christians who had not survived.[PARAGRAPH:1]However, Bohemond convinced a guard in one of the towers, a former Christian named Firouz, to let the Crusaders enter the city. He did so on June 3, 1098, and a massacre of the Muslim inhabitants followed. There was a lengthy dispute over who should control the city. Bohemond and the other Italian Normans eventually won, and Bohemond named himself prince. Bohemond was already prince of Taranto in Italy, and he desired to continue such independence in his new lordship; thus he did not attempt to receive the title of Duke from the Byzantine Emperor (in whose name he had taken an oath to fight), nor any other title with deep feudal obligations, such as count.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bohemond I was captured in battle with the Danishmends in 1100, and his nephew Tancred became regent. Tancred expanded the borders of the Principality, taking the cities of Tarsus and Latakia from the Byzantine Empire. Bohemond was released in 1103, but left Tancred as regent again when he went to Italy to raise more troops in 1105. He used these troops to attack the Byzantines in 1107, but was defeated. Bohemond also fought Aleppo with Baldwin and Joscelin of the County of Edessa; when Baldwin and Joscelin were captured, Tancred became regent in Edessa as well. Bohemond left Tancred as regent once more and returned to Italy, where he died in 1111.[PARAGRAPH:1]After the fall of Edessa in 1144, Antioch was attacked by Nur ad-Din during the Second Crusade. Much of the eastern part of the Principality was lost to the Muslims. From the second half of the 12th century onwards, Antioch took no active part in the Crusades. Instead, its rulers engaged in constant political and military struggle with the Zengids, Byzantines, Armenians and Tripoli, often switching alliegance and enemies. When the Mongols were defeated at the Battle of Ain Jalut in 1260, the Mamluk Sultan Baibars began to threaten Antioch, which (as a vassal of the Armenians) had supported the Mongols. Baibars finally took the city in 1268, and all of northern Syria was quickly lost; twenty-three years later, Acre was taken, and the Crusader states ceased to exist.

Instead, its rulers engaged in constant political and military struggle with the Zengids, Byzantines, Armenians and Tripoli, often switching alliegance and enemies. When the Mongols were defeated at the Battle of Ain Jalut in 1260, the Mamluk Sultan Baibars began to threaten Antioch, which (as a vassal of the Armenians) had supported the Mongols. Baibars finally took the city in 1268, and all of northern Syria was quickly lost; twenty-three years later, Acre was taken, and the Crusader states ceased to exist.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Whrend Balduin von Boulogne und Tankred von Kleinasien nach Osten zog, um die Grafschaft Edessa zu errichten, zog die Hauptarmee des Ersten Kreuzzugs weiter nach Sden, um Antiochia zu belagern. Bohemund von Taranto fhrte die Belagerung an, die im Oktober 1097 begann. Mit ber vierhundert Trmen war die Stadt nahezu uneinnehmbar. Die Belagerung dauerte den ganzen Winter und brachte viel Leid unter den Kreuzfahrern, die oft gezwungen waren, ihre eigenen Pferde zu essen, oder, wie die Legende sagt, die Leichen ihrer Mitchristen, die nicht berlebt hatten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Allerdings, Bohemond berzeugte einen Wachmann in einem der Trme, einen ehemaligen Christen namens Firouz, den Kreuzfahrern den Zutritt zur Stadt zu ermglichen. Er tat dies am 3. Juni 1098 und es kam zu einem Massaker an den muslimischen Einwohnern. Es gab einen langen Streit darber, wer die Stadt kontrollieren sollte. Bohemond und die anderen italienischen Normannen gewannen schlielich und Bohemond ernannte sich selbst zum Prinzen. Bohemond war bereits Prinz von Taranto in Italien und wollte diese Unabhngigkeit auch in seiner neuen Herrschaft beibehalten; Daher versuchte er nicht, vom byzantinischen Kaiser (in dessen Namen er einen Kampfeid geschworen hatte) den Titel eines Herzogs oder einen anderen Titel mit tiefen feudalen Verpflichtungen wie den Grafentitel zu erhalten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bohemund I. wurde gefangen genommen im Kampf mit den Danishmends im Jahr 1100, und sein Neffe Tancred wurde Regent. Tankred erweiterte die Grenzen des Frstentums und eroberte die Stdte Tarsus und Latakia vom Byzantinischen Reich. Bohemond wurde 1103 freigelassen, berlie Tancred jedoch erneut die Regentschaft, als er 1105 nach Italien ging, um weitere Truppen aufzustellen. Mit diesen Truppen griff er 1107 die Byzantiner an, wurde jedoch besiegt. Bohemond kmpfte auch mit Balduin und Joscelin aus der Grafschaft Edessa gegen Aleppo; Als Balduin und Joscelin gefangen genommen wurden, wurde Tancred auch Regent in Edessa. Bohemond verlie Tancred erneut als Regent und kehrte nach Italien zurck, wo er 1111 starb.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nach dem Fall von Edessa im Jahr 1144 wurde Antiochia whrend des Zweiten Kreuzzugs von Nur ad-Din angegriffen. Ein groer Teil des stlichen Teils des Frstentums ging an die Muslime verloren. Ab der zweiten Hlfte des 12. Jahrhunderts nahm Antiochia nicht mehr aktiv an den Kreuzzgen teil. Stattdessen fhrten seine Herrscher einen stndigen politischen und militrischen Kampf mit den Zengiden, Byzantinern, Armeniern und Tripolis und wechselten hufig die Verbndeten und Feinde. Als die Mongolen 1260 in der Schlacht von Ain Jalut besiegt wurden, begann der Mamluken-Sultan Baibars, Antiochia zu bedrohen, das (als Vasall der Armenier) die Mongolen untersttzt hatte. Baibars eroberten schlielich 1268 die Stadt und ganz Nordsyrien war schnell verloren; 23 Jahre spter wurde Acre eingenommen und die Kreuzfahrerstaaten hrten auf zu existieren.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]While Baldwin of Boulogne and Tancred headed east from Asia Minor to set up the County of Edessa, the main army of the First Crusade continued south to besiege Antioch. Bohemond of Taranto led the siege, beginning in October, 1097. With over four hundred towers, the city was almost impenetrable. The siege lasted throughout the winter, with much suffering among the Crusaders, who were often forced to eat their own horses, or, as legend has it, the bodies of their fellow Christians who had not survived.[PARAGRAPH:1]However, Bohemond convinced a guard in one of the towers, a former Christian named Firouz, to let the Crusaders enter the city. He did so on June 3, 1098, and a massacre of the Muslim inhabitants followed. There was a lengthy dispute over who should control the city. Bohemond and the other Italian Normans eventually won, and Bohemond named himself prince. Bohemond was already prince of Taranto in Italy, and he desired to continue such independence in his new lordship; thus he did not attempt to receive the title of Duke from the Byzantine Emperor (in whose name he had taken an oath to fight), nor any other title with deep feudal obligations, such as count.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bohemond I was captured in battle with the Danishmends in 1100, and his nephew Tancred became regent. Tancred expanded the borders of the Principality, taking the cities of Tarsus and Latakia from the Byzantine Empire. Bohemond was released in 1103, but left Tancred as regent again when he went to Italy to raise more troops in 1105. He used these troops to attack the Byzantines in 1107, but was defeated. Bohemond also fought Aleppo with Baldwin and Joscelin of the County of Edessa; when Baldwin and Joscelin were captured, Tancred became regent in Edessa as well. Bohemond left Tancred as regent once more and returned to Italy, where he died in 1111.[PARAGRAPH:1]After the fall of Edessa in 1144, Antioch was attacked by Nur ad-Din during the Second Crusade. TEXT.English: [H1]Bohemond I of Antioch[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Prince of Taranto and Antioch[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c. 1058 - 3 March 1111[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Bohemond I was one of the leaders of the First Crusade and the founder of the Principality of Antioch. He was born in San Marco Argentano, Calabria, as the eldest son of the Norman nobleman Robert Guiscard, Duke of Apulia and Calabria, and his first wife Alberada of Buonalbergo.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bohemond served under his father in the great attack on the Byzantine Empire (10801085) and commanded the Normans during Guiscard's absence (10821084), penetrating into Thessaly as far as Larissa, but being eventually repulsed by Alexius I Comnenus. This early hostility to Alexius had a great influence in determining the course and policy of the Empire from time of Bohemond (whom his father had destined for the throne of Constantinople) to that of Roger II of Sicily.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1096, Bohemond, along with his uncle Roger I of Sicily the great count of Sicily, was attacking Amalfi, which had revolted against Duke Roger, when bands of crusaders began to pass, on their way through Italy to Constantinople. The zeal of the crusader came upon Bohemond: it is possible however, that he saw in the First Crusade nothing more than a chance to carve for himself an eastern principality. Geoffrey Malaterra bluntly states that Bohemond took the Cross with the intention of plundering and conquering Greek lands.[PARAGRAPH:1]He gathered a Norman army, perhaps one of the finest in the crusading host, at the head of which he crossed the Adriatic Sea, and penetrated to Constantinople along the route he had tried to follow in 10821084. He was careful to observe a "correct" attitude towards Alexius, and when he arrived at Constantinople in April 1097 he did homage to the emperor. From Constantinople to Antioch, Bohemond was the real leader of the First Crusade; and it says much for his leadership that the First Crusade succeeded in crossing Asia Minor, which the Crusade of 1101, the Second Crusade in 1147, and the Third Crusade in 1189 failed to accomplish.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bohemond was the first to get into position before Antioch, and he took a great part in the siege of the city. The capture of Antioch was due to his connection with Firouz, one of the commanders in the city; but he would not bring matters to an issue until the possession of the city was assured him in 1098. He stayed in the neighbourhood of Antioch to secure his position, while the other crusaders moved southward to the capture of Jerusalem.[PARAGRAPH:1]It might seem that Bohemond was destined to found a great principality in Antioch, which would dwarf Jerusalem; he had a fine territory, a good strategic position and a strong army. But he had to face two great forcesthe Byzantine Empire, which claimed the whole of his territories and was supported in its claim by Raymond of Toulouse, and the strong Muslim principalities in the north-east of Syria. Against these two forces he failed.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bohemond was decisively defeated by Muslim forces while marching on Harran. This defeat was followed by Greek attack on Cilicia, previously captured for the principality by Tancred, Bohemond's nephew. In late 1104 Bohemond returned to Europe for reinforcements. He enthralled audiences across France with gifts of relics from the Holy Land and tales of heroism while fighting the infidel, gathering a large army in the process. His new found status won him the hand of Constance, the daughter of the French king, Philip I. [PARAGRAPH:1]Dazzled by his success, Bohemond resolved to use his army of 34,000 men, not to defend Antioch against the Greeks, but to attack Alexius. He did so; but Alexius, aided by the Venetians, proved too strong, and Bohemond had to submit to a humiliating peace, by which he became the vassal of Alexius, consented to receive his pay, with the title of sebastos, and promised to cede disputed territories and to admit a Greek patriarch into Antioch. Henceforth Bohemond was a broken man. He died without returning to the East, and was buried at Canosa in Apulia, in 1111. The principality he founded, however, survived for 170 years.

TEXT.German: [H1]Bohemond I. von Antiochia[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Prinz von Taranto und Antiochia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] ca. 1058 - 3. Mrz 1111[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Bohemond I. war einer der Anfhrer des Ersten Kreuzzugs und der Grnder des Frstentums Antiochia. Er wurde in San Marco Argentano, Kalabrien, als ltester Sohn des normannischen Adligen Robert Guiscard, Herzog von Apulien und Kalabrien, und seiner ersten Frau Alberada von Buonalbergo geboren.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bohemond diente unter seinem Vater beim groen Angriff auf das Byzantinische Reich (1080-1085) und befehligte die Normannen whrend Guiscards Abwesenheit (1082-1084), drang bis nach Larissa in Thessalien ein, wurde aber schlielich von Alexios I. Komnenos zurckgeschlagen. Diese frhe Feindseligkeit gegenber Alexius hatte groen Einfluss auf den Kurs und die Politik des Reiches von der Zeit Bohemunds (den sein Vater fr den Thron von Konstantinopel vorgesehen hatte) bis zur Zeit Rogers II. von Sizilien.[PARAGRAPH:1]Im Jahr 1096 Bohemond griff zusammen mit seinem Onkel Roger I. von Sizilien, dem groen Grafen von Sizilien, Amalfi an, das sich gegen Herzog Roger aufgelehnt hatte, als Kreuzfahrerbanden auf ihrem Weg durch Italien nach Konstantinopel durchzogen. Der Eifer des Kreuzfahrers berkam Bohemund: Es ist jedoch mglich, dass er im Ersten Kreuzzug nichts weiter sah als eine Chance, sich ein stliches Frstentum zu erarbeiten. Geoffrey Malaterra gibt unverblmt an, dass Bohemond das Kreuz mit der Absicht nahm, griechische Lnder zu plndern und zu erobern.[PARAGRAPH:1]Er versammelte eine normannische Armee, vielleicht eine der besten der Kreuzzugsarmee, an deren Spitze er das Adriatische Meer berquerte und drang auf dem Weg, den er 1082-1084 versucht hatte, nach Konstantinopel vor. Er achtete darauf, eine "richtige" Haltung gegenber Alexius einzunehmen, und als er im April 1097 in Konstantinopel ankam, huldigte er dem Kaiser. Von Konstantinopel bis Antiochia war Bohemund der eigentliche Anfhrer des Ersten Kreuzzugs; und es sagt viel ber seine Fhrung aus, dass es dem Ersten Kreuzzug gelang, Kleinasien zu durchqueren, was dem Kreuzzug von 1101, dem Zweiten Kreuzzug von 1147 und dem Dritten Kreuzzug von 1189 nicht gelang.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bohemond war der Erste, der es schaffte stellte sich vor Antiochia in Stellung und beteiligte sich mageblich an der Belagerung der Stadt. Die Einnahme von Antiochia war auf seine Verbindung mit Firouz, einem der Kommandeure der Stadt, zurckzufhren; aber er brachte die Sache nicht zur Entscheidung, bis ihm 1098 der Besitz der Stadt zugesichert wurde. Er blieb in der Nhe von Antiochia, um seine Position zu sichern, whrend die anderen Kreuzfahrer nach Sden zogen, um Jerusalem einzunehmen.[ABSATZ:1] Es knnte scheinen, dass Bohemond dazu bestimmt war, in Antiochia ein groes Frstentum zu grnden, das Jerusalem in den Schatten stellen wrde; er hatte ein schnes Territorium, eine gute strategische Position und eine starke Armee. Aber er musste sich zwei groen Mchten stellen: dem Byzantinischen Reich, das sein gesamtes Territorium beanspruchte und in seinem Anspruch von Raymond von Toulouse untersttzt wurde, und den starken muslimischen Frstentmern im Nordosten Syriens. Gegen diese beiden Krfte scheiterte er.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bohemond wurde von muslimischen Streitkrften entscheidend geschlagen, als er auf Harran marschierte. Dieser Niederlage folgte ein griechischer Angriff auf Kilikien, das Tancred, Bohemonds Neffe, zuvor fr das Frstentum erobert hatte. Ende 1104 kehrte Bohemund zur Verstrkung nach Europa zurck. Er begeisterte das Publikum in ganz Frankreich mit Geschenken von Reliquien aus dem Heiligen Land und Geschichten ber Heldentum im Kampf gegen die Unglubigen und stellte dabei eine groe Armee zusammen. Sein neu gewonnener Status brachte ihm die Hand von Konstanze ein, der Tochter des franzsischen Knigs Philipp I. [PARAGRAPH:1]Von seinem Erfolg geblendet, beschloss Bohemond, seine Armee von 34.000 Mann einzusetzen, nicht um Antiochia gegen die Griechen zu verteidigen, sondern Alexius anzugreifen. Er tat es; Aber Alexius erwies sich mit Untersttzung der Venezianer als zu stark, und Bohemond musste sich einem demtigenden Frieden unterwerfen, durch den er zum Vasallen von Alexius wurde, sich bereit erklrte, seinen Lohn mit dem Titel Sebastos zu erhalten, und versprach, umstrittene Gebiete abzutreten einen griechischen Patriarchen in Antiochia aufzunehmen. Fortan war Bohemund ein gebrochener Mann. Er starb, ohne in den Osten zurckzukehren, und wurde 1111 in Canosa in Apulien beigesetzt. Das von ihm gegrndete Frstentum berlebte jedoch 170 Jahre.

He stayed in the neighbourhood of Antioch to secure his position, while the other crusaders moved southward to the capture of Jerusalem.[PARAGRAPH:1]It might seem that Bohemond was destined to found a great principality in Antioch, which would dwarf Jerusalem; he had a fine territory, a good strategic position and a strong army. But he had to face two great forcesthe Byzantine Empire, which claimed the whole of his territories and was supported in its claim by Raymond of Toulouse, and the strong Muslim principalities in the north-east of Syria. Against these two forces he failed.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bohemond was decisively defeated by Muslim forces while marching on Harran. This defeat was followed by Greek attack on Cilicia, previously captured for the principality by Tancred, Bohemond's nephew. In late 1104 Bohemond returned to Europe for reinforcements. He enthralled audiences across France with gifts of relics from the Holy Land and tales of heroism while fighting the infidel, gathering a large army in the process. His new found status won him the hand of Constance, the daughter of the French king, Philip I. [PARAGRAPH:1]Dazzled by his success, Bohemond resolved to use his army of 34,000 men, not to defend Antioch against the Greeks, but to attack Alexius. He did so; but Alexius, aided by the Venetians, proved too strong, and Bohemond had to submit to a humiliating peace, by which he became the vassal of Alexius, consented to receive his pay, with the title of sebastos, and promised to cede disputed territories and to admit a Greek patriarch into Antioch. Henceforth Bohemond was a broken man. He died without returning to the East, and was buried at Canosa in Apulia, in 1111. The principality he founded, however, survived for 170 years.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Georgia has one of the world's richest and oldest histories, stretching back to the prehistoric times. The rise of the early Georgian states of Colchis and Iberia in c.2000 BC formed the unique Georgian civilization which achieved its renaissance and golden age in 12-13th century.[PARAGRAPH:1]The first united Georgian monarchy was formed at the end of the 10th century when Curopalate David invaded the Earldom of Kartli-Iberia. Three years later, after the death of his uncle Theodosius the Blind, King of Egrisi-Abkhazia, Bagrat III inherited the Abkhazian throne. In 1001 Bagrat added Curopalatinate of Iberia to his domain as a result of David's death. In 1008-1010, Bagrat annexed Kakheti and Ereti, thus becoming the first king of a united Georgia.[PARAGRAPH:1]The second half of the 11th century was marked by the disastrous invasion of the Seljuk Turks, who by the end of the 1040s had succeeded in building a vast nomadic empire including most of Central Asia and Persia. In 1071, the Seljuk army destroyed the united Byzantine-Armenian and Georgian forces in the battle of Manzikert. By 1081, all of Armenia, Anatolia, Mesopotamia, Syria, and most of Georgia had been conquered and devastated by the Seljuks. In Georgia, only the mountainous areas of Abkhazia, Svanetia, Racha, and Khevi-Khevsureti remained out of Seljuk control and served as a relatively safe havens for numerous refugees. [PARAGRAPH:1]Although they were subsequently beset by various other invaders, principally Arabs, Mongols, Persians, and Turks, the Georgians retained a greater or lesser degree of independence for over 1,000 years. Thus after 1008, all Georgian principalities were united into the unified Kingdom of Georgia (1008-1466) under the Bagrationi dynasty.[PARAGRAPH:1]The struggle against the Seljuk invaders in Georgia was led by the young King David IV of the Bagrationi royal family, who inherited the throne in 1089 at the age of 16 after the abdication of his father George II Bagrationi. Soon after coming to power, David created the regular army and peasant militia in order to be able to resist Seljuk colonization of his country. The Crusaders' offensive against Seljuk Turks in Anatolia and Syria favored David's successful campaigns in Georgia. By the end of 1099 David had stopped paying tribute to the Seljuks and had liberated most of the Georgian lands. In 1103 he reorganized the Georgian Orthodox Church and closely linked it with the state. Between 1103 and 1122, David took over the lands of Ereti, Kartli and Tashiri, including Tbilisi, making it Georgia's capital.[PARAGRAPH:1]The reign of Queen Tamar represented the peak of Georgia's might. In 1194-1204 Tamar's armies crushed new Turkish invasions from the south-east and south and launched several successful campaigns into Turkish-controlled lands. As a result, most of Southern Armenia came under Georgian control.[PARAGRAPH:1]The temporary fall of the Byzantine Empire in 1204 to the Crusaders left Georgia as the strongest Christian state in the whole East Mediterranean area. The same year Queen Tamar sent her troops to take over the former Byzantine Lazona and Paryadria. In 1205, the occupied territory was transformed into the Empire of Trebizond and Tamar's relative Prince Alexios Komnenos was crowned as Emperor. The Empire of Trebizond was heavily dependent on Georgia for more than two hundred years. [PARAGRAPH:1]In the 13th century, the South Caucasus and Asia Minor faced the invasion of the Mongols. In spite of the fierce resistance on behalf of the united Georgian-Armenian forces, the whole area including most of Georgia, all Armenian lands and Central Anatolia fell to the Mongols. In 1386-1403 the diminished Kingdom of Georgia faced eight more Turco-Mongolic invasions under the leadership of Tamerlane that probably happened to be the most destructive cataclysm in the whole history of the nation. All over Georgia except Abkhazia and Svanetia, the cities and towns fell in ruins, tens of thousands were brutally slaughtered and even more enslaved and deported. Still, Georgia survived and turned into an isolated, fractured Christian enclave, a relic of the faded East Roman epoch surrounded by Muslim, predominantly Turco-Iranian-Arabic world.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Georgien hat eine der reichsten und ltesten Geschichten der Welt, die bis in die prhistorische Zeit zurckreicht. Der Aufstieg der frhen georgischen Staaten Kolchis und Iberia im Jahr 2000 v. Chr. formte die einzigartige georgische Zivilisation, die im 12. und 13. Jahrhundert ihre Renaissance und ihr goldenes Zeitalter erlebte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die erste vereinte georgische Monarchie wurde am Ende gegrndet im 10. Jahrhundert, als Kuropalat David in die Grafschaft Kartli-Iberien einfiel. Drei Jahre spter, nach dem Tod seines Onkels Theodosius dem Blinden, Knig von Egrisi-Abchasien, erbte Bagrat III. den abchasischen Thron. Im Jahr 1001 fgte Bagrat infolge von Davids Tod das Curopalatinate von Iberia zu seinem Herrschaftsbereich hinzu. In den Jahren 1008-1010 annektierte Bagrat Kachetien und Ereti und wurde so der erste Knig eines vereinten Georgiens.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die zweite Hlfte des 11. Jahrhunderts war geprgt von der verheerenden Invasion der seldschukischen Trken, die am Ende des In den 1040er Jahren war es gelungen, ein riesiges Nomadenreich aufzubauen, das den grten Teil Zentralasiens und Persiens umfasste. Im Jahr 1071 vernichtete die seldschukische Armee die vereinten byzantinisch-armenischen und georgischen Streitkrfte in der Schlacht von Manzikert. Bis 1081 waren ganz Armenien, Anatolien, Mesopotamien, Syrien und der grte Teil Georgiens von den Seldschuken erobert und verwstet worden. In Georgien blieben nur die Berggebiete Abchasiens, Swanetiens, Ratschas und Khevi-Chewsuretiens auerhalb der Kontrolle der Seldschuken und dienten zahlreichen Flchtlingen als relativ sichere Zufluchtsorte. [PARAGRAPH:1]Obwohl sie anschlieend von verschiedenen anderen Eindringlingen bedrngt wurden, hauptschlich Arabern, Mongolen, Persern und Trken, behielten die Georgier ber 1.000 Jahre lang einen mehr oder weniger groen Grad an Unabhngigkeit. So wurden nach 1008 alle georgischen Frstentmer unter der Bagrationi-Dynastie zum vereinten Knigreich Georgien (1008-1466) vereint.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der Kampf gegen die seldschukischen Invasoren in Georgien wurde vom jungen Knig David IV. vom Bagrationi-Knigshaus angefhrt Familie, die 1089 im Alter von 16 Jahren nach der Abdankung seines Vaters Georg II. Bagrationi den Thron erbte. Bald nach seiner Machtbernahme grndete David eine regulre Armee und eine Bauernmiliz, um der seldschukischen Kolonisierung seines Landes widerstehen zu knnen. Die Offensive der Kreuzfahrer gegen die seldschukischen Trken in Anatolien und Syrien begnstigte Davids erfolgreiche Feldzge in Georgien. Ende 1099 hatte David aufgehrt, den Seldschuken Tribut zu zahlen, und die meisten georgischen Lnder befreit. Im Jahr 1103 organisierte er die georgisch-orthodoxe Kirche neu und verband sie eng mit dem Staat. Zwischen 1103 und 1122 bernahm David die Lnder Ereti, Kartli und Tashiri, einschlielich Tiflis, und machte es zur Hauptstadt Georgiens.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Herrschaft von Knigin Tamar stellte den Hhepunkt der Macht Georgiens dar. In den Jahren 1194-1204 schlugen Tamars Armeen neue trkische Invasionen aus dem Sdosten und Sden nieder und starteten mehrere erfolgreiche Feldzge in trkisch kontrollierte Gebiete. Infolgedessen geriet der grte Teil Sdarmeniens unter georgische Kontrolle.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der vorbergehende Fall des Byzantinischen Reiches im Jahr 1204 an die Kreuzfahrer hinterlie Georgien als strksten christlichen Staat im gesamten stlichen Mittelmeerraum. Im selben Jahr schickte Knigin Tamar ihre Truppen, um das ehemalige byzantinische Lazona und Paryadria einzunehmen. Im Jahr 1205 wurde das besetzte Gebiet in das Reich von Trapezunt umgewandelt und Tamars Verwandter, Prinz Alexios Komnenos, zum Kaiser gekrnt. Das Reich von Trapezunt war mehr als zweihundert Jahre lang stark von Georgien abhngig. [PARAGRAPH:1]Im 13. Jahrhundert waren der Sdkaukasus und Kleinasien mit der Invasion der Mongolen konfrontiert. Trotz des erbitterten Widerstands der vereinten georgisch-armenischen Streitkrfte fiel das gesamte Gebiet, einschlielich des grten Teils Georgiens, aller armenischen Gebiete und Zentralanatoliens, an die Mongolen. In den Jahren 1386-1403 erlebte das geschwchte Knigreich Georgien unter der Fhrung von Tamerlan acht weitere trkisch-mongolische Invasionen, die wahrscheinlich die zerstrerischste Katastrophe in der gesamten Geschichte des Landes darstellten. In ganz Georgien, auer Abchasien und Swanetien, verfielen Stdte und Gemeinden, Zehntausende wurden brutal abgeschlachtet und noch mehr versklavt und deportiert. Dennoch berlebte Georgien und verwandelte sich in eine isolierte, zersplitterte christliche Enklave, ein Relikt der verblassten ostrmischen Epoche, umgeben von einer muslimischen, berwiegend trkisch-iranisch-arabischen Welt.

TEXT.English: [H1]Tamar Bagrationi[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Queen of Georgia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c. 1160 - 18 January 1213[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Tamar, of the Bagrationi dynasty, was Queen Regnant of Georgia from 1184 to 1213. The first woman to rule Georgia in her own right, Tamar presided over the "Golden age" of the medieval Georgian monarchy. Tamar was proclaimed heir apparent and co-ruler by her reigning father George III in 1178, but she faced significant opposition from the aristocracy upon her ascension to full ruling powers after George's death. Nevertheless, Tamar was successful in neutralizing this opposition and embarked on an energetic foreign policy aided by the downfall of the rival powers of the Seljuks and Byzantium. Supported by a powerful military lite, Tamar was able to build on the successes of her predecessors to consolidate an empire which dominated the Caucasus until its collapse under the Mongol attacks within two decades after Tamar's death. Tamar's association with this period of political and cultural revival, combined with her role as a female ruler, has led to her idealization and Romantization. She remains an important symbol in Georgian popular culture and has also been canonized by the Georgian Orthodox Church.

TEXT.German: [H1]Tamar Bagrationi[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Knigin von Georgien[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Gelebt:[\BOLD] c. 1160 - 18. Januar 1213[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Tamar aus der Bagrationi-Dynastie war von 1184 bis 1213 regierende Knigin von Georgien. Die erste Frau, die in ihr Georgien regierte Aus eigenem Recht prsidierte Tamar das "Goldene Zeitalter" der mittelalterlichen georgischen Monarchie. Tamar wurde 1178 von ihrem regierenden Vater Georg III. zur Thronfolgerin und Mitherrscherin ernannt, doch als sie nach Georgs Tod die volle Macht bernahm, stie sie auf erheblichen Widerstand seitens der Aristokratie. Dennoch gelang es Tamar, diese Opposition zu neutralisieren, und er begann eine energische Auenpolitik, die durch den Sturz der rivalisierenden Mchte der Seldschuken und Byzanz untersttzt wurde. Untersttzt von einer mchtigen Militrelite konnte Tamar auf den Erfolgen ihrer Vorgnger aufbauen und ein Reich konsolidieren, das den Kaukasus beherrschte, bis es zwei Jahrzehnte nach Tamars Tod unter den Angriffen der Mongolen zusammenbrach. Tamars Verbindung mit dieser Zeit des politischen und kulturellen Aufschwungs, kombiniert mit ihrer Rolle als weibliche Herrscherin, hat zu ihrer Idealisierung und Romantisierung gefhrt. Sie bleibt ein wichtiges Symbol in der georgischen Populrkultur und wurde auch von der georgisch-orthodoxen Kirche heiliggesprochen.

Nevertheless, Tamar was successful in neutralizing this opposition and embarked on an energetic foreign policy aided by the downfall of the rival powers of the Seljuks and Byzantium. Supported by a powerful military lite, Tamar was able to build on the successes of her predecessors to consolidate an empire which dominated the Caucasus until its collapse under the Mongol attacks within two decades after Tamar's death. Tamar's association with this period of political and cultural revival, combined with her role as a female ruler, has led to her idealization and Romantization. She remains an important symbol in Georgian popular culture and has also been canonized by the Georgian Orthodox Church.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Bahmani Sultanate (also called the Bahmanid Empire or Bahmani Kingdom) was a Muslim state of the Deccan in southern India and one of the great medieval Indian kingdoms. Bahmanid Sultanate was the first independent Islamic Kingdom in South India.[PARAGRAPH:1]The sultanate was founded on 3 August 1347 by governor Ala-ud-Din Hassan Bahman Shah, possibly of Tajik-Persian descent, who revolted against the Sultan of Delhi, Muhammad bin Tughluq. Nazir uddin Ismail Shah who had revolted against the Delhi sultanate stepped down on that day in favour of Zafar Khan who ascended the throne with the title of Alauddin Bahman Shah. His revolt was successful, and he established an independent state on the Deccan within the Delhi Sultanate's southern provinces. The Bahmani capital was Ahsenabad (Gulbarga) between 1347 and 1425 when it was moved to Muhammadabad (Bidar).[PARAGRAPH:1]The Bahmani contested the control of the Deccan with the Hindu Vijayanagara empire to the south. The sultanate reached the peak of its power during the vizierate (1466-1481) of Mahmud Gawan. After 1518 the sultanate broke up into five states: Ahmednagar, Berar, Bidar, Bijapur, and Golconda, known collectively as the Deccan sultanates.

TEXT.English: [H1]Ala ud-Din Hassan Bahman Shah[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan of the Bahmani Sultanate[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 3 August 1347 - 1358[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Abu'l Muzaffar Ala-ud-Din Bahman Shah, born Hasan Gangu, was the founder of the Bahmani sultanate. Hasan Gangu was possibly descended from the Persian king Bahman, so of Isfandiyar, but other sources point to Afghan ancestry and association with the Brahmin caste. Hasan began his career as a general serving under the Delhi Sultan Muhammad bin Tughluq. On 3 August 1347 Nasir-ud-Din Ismail Shah (whom rebel amirs of the Deccan placed on the throne of Daulatabad in 1345) abdicated in his favour and he set up the Bahmani Kingdom with its headquarters at Ahsenabad (Gulbarga). On establishing an independent kingdom Gangu took the title of Abu'l-Muzaffar Ala-ud-din Bahman Shah. [PARAGRAPH:1]Bahman Shah led his first campaign against Warangal in 1350 and forced its ruler Kapaya Nayaka to cede to him the fortress of Kaulas. His kingdom was divided into four provinces and he appointed a governor for each province. During his reign Hasan fought many wars with Vijayanagara. By the time of his death the kingdom streched from north to south from the Wainganga River to Krishna and east to west from Bhongir to Daulatabad.[PARAGRAPH:1]He was succeeded by his son Muhammad Shah I after his death in 1358.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Buyid dynasty, also known as the Buyid Empire or the Buyids, also known as Buwaihids, Buyahids, or Buyyids, were a Shia Persian dynasty that originated from Daylaman in Gilan. They founded a confederation that controlled most of modern-day Iran and Iraq in the 10th and 11th centuries.[PARAGRAPH:1]The founders of the Buyid confederation were Ali ibn Buyah and his two younger brothers, al-Hassan and Ahmad. Originally a soldier in the service of the Ziyarids of Tabaristan, Ali was able to recruit an army to defeat a Turkish general from Baghdad named Yaqut in 934. Over the next nine years the three brothers gained control of the remainder of the Abbasid Caliphate. While they accepted the titular authority of the caliph in Baghdad, the Buyid rulers assumed effective control of the state.[PARAGRAPH:1]The first several decades of the Buyid confederation were characterized by large territorial gains. In addition to Fars and Jibal, which were conquered in the 930s, and central Iraq, which submitted in 945, the Buyids took Kerman (967), Oman (967), the Jazira (979), Tabaristan (980), and Gurgan (981). After this, however, the Buyids went into a slow decline, with pieces of the confederation gradually breaking off and local dynasties under their rule becoming de facto independent.[PARAGRAPH:1]The approximate century of Buyid rule, coupled with the rise of other Iranian dynasties in the region, represents a period in Iranian history sometimes called the 'Iranian Intermezzo' since it was an interlude between the rule of the Abbasid Arabs and the Seljuk Turks. Indeed, as Dailamite Iranians the Buyids consciously revived symbols and practices of Persia's Sassanid dynasty. In fact, beginning with Adud al-Daula they used the ancient Sassanid title Shahanshah, literally king of kings.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Buyid army consisted of their fellow Dailamite Iranians, who served as foot soldiers, and of the Turkish cavalry that had played a prominent role in the Abbasid military. The Dailamites and Turks often quarreled with each other in an attempt to be the dominant force within the army. To compensate their soldiers the Buyid amirs often distributed iqta's, or the rights to a percentage of tax revenues from a province, although the practice of payment in kind was also frequently used.[PARAGRAPH:1]Like most Daylamites at the time, the Buyids were originally Zaydi or Fiver Shi'as. After taking power in Iran and Iraq, however, they began to lean closer to Twelver Shi'ism, possibly due to political considerations. In fact, the Buyids rarely attempted to enforce a particular religious view upon their subjects except when in matters where it would be politically expedient. The Sunni Abbasids retained the caliphate, although they were deprived of all secular power. In addition, in order to prevent tensions between the Shi'a and Sunni from spreading to government agencies, the Buyid amirs occasionally appointed Christians to high offices instead of Muslims from either sect.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the mid-11th century, the Buyid amirates gradually fell to the Ghaznavid and Seljuk Turks. In 1055, Tughrul conquered Baghdad, the seat of the caliphate, and ousted the last of the Buyid rulers. Like the Buyids, the Seljuks kept the Abbasid caliphate as the titular ruler.

Die Dailamiten und Trken stritten oft miteinander, um die dominierende Kraft innerhalb der Armee zu werden. Um ihre Soldaten zu entschdigen, verteilten die Buyiden-Emirs oft Iqta, also das Recht auf einen Prozentsatz der Steuereinnahmen einer Provinz, obwohl auch die Praxis der Bezahlung in Form von Sachleistungen hufig angewandt wurde.[PARAGRAPH:1]Wie die meisten Daylamiten zu dieser Zeit waren die Buyiden waren ursprnglich Zaydi oder Fiver Schiiten. Nach der Machtbernahme im Iran und im Irak begannen sie jedoch, sich mglicherweise aus politischen Erwgungen dem Zwlf-Schiismus anzunhern. Tatschlich versuchten die Buyiden selten, ihren Untertanen eine bestimmte religise Sichtweise aufzuzwingen, auer in Angelegenheiten, in denen dies politisch sinnvoll wre. Die sunnitischen Abbasiden behielten das Kalifat, obwohl ihnen jegliche weltliche Macht entzogen wurde. Um auerdem zu verhindern, dass sich die Spannungen zwischen Schiiten und Sunniten auf Regierungsbehrden ausbreiten, beriefen die Buyid-Emire gelegentlich Christen in hohe mter anstelle von Muslimen einer der beiden Sekten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Whrend der Mitte des 11. Jahrhunderts wurden die Die Buyid-Amirate fielen nach und nach an die Ghaznawiden- und Seldschuken-Trken. Im Jahr 1055 eroberte Tughrul Bagdad, den Sitz des Kalifats, und verdrngte den letzten Buyid-Herrscher. Wie die Buyiden behielten die Seldschuken das abbasidische Kalifat als Titelherrscher.

To compensate their soldiers the Buyid amirs often distributed iqta's, or the rights to a percentage of tax revenues from a province, although the practice of payment in kind was also frequently used.[PARAGRAPH:1]Like most Daylamites at the time, the Buyids were originally Zaydi or Fiver Shi'as. TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Buyid dynasty, also known as the Buyid Empire or the Buyids, also known as Buwaihids, Buyahids, or Buyyids, were a Shia Persian dynasty that originated from Daylaman in Gilan. They founded a confederation that controlled most of modern-day Iran and Iraq in the 10th and 11th centuries.[PARAGRAPH:1]The founders of the Buyid confederation were Ali ibn Buyah and his two younger brothers, al-Hassan and Ahmad. Originally a soldier in the service of the Ziyarids of Tabaristan, Ali was able to recruit an army to defeat a Turkish general from Baghdad named Yaqut in 934. Over the next nine years the three brothers gained control of the remainder of the Abbasid Caliphate. While they accepted the titular authority of the caliph in Baghdad, the Buyid rulers assumed effective control of the state.[PARAGRAPH:1]The first several decades of the Buyid confederation were characterized by large territorial gains. In addition to Fars and Jibal, which were conquered in the 930s, and central Iraq, which submitted in 945, the Buyids took Kerman (967), Oman (967), the Jazira (979), Tabaristan (980), and Gurgan (981). After this, however, the Buyids went into a slow decline, with pieces of the confederation gradually breaking off and local dynasties under their rule becoming de facto independent.[PARAGRAPH:1]The approximate century of Buyid rule, coupled with the rise of other Iranian dynasties in the region, represents a period in Iranian history sometimes called the 'Iranian Intermezzo' since it was an interlude between the rule of the Abbasid Arabs and the Seljuk Turks. Indeed, as Dailamite Iranians the Buyids consciously revived symbols and practices of Persia's Sassanid dynasty. In fact, beginning with Adud al-Daula they used the ancient Sassanid title Shahanshah, literally king of kings.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Buyid army consisted of their fellow Dailamite Iranians, who served as foot soldiers, and of the Turkish cavalry that had played a prominent role in the Abbasid military. The Dailamites and Turks often quarreled with each other in an attempt to be the dominant force within the army. To compensate their soldiers the Buyid amirs often distributed iqta's, or the rights to a percentage of tax revenues from a province, although the practice of payment in kind was also frequently used.[PARAGRAPH:1]Like most Daylamites at the time, the Buyids were originally Zaydi or Fiver Shi'as. After taking power in Iran and Iraq, however, they began to lean closer to Twelver Shi'ism, possibly due to political considerations. In fact, the Buyids rarely attempted to enforce a particular religious view upon their subjects except when in matters where it would be politically expedient. The Sunni Abbasids retained the caliphate, although they were deprived of all secular power. In addition, in order to prevent tensions between the Shi'a and Sunni from spreading to government agencies, the Buyid amirs occasionally appointed Christians to high offices instead of Muslims from either sect.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the mid-11th century, the Buyid amirates gradually fell to the Ghaznavid and Seljuk Turks. In 1055, Tughrul conquered Baghdad, the seat of the caliphate, and ousted the last of the Buyid rulers. Like the Buyids, the Seljuks kept the Abbasid caliphate as the titular ruler.

TEXT.English: [H1]Adud al-Dawla[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Buyid Emir, Shahanshah[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] September 24, 936 - March 26, 983[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Adud al-Dawla was an emir of the Buyid dynasty in Iran and Iraq. He is widely regarded as the greatest emir of the dynasty.[PARAGRAPH:1]The son of Rukn al-Daula, Fana Khusrau was given the title of 'Adud al-Daula by the Abbasid caliph in 948 when he was made emir of Fars after the death of his childless uncle 'Imad al-Daula, after which Rukn al-Daula became the senior emir of the Buwayhids. In 974 'Adud al-Daula was sent by his father to crush a rebellion by his cousin 'Izz al-Daula. After defeating his cousin's forces, he claimed the emirate of Iraq for himself, angering his father, though he would become the senior emir after the death of his father.[PARAGRAPH:1]'Adud al-Dawla became emir of Iraq while the capital of Baghdad was suffering from violence and instability owing to sectarian conflict. In order to bring peace and stability to the city, he ordered the banning of public demonstrations and polemics. At the same time, he patronized a number of Shi'a scholars such as al-Mufid, and he sponsored the renovation of a number of important Shi'a shrines.[PARAGRAPH:1]In addition, 'Adud al-Daula is credited with sponsoring and patronizing other scientific projects during his time. An observatory was built by his orders in Isfahan where Azophi worked. al-Muqaddasi also reports of a great dam built under his orders between Shiraz, Iran and Istakhr in 960 CE. The dam irrigated some 300 villages in Fars province and became known as Band-i Amir. Among his other major constructions was the digging of the Haffar channel, that joined the Karun River to the Arvand Rud / Shatt al-Arab river (the confluence of Tigris and Euphrates). The port of Khorramshahr is built on the Haffar, at its joining point with the Arvand Rud/Shatt al-Arab.

Er gilt weithin als der grte Emir der Dynastie.[PARAGRAPH:1]Fana Khusrau, der Sohn von Rukn al-Daula, erhielt 948 vom abbasidischen Kalifen den Titel "Adud al-Daula", als er zum Emir von Fars ernannt wurde nach dem Tod seines kinderlosen Onkels Imad al-Daula, woraufhin Rukn al-Daula der Oberemir der Buwayhiden wurde. Im Jahr 974 wurde 'Adud al-Daula von seinem Vater geschickt, um einen Aufstand seines Cousins 'Izz al-Daula niederzuschlagen. Nachdem er die Streitkrfte seines Cousins besiegt hatte, beanspruchte er das Emirat Irak fr sich, was seinen Vater verrgerte, obwohl er nach dem Tod seines Vaters der ranghchste Emir werden sollte. [PARAGRAPH:1]'Adud al-Dawla wurde Emir des Irak als Hauptstadt Bagdad litt aufgrund konfessioneller Konflikte unter Gewalt und Instabilitt. Um Frieden und Stabilitt in die Stadt zu bringen, ordnete er das Verbot ffentlicher Demonstrationen und Polemiken an. Gleichzeitig frderte er eine Reihe schiitischer Gelehrter wie al-Mufid und frderte die Renovierung einer Reihe wichtiger schiitischer Schreine.[PARAGRAPH:1]Auerdem wird 'Adud al-Daula genannt whrend seiner Zeit sponserte und frderte er andere wissenschaftliche Projekte. Auf seinen Befehl wurde in Isfahan, wo Azophi arbeitete, ein Observatorium gebaut. al-Muqaddasi berichtet auch von einem groen Staudamm, der 960 n. Chr. auf seinen Befehl zwischen Shiraz, Iran und Istakhr gebaut wurde. Der Damm bewsserte rund 300 Drfer in der Provinz Fars und wurde als Band-i Amir bekannt. Zu seinen weiteren groen Bauwerken gehrte der Graben des Haffar-Kanals, der den Karun-Fluss mit dem Arvand Rud/Shatt al-Arab-Fluss (dem Zusammenfluss von Tigris und Euphrat) verband. Der Hafen von Khorramshahr liegt am Haffar, an seinem Verbindungspunkt mit dem Arvand Rud/Shatt al-Arab.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Bulgars originally came from Central Asia, 'somewhere east of the Black Sea,' near modern day Kazakhstan and were occasional allies of the Huns. They began sporadic service with the Byzantines asmercenaries in the late 5th cent., and by the time of Emperor Justinian I were actually administering some towns in the Empire, defending them against other Bulgars and nomadic tribes from the east. The Bulgars had a falling outwith the Empire, retreated to the steppes, and were next heard from when they joined the Gepids and Lombards in invading Italy. Around 600 AD, the Bulgars had returned and conquered the Slavic area of the Balkans controlled bythe Byzantines. The Byzantine Empire recognized the first Bulgarian Empire in 681 AD, and this nation lasted until 1081 AD.[PARAGRAPH:2]Even though the Bulgars ruled this area with an iron fist, they ended up assimilating much of the Slavic language and culture and eventually would mingle so much with their subjects that eventually it was impossible to determine who was Bulgar and who was Slav. This interbreeding with their Slavic subjects did not dull their ferocity however, and during the Middle Ages Bulgaria was a great military power. The Bulgars fought many wars against the Byzantine Empire, their other neighbors, and nomadic invaders. By 865 AD, Czar Boris I had converted to Christianity and established an independent Bulgarian branch of the Eastern Orthodox church and adopted the Cyrillic alphabet as the official state language, and this alphabet and church spread from Bulgaria to the rest of eastern Europe and then into Russia. Boris' son, Czar Simeon I (893-927 AD) was one of Bulgaria's greatest rulers and during his reign, Bulgaria flourished as a center of Slavic culture and learning. As befitted his warrior heritage, Simeon also conquered many new territories and at his death, Bulgaria stretched from the Black Sea to the Adriatic. After Simeon's death, Bulgaria waned in power, eventually being conquered by the Byzantines. After almost two hundred years of rule by the Byzantines, there followed a two hundred year second Bulgarian Empire that was, in turn, conquered by the Ottoman Empire.

Ende des fnften Jahrhunderts fingen sie vereinzelt an, Byzanz als Sldner zu dienen, und zur Zeit Kaiser Justinians I. verwalteten sie sogar einige Stdte im Reich, die sie gegen andere Bulgaren und nomadische Stmme aus dem Osten verteidigten. Die Bulgaren hatten einen Fall auerhalb des Reichs, zogen sich in die Steppe zurck und wurden zum nchsten Mal gehrt, als sie zusammen mit den Gepiden und den Lombarden in Italien einfielen. Um 600 n. Chr. kehrten die Bulgaren um und eroberten das slawische Gebiet des Balkans, das von Byzanz kontrolliert wurde. Das Byzantinische Reich erkannte das Erste Bulgarische Reich 681 n. Chr. an und diese Nation dauerte bis 1081 an.[PARAGRAPH:2]Obwohl die Bulgaren dieses Gebiet mit eiserner Faust regierten, nahmen sie letztendlich viel von der slawischen Sprache und Kultur an und vermischten sich derart mit den Slawen, dass es unmglich war, zu unterscheiden, wer Bulgare und wer Slawe war. Diese Vermischung mit dem slawischen Volk stumpfte ihre Wildheit jedoch nicht ab und whrend des Mittelalters war Bulgarien eine groe militrische Macht. Die Bulgaren kmpften mehrfach gegen das Byzantinische Reich, ihre anderen Nachbarn und nomadische Eindringlinge. 865 konvertierte Zar Boris I. zum Christentum und etablierte einen unabhngigen bulgarischen Ableger der stlich-Orthodoxen Kirche und bernahm das Kyrillische Alphabet in die offizielle Amtssprache. Dieses Alphabet und diese Kirche breitete sich von Bulgarien zum Rest Osteuropas und dann nach Russland aus. Boris' Sohn, Zar Simeon I. (893-927) war einer von Bulgariens grten Herrschern und whrend seiner Herrschaft blhte Bulgarien als ein Zentrum slawischer Kultur und Bildung auf. Geziemend seinem kriegerischen Erbe, eroberte Simeon auch viele Gebiete und zu seinem Tod erstreckte sich Bulgarien vom Schwarzen Meer bis zur Adria. Nach Simeons Tod nahm Bulgariens Macht ab und wurde letztendlich von den Byzantinern erobert. Nach fast 200 Jahren der byzantinischen Herrschaft folgte 200 Jahre lang ein Zweites Bulgarisches Reich, das wiederum vom Osmanischen Reich erobert wurde.
