TEXT.English: [H1]Simeon I[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Tsar of Bulgaria[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c. 864 - May 27, 927 AD[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Simeon was born in 864 as the third son of Knyaz Boris I. Simeon was born to a Christianized Bulgaria due to his father's reign. In his early years, Simeon learned the Greek language and received a theological education in Constantinople. Although Simeon's brother Vladimir was the designated heir of Boris, he was deposed after attempting to reintroduce paganism to Bulgaria and Simeon became king.[PARAGRAPH:2]Under the Byzantine Emperor Leo VI, the Bulgarian marketplace was moved from Constantinople to Thessaloniki, where the Bulgarian merchants were heavily taxed. The merchants then required protection from Simeon, who invaded the Byzantine Empire in 894. However, the Bulgarian army was required back in the country after a Magyar invasion from the north. Later, the Magyars were convinced by the Byzantines to attack Bulgaria. Simeon, being unaware of this agreement, met another force of Byzantines from Italy. After agreeing to peace with the Byzantine commander, Simeon blocked off the Byzantine navy's route into the Danube. Simeon, after hearing of the Magyar attack, moved to confront them. The Magyars defeated Bulgaria and later pillaged its land, and Simeon agreed to peace with Byzantium in 895.[PARAGRAPH:2]Now that the Byzantine threat was abolished, Simeon planned a campaign against the Magyars. Simeon defeated the Magyars and expanded Bulgarian territory. Simeon then defeated a Byzantine army after a dispute about Bulgarian prisoners in Thrace. The war ended and Byzantium was required to pay an annual tribute and cede lands to Bulgaria. However, Simeon often violated these treaties, conquering and attacking Byzantine territory on several occasions.[PARAGRAPH:2]Leo VI's death paved the way for another Bulgarian invasion of Byzantium. Simeon was recognized as Emperor of the Bulgarians after negotiations with the Byzantines. In 917, the Byzantines planned a campaign against eh Bulgarians. In the Battle of Anchialos, one of the largest medieval battles in history, Simeon defeated the Byzantines. In order to cease Serbian unrest, Simeon removed the current Serbian ruler and replaced him with another, ensuring Bulgarian influence over Serbia.[PARAGRAPH:2]After another government change in Constantinople, Simeon declared war on Byzantium to further assert his power. He captured several Byzantine cities and requested the help of the Arabs. However, the Arabs accepted peace with the Byzantines, thus ruining their alliance with Bulgaria. Simeon was forced to establish peace with Byzantium after the threat of a Serbian uprising, where he deposed the Serbian ruler. In 926, Simeon's troops invaded Croatia, but were defeated by the army of King Tomislav. In the last years of his life, Simeon prepared for another siege of Constantinople. On May 27, 927, Simeon died of heart failure in his palace in Preslav and was succeeded by his son Peter I.
TEXT.French: [H1]Siméon Ier[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Tsar de Bulgarie[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates:[\BOLD] 864 - 927 ap. J.C.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biographie:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Simeon a t soutenu dans 864 en tant que troisime fils de Knyaz Boris I. Simeon a t soutenu en Bulgarie christianise due au rgne de son pre. En ses premires annes, Simeon a appris la langue grecque et a reu une ducation thologique Constantinople. Bien que le frre Vladimir de Simeon ait t l'hritier indiqu de Boris, il a t dpos aprs avoir essay de rintroduire le paganisme en Bulgarie et Simeon est all bien au roi.[PARAGRAPH:2]Sous le Lion bizantin d'empereur VI, le march bulgare a t dplac de Constantinople Thessaloniki, o les ngociants bulgares ont t fortement imposs. Les ngociants ont alors eu besoin de la protection contre Simeon, qui a envahi l'empire bizantin dans 894. Cependant, l'arme bulgare a t prie en arrire dans le pays aprs une invasion magyare du nord. Plus tard, les Magyars ont t convaincus par le Byzantines d'attaquer la Bulgarie. Simeon, tant ignorant de cet accord, a rencontr une autre force de Byzantines d'Italie. Aprs avoir t d'accord sur la paix avec le commandant bizantin, Simeon bloqu outre de l'itinraire de la marine bizantine dans le Danube. Simeon, aprs avoir entendu parler de l'attaque magyare, s'est dplac pour les confronter. Par Magyars la Bulgarie dfaite Simeon et plus tard pill sa terre, et tait d'accord sur la paix avec Byzance dans 895.[PARAGRAPH:2]Maintenant que la menace bizantine a t supprime, Simeon a projet une campagne contre les Magyars. Simeon a dfait les Magyars et a augment le territoire bulgare. Simeon a alors dfait une arme bizantine aprs un conflit au sujet des prisonniers bulgares dans Thrace. La guerre finie et Byzance ont t exiges pour payer un hommage annuel et pour cder des terres en Bulgarie. Cependant, Simeon a souvent viol ces traits, conqurant et attaquant le territoire bizantin plusieurs occasions.[PARAGRAPH:2]Le Lion la mort de VI a prpar le terrain pour une autre invasion bulgare de Byzance. Simeon a t identifi comme empereur des Bulgares aprs des ngociations avec le Byzantines. Dans 917, le bizantin a projet une campagne contre hein des Bulgares. Dans la bataille d'Anchialos, une des plus grandes batailles mdivales dans l'histoire, Simeon a dfait le Byzantines. Afin de cesser le malaise serbe, Simeon a enlev la rgle serbe courante et l'a remplac avec des autres, assurant l'influence bulgare au-dessus de la Serbie.[PARAGRAPH:2]Aprs qu'un autre changement de gouvernement Constantinople, Simeon ait dclar la guerre sur Byzance affirmer plus loin sa puissance. Il a captur plusieurs villes bizantines et a demand l'aide des Arabes. Cependant, les Arabes ont accept la paix avec le Byzantines, de ce fait ruinant leur alliance avec la Bulgarie. Simeon a t forc d'tablir la paix avec Byzance aprs la menace d'un soulvement serbe, o il a dpos le gouverneur serbe. Dans 926, les troupes de Simeon envahissent la Croatie, mais ont t dfaites par l'arme du Roi Tomislav. En dernires annes de sa vie, Simeon s'est prpar un autre sige de Constantinople. Le 27 mai 927, Simeon mort de l'arrt du coeur dans son palais dans Preslav et a t russi par son fils Peter I.
TEXT.German: [H1]Simeon I.[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Zar von Bulgarien[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 864 - 927 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Simeon wurde in 864 als der dritte Sohn von Knyaz Boris I. getragen. Simeon wurde zu einem Christianized Bulgarien wegen der Herrschaft seines Vaters getragen. In seinen frhen Jahren erlernte Simeon die griechische Sprache und empfing eine theological Ausbildung in Konstantinopolise. Obgleich Bruder Vladimir Simeons der gekennzeichnete Erbe von Boris war, wurde er abgesetzt, nachdem man versucht hatte, Heidentum nach Bulgarien wieder einzufhren und Simeon stand Knig.[PARAGRAPH:2]Unter dem byzantinischen Kaiser-Lwen wurde VI, der bulgarische Markt von Konstantinopolise auf Thessaloniki verschoben, in dem die bulgarischen Kaufleute schwer besteuert wurden. Die Kaufleute bentigten dann Schutz vor Simeon, das das byzantinische Reich in 894 eindrang. Jedoch wurde die bulgarische Armee zurck im Land nach einer Magyarinvasion vom Norden angefordert. Spter wurden die Magyars durch das Byzantines berzeugt, Bulgarien in Angriff zu nehmen. Simeon, seiend ahnungslos von dieser Vereinbarung, traf eine andere Kraft von Byzantines aus Italien. Nachdem dem Zustimmen Frieden mit dem byzantinischen Kommandanten, Simeon blockiert weg vom byzantinischen Weg der Marine in die Donau. Simeon, nachdem er von den Magyarangriff gehrt hatte, bewog, um sie zu konfrontieren. Das Magyars besiegte Bulgarien und spter geplndert seinem Land und Simeon stimmte Frieden mit Byzanz in 895 zu.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nun da die byzantinische Drohung abgeschafft wurde, plante Simeon eine Kampagne gegen die Magyars. Simeon besiegte die Magyars und erweiterte bulgarische Gegend. Simeon besiegte dann eine byzantinische Armee nach einer Debatte ber bulgarische Gefangene in Thrace. Der beendete Krieg und Byzanz wurden angefordert, einen jhrlichen Tribut zu zahlen und Lnder nach Bulgarien zu berlassen. Jedoch verletzte Simeon hufig diese Vertrge und eroberte und nimmt byzantinische Gegend bei einigen Gelegenheiten in Angriff.[PARAGRAPH:2]Lwe der Tod VI pflasterte die Weise fr eine andere bulgarische Invasion von Byzanz. Simeon wurde als Kaiser der Bulgaren nach Vermittlungen mit dem Byzantines erkannt. In 917 plante das byzantinische eine Kampagne gegen wie Bulgaren. In der Schlacht von Anchialos, besiegte eine der grten mittelalterlichen Schlachten in der Geschichte, Simeon das Byzantines. Um serbische Ruhelosigkeit aufzuhren, entfernte Simeon die gegenwrtige serbische Lehre und ersetzte ihn mit anderen und stellte bulgarischen Einflu ber Serbien sicher.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nachdem eine andere Regierung nderung in Konstantinopolise, Simeon Krieg auf Byzanz erklrte, seine Energie weiter zu erklren. Er nahm einige byzantinische Stdte gefangen und bat um die Hilfe der Araber. Jedoch nahmen die Araber Frieden mit dem Byzantines an und so ruinierten ihr Bndnis mit Bulgarien. Simeon wurde gezwungen, Frieden mit Byzanz nach der Drohung eines serbischen Aufstiegs herzustellen, in dem er die serbische Lehre absetzte. In 926 dringen Truppen Simeons Kroatien ein, aber wurden von der Armee des Knigs Tomislav besiegt. In den letzten Jahren seines Lebens, bereitete sich Simeon fr eine andere Belagerung von Konstantinopolise vor. Am 27. Mai 927 wurde Simeon, das am Herzausfall in seinem Palast in Preslav gestorben wurde und von seinem Sohn Peter I. gefolgt.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Simeone I[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Zar di Bulgaria[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vita:[\BOLD] 864 - 927 d.C.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Informazioni:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Simeon stato sopportato in 864 come il terzo figlio di Knyaz Boris I. Simeon stato sopportato ad un Christianized Bulgaria dovuto il regno del suo padre. Durante i suoi primi anni, Simeon ha imparato la lingua greca ed ha ricevuto una formazione theological a Constantinople. Anche se il fratello Vladimir del Simeon era l'erede indicato di Boris, deposed dopo avere tentato di rintrodurre il paganism in Bulgaria e Simeon ha stato bene al re.[PARAGRAPH:2]Sotto il Leo Byzantine dell'imperatore VI, il mercato bulgaro stato spostato da Constantinople verso Thessaloniki, dove i commercianti bulgari sono stati tassati pesante. I commercianti allora hanno richiesto la protezione da Simeon, che ha invaso l'impero Byzantine in 894. Tuttavia, l'esercito bulgaro stato richiesto indietro nel paese dopo un'invasione del Magyar dal nord. Pi successivamente, i Magyars sono stati convinti dal Byzantines attacare la Bulgaria. Simeon, essendo ignaro di questo accordo, ha venuto a contatto di un'altra forza di Byzantines dall'Italia. Dopo avere accosentitoe alla pace con il comandante Byzantine, Simeon ostruito fuori dell'itinerario del blu marino Byzantine nel Danubio. Simeon, dopo avere sentito parlare l'attacco del Magyar, si mosso per confrontarlo. I Magyars hanno sconfitto la Bulgaria e pi successivamente hanno saccheggiato la relativa terra e Simeon ha accosentito a pace con Byzantium in 895.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ora che la minaccia Byzantine si abolita, Simeon ha progettato una campagna contro i Magyars. Simeon ha sconfitto i Magyars ed ha espanso il territorio bulgaro. Simeon allora ha sconfitto un esercito Byzantine dopo una disputa circa i prigionieri bulgari in Thrace. La guerra conclusa e Byzantium sono stati richiesti rendere tributo annuale e cedere le terre in Bulgaria. Tuttavia, Simeon ha violato spesso questi trattati, conquistanti ed attacanti il territorio Byzantine in parecchie occasioni.[PARAGRAPH:2]Il Leo morte del VI ha aperto la strada per un'altra invasione bulgara di Byzantium. Simeon stato riconosciuto come imperatore dei bulgari dopo le trattative con il Byzantines. In 917, il Byzantine ha progettato una campagna contro eh i bulgari. Nella battaglia di Anchialos, una di pi grandi battaglie medioevali nella storia, Simeon ha sconfitto il Byzantines. Per cessare l'agitazione di Serbian, Simeon ha rimosso il righello corrente di Serbian e lo ha sostituito con un altro, accertando l'influenza bulgara sopra la Serbia.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dopo che un altro cambiamento di governo a Constantinople, Simeon dichiari la guerra con Byzantium pi ulteriormente di asserire la sua alimentazione. Ha bloccato parecchie citt Byzantine ed ha chiesto l'aiuto degli arabi. Tuttavia, gli arabi hanno accettato la pace con il Byzantines, cos rovinando la loro alleanza con la Bulgaria. Simeon stato costretto a stabilire la pace con Byzantium dopo la minaccia di una rivolta di Serbian, in cui deposed il righello di Serbian. In 926, le truppe del Simeon invadono il Croatia, ma sono state sconfitte dall'esercito del re Tomislav. Durante gli anni scorsi della sua vita, Simeon si preparato per un altro siege di Constantinople. Il 27 maggio 927, Simeon morto di guasto di cuore nel suo palazzo in Preslav ed stato riuscito dal suo figlio Peter I.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Simeón I[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Zar de Bulgaria[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] 864 - 927 d. C.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Historia:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Simeon fue llevado en 864 como el tercer hijo de Knyaz Boris I. Simeon fue llevado a un Christianized Bulgaria debido al reinado de su padre. En sus aos, Simeon aprendi la lengua griega y recibi una educacin teolgica en Constantinople. Aunque el hermano Vladimir de Simeon era el heredero sealado de Boris, lo depusieron despus de procurar reintroducir paganism a Bulgaria y Simeon sinti bien al rey.[PARAGRAPH:2]Debajo del Leo Byzantine del emperador VI, el mercado blgaro fue movido desde Constantinople a Thessaloniki, donde gravaron a los comerciantes blgaros pesadamente. Los comerciantes entonces requirieron la proteccin contra Simeon, que invadi el imperio Byzantine en 894. Sin embargo, requirieron al ejrcito blgaro detrs en el pas despus de una invasin del Magyar del norte. Ms adelante, se convenci a los Magyars por el Byzantines que atacaran Bulgaria. Simeon, siendo inconsciente de este acuerdo, resolvi otra fuerza de Byzantines de Italia. Despus de convenir la paz con el comandante Byzantine, Simeon bloqueado de la ruta de la marina de guerra Byzantine en el Danubio. Simeon, despus de or hablar del ataque del Magyar, se movi para enfrentarlos. Los Magyars la Bulgaria derrotada Simeon y ms adelante pillado su tierra, y convino la paz con Byzantium en 895.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ahora que la amenaza Byzantine fue suprimida, Simeon plane una campaa contra los Magyars. Simeon derrot a Magyars y ampli el territorio blgaro. Simeon entonces derrot a ejrcito Byzantine despus de un conflicto sobre presos blgaros en Thrace. La guerra terminada y Byzantium fueron requeridos pagar un tributo anual y ceder tierras a Bulgaria. Sin embargo, Simeon viol a menudo estos tratados, conquistando y atacando el territorio Byzantine en varias ocasiones.[PARAGRAPH:2]El Leo la muerte de VI paviment la manera para otra invasin blgara de Byzantium. Simeon fue reconocido como emperador de los blgaros despus de negociaciones con el Byzantines. En 917, el Byzantine plane una campaa contra eh blgaros. En la batalla de Anchialos, una de las batallas medievales ms grandes de la historia, Simeon derrot el Byzantines. Para cesar malestar servio, Simeon quit la regla servia actual y lo substituy por otro, asegurando influencia blgara sobre Serbia.[PARAGRAPH:2]Despus de que otro cambio del gobierno en Constantinople, Simeon declarara guerra en Byzantium afirmar ms lejos su energa. l captur varias ciudades Byzantine y solicit la ayuda de los rabes. Sin embargo, los rabes aceptaron paz con el Byzantines, as arruinando su alianza con Bulgaria. Simeon fue forzado establecer paz con Byzantium despus de la amenaza de una sublevacin servia, donde l depuso la regla servia. En 926, las tropas de Simeon invaden el Croatia, pero fueron derrotadas por el ejrcito de rey Tomislav. En los aos pasados de su vida, Simeon se prepar para otro sitio de Constantinople. El 27 de mayo de 927, Simeon muerto de paro cardaco en su palacio en Preslav y fue tenido xito por su hijo Peter I.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Serbs in the Byzantine world lived in the so-called Slav lands, lands initially out of Byzantine control and independent. The Vlastimirovic dynasty established the Serbian Principality in the 7th century. In 822, Frankish annalists recorded that for the Serbs "is said to be holding the large part of Dalmatia. Christianization of Serbs, initiated in the 7th century, was a gradual process, finalized by the middle of the 9th century. In the mid-10th century, Serbian state stretched between the shores of the Adriatic Sea, the Neretva, the Sava, the Morava, and Skadar. Ethnic identity of local populations remains a matter of historiographical disputes.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 924, the Serbs ambushed and defeated a small Bulgarian army, provoking a major retaliatory campaign that ended with Bulgaria's annexation of Serbia at the end of that year. Threatened by an alliance between the Byzantines and the Serbian state of Duklja, in 997 the Bulgarian tsar Samuel defeated and captured its Prince Jovan Vladimir and took control of the Serb lands again. The state disintegrated after the death of the last known Vlastimirid ruler; the Byzantines annexed the region and held it for a century, until 1040 when the Serbs under the leadership of what would become the Vojislavljevic dynasty revolted in Duklja, a maritime region. In 1091, the Vukanovic dynasty established the Serbian Grand Principality, based in Raska (Latin: Rascia).[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1166, Stefan Nemanja assumed the throne, marking the beginning of a prospering Serbia, henceforth under the rule of the Nemanjic dynasty. Nemanja's son Rastko (posth. Saint Sava), gained autocephaly for the Serbian Church in 1219 and authored the oldest known constitution, and at the same time Stefan the First-Crowned established the Serbian Kingdom in 1217. Medieval Serbia reached its peak during the reign of Stefan Dusan (1331-1355), who took advantage of the Byzantine civil war and doubled the size of the state by conquering territories to the south and east at the expense of Byzantium, reaching as far as the Peloponnese, also being crowned Emperor of Serbs and Greeks in 1346.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Battle of Kosovo against the rising Ottoman Empire in 1389 marks a turning point and is considered as a beginning of the fall of the medieval Serbian state. The magnate families Lazarevic and Brankovic ruled the suzerain Serbian Despotate afterwards (in the 15th and 16th centuries). After the fall of Constantinople to the Ottomans in 1453 and the Siege of Belgrade, the Serbian Despotate fell in 1459 following the siege of the provisional capital of Smederevo. By 1455, central Serbia was completely conquered by the Ottoman Empire. After repelling Ottoman attacks for over 70 years, Belgrade finally fell in 1521, opening the way for Ottoman expansion into Central Europe. Dlvidk (today Vojvodina), which was inhabited by Serbs and Hungarians, resisted Ottoman rule until well into the 16th century.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Serben in der byzantinischen Welt lebten in den sogenannten slawischen Lndern, Lndern, die ursprnglich auerhalb der byzantinischen Kontrolle lagen und unabhngig waren. Die Vlastimirovic-Dynastie grndete im 7. Jahrhundert das serbische Frstentum. Im Jahr 822 berichteten frnkische Annalisten, dass die Serben "einen groen Teil Dalmatiens innehaben" sollen. Die Christianisierung der Serben begann im 7. Jahrhundert und war ein schrittweiser Prozess, der Mitte des 9. Jahrhunderts abgeschlossen wurde. Im 10. Jahrhundert erstreckte sich der serbische Staat zwischen den Ksten der Adria, der Neretva, der Save, der Morava und der Skadar. Die ethnische Identitt der lokalen Bevlkerung ist nach wie vor Gegenstand historiographischer Streitigkeiten.[PARAGRAPH:2]Im Jahr 924 berfielen die Serben und besiegte eine kleine bulgarische Armee und provozierte einen groen Vergeltungsfeldzug, der Ende des Jahres mit der Annexion Serbiens durch Bulgarien endete. Bedroht durch ein Bndnis zwischen den Byzantinern und dem serbischen Staat Duklja besiegte der bulgarische Zar Samuel 997 seinen Frsten und nahm ihn gefangen Jovan Wladimir und bernahm erneut die Kontrolle ber die serbischen Lnder. Der Staat zerfiel nach dem Tod des letzten bekannten vlastimiridischen Herrschers; die Byzantiner annektierten die Region und hielten sie ein Jahrhundert lang, bis 1040 die Serben unter der Fhrung der spteren Vojislavljevic kamen Dynastie revoltierte in Duklja, einer Kstenregion. Im Jahr 1091 grndete die Vukanovic-Dynastie das serbische Grofrstentum mit Sitz in Raska (lateinisch: Rascia).[PARAGRAPH:2]Im Jahr 1166 bestieg Stefan Nemanja den Thron und markierte den Beginn eines prosperierenden Serbiens, das fortan unter der Herrschaft der Nemanjic stand Dynastie. Nemanjas Sohn Rastko (posth. Heiliger Sava) erlangte 1219 die Autokephalie fr die serbische Kirche und verfasste die lteste bekannte Verfassung. Gleichzeitig grndete Stefan der Erstgekrnte 1217 das serbische Knigreich. Whrend der Herrschaft erreichte das mittelalterliche Serbien seinen Hhepunkt von Stefan Dusan (1331-1355), der den byzantinischen Brgerkrieg ausnutzte und die Gre des Staates verdoppelte, indem er auf Kosten von Byzanz Gebiete im Sden und Osten eroberte, die bis zur Peloponnes reichten, und ebenfalls zum Kaiser gekrnt wurde Serben und Griechen im Jahr 1346.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die Schlacht im Kosovo gegen das aufstrebende Osmanische Reich im Jahr 1389 markiert einen Wendepunkt und gilt als Beginn des Untergangs des mittelalterlichen serbischen Staates. Die Magnatenfamilien Lazarevic und Brankovic regierten danach (im 15. und 16. Jahrhundert) das serbische Despotat. Nach der Eroberung Konstantinopels durch die Osmanen im Jahr 1453 und der Belagerung von Belgrad fiel das serbische Despotat 1459 nach der Belagerung der provisorischen Hauptstadt Smederevo. Im Jahr 1455 wurde Zentralserbien vollstndig vom Osmanischen Reich erobert. Nachdem Belgrad ber 70 Jahre lang osmanische Angriffe abgewehrt hatte, fiel es schlielich 1521 und ebnete den Weg fr die osmanische Expansion nach Mitteleuropa. Dlvidk (heute Vojvodina), das von Serben und Ungarn bewohnt war, widersetzte sich bis weit ins 16. Jahrhundert der osmanischen Herrschaft.

Medieval Serbia reached its peak during the reign of Stefan Dusan (1331-1355), who took advantage of the Byzantine civil war and doubled the size of the state by conquering territories to the south and east at the expense of Byzantium, reaching as far as the Peloponnese, also being crowned Emperor of Serbs and Greeks in 1346.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Battle of Kosovo against the rising Ottoman Empire in 1389 marks a turning point and is considered as a beginning of the fall of the medieval Serbian state. The magnate families Lazarevic and Brankovic ruled the suzerain Serbian Despotate afterwards (in the 15th and 16th centuries). After the fall of Constantinople to the Ottomans in 1453 and the Siege of Belgrade, the Serbian Despotate fell in 1459 following the siege of the provisional capital of Smederevo. By 1455, central Serbia was completely conquered by the Ottoman Empire. After repelling Ottoman attacks for over 70 years, Belgrade finally fell in 1521, opening the way for Ottoman expansion into Central Europe. Dlvidk (today Vojvodina), which was inhabited by Serbs and Hungarians, resisted Ottoman rule until well into the 16th century.

TEXT.English: [H1]Stefan Uros IV Dusan the Mighty[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emperor of the Serbs and Greeks[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1308 - December 20, 1355[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Dusan conquered a large part of southeast Europe, becoming one of the most powerful monarchs of the era. Under Dusan's rule, Serbia was the most powerful state in Southeast Europe, one of the most powerful European states and an Eastern Orthodox multi-ethnic and multilingual empire that stretched from the Danube in the north to the Gulf of Corinth in the south, with its capital in Skopje. He enacted the constitution of the Serbian Empire, known as Dusan's Code, perhaps the most important literary work of medieval Serbia. Dusan promoted the Serbian Church from an archbishopric to a patriarchate, finished the construction of the Visoki Decani Monastery (now a UNESCO site), and founded the monastery of the Holy Archangels, among others. Under his rule, Serbia reached its territorial, political, economic, and cultural peak.[PARAGRAPH:2]After Dusan's sudden death in 1355, the empire began to weaken. With the death of Dusan's successor, emperor Stefan Uros V, the Serbian Empire was definitively divided into a large number of independent Serbian states, among which the Serbian Despotate will stand out as the most prominent under the rule of Lazarevic dynasty.

TEXT.German: [H1]Stefan Uros IV Dusan der Mchtige[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Kaiser der Serben und Griechen[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Gelebt:[\BOLD] 1308 - 20. Dezember 1355[PARAGRAPH: 2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Dusan eroberte einen groen Teil Sdosteuropas und wurde einer der mchtigsten Monarchen seiner Zeit. Unter Dusans Herrschaft war Serbien der mchtigste Staat in Sdosteuropa, einer der mchtigsten europischen Staaten und ein ostorthodoxes multiethnisches und mehrsprachiges Reich, das sich von der Donau im Norden bis zum Golf von Korinth im Sden erstreckte Hauptstadt in Skopje. Er erlie die Verfassung des Serbischen Reiches, bekannt als Dusans Kodex, das vielleicht wichtigste literarische Werk des mittelalterlichen Serbien. Dusan machte die serbische Kirche von einem Erzbistum zu einem Patriarchat, vollendete den Bau des Klosters Visoki Decani (heute UNESCO-Weltkulturerbe) und grndete unter anderem das Kloster der Heiligen Erzengel. Unter seiner Herrschaft erreichte Serbien seinen territorialen, politischen, wirtschaftlichen und kulturellen Hhepunkt.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nach Dusans pltzlichem Tod im Jahr 1355 begann das Reich zu schwchen. Mit dem Tod von Dusans Nachfolger, Kaiser Stefan Uros V., wurde das serbische Reich endgltig in eine groe Anzahl unabhngiger serbischer Staaten aufgeteilt, von denen das serbische Despotat unter der Herrschaft der Lazarevic-Dynastie der prominenteste sein wird.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The term "barbarian" was created by the Greeks; it was originally used to denote any foreigner. Since then it has gained a more negative connotation, and it is commonly applied to civilizations deemed "inferior" to one's own. The Chinese, for instance, thought of all foreign cultures - everybody from the Manchus to the Turks to the Europeans - as barbarians. Rome applied it to the Huns and the Germanic tribes, as well as to the more advanced Gauls.[PARAGRAPH:1]In Civilization IV, the term denotes people that are not part of any organized civilization appearing in the game, but are instead old-style hunter-gatherers who prey on the "weak" civilized world. Though some barbarians may have acquired fairly advanced weaponry - swords and axes, for example - and though they may occasionally capture or even build their own cities, they remain at heart brigandic nomads, destroying everything that comes in their path. Barbarians cannot be bargained with or appeased: they must be destroyed - before they destroy you!
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le terme "Barbare" est à l'origine un critère linguistique utilisé par les Grecs pour désigner toute personne étrangère à la civilisation grecque. Depuis, ce terme a pris une connotation péjorative et s'applique aux civilisations jugées "inférieures". Les Chinois, par exemple, considéraient toutes les cultures étrangères, des Mandchous aux Turcs en passant par les Européens, comme des barbares. Rome utilisait ce terme pour désigner les Huns, les Gaulois et les tribus germaniques.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dans Civilization IV, le terme "Barbares" désigne des gens qui ne font partie d'aucune civilisation organisée du jeu. Il s'agit de chasseurs-cueilleurs qui n'ont pas peur de s'attaquer au monde civilisé. Bien que certains barbares aient pu acquérir un armement assez avancé, avec notamment des épées et des haches, et bien qu'ils puissent à l'occasion capturer ou même fonder leurs propres villes, ils restent avant tout des "bandits-nomades", détruisant tout sur leur passage. Il est impossible de négocier avec des barbares ni même de les apaiser : il faut les éliminer avant qu'ils ne vous éliminent !
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Begriff "Barbar" kommt aus dem Griechischen und bezeichnete in seiner ursprünglichen Bedeutung alle Nichtgriechen. Seither haftete dem Wort allerdings eine immer negativere Assoziation an und heute wird es im Allgemeinen als Bezeichnung für primitivere, "unterlegenere" Zivilisationen verwendet. Die Chinesen betrachteten beispielsweise alle fremden Kulturen - wirklich alle, von den Manchus über die Türken bis hin zu den Europäern - als Barbaren. Rom benutzte den Begriff für die Hunnen und die germanischen Stämme sowie für die immerhin etwas fortschrittlicheren Gallier.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Civilization IV sind mit den "Barbaren" Völker gemeint, die keiner der organisierten Zivilisationen im Spiel angehören, sondern eher in die Kategorie "Jäger und Sammler" eingeordnet werden können und die "schwache" zivilisierte Welt mit Überfällen heimsuchen. Zwar gibt es vereinzelt Barbaren, die über relativ fortschrittliche Waffen verfügen - zum Beispiel Schwerter und Äxte - und sie können auch gelegentlich Städte erobern oder sogar eigene Städte gründen, dennoch bleiben sie im Herzen stets räuberische Nomaden, die alles zerstören, was sich ihnen in den Weg stellt. Barbaren lassen sich nicht beschwichtigen und auch nicht mit sich handeln - deshalb sollten sie möglichst schnell vernichtet werden, bevor sie eine ernsthafte Bedrohung darstellen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Il termine "barbaro" venne coniato dai Greci e inizialmente veniva utilizzato per indicare qualsiasi straniero. Da allora, la parola ha assunto una connotazione negativa e viene associato a quelle civiltà definite "inferiori". I Cinesi, per esempio, identificavano tutte le culture straniere come "barbare" dai Manciù ai Turchi agli Europei. Roma bollò con questo termine gli Unni e le popolazioni germaniche, così come i Galli che erano culturalmente evoluti.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Civilization IV, questo termine indica le popolazioni che non fanno parte di una civiltà organizzata, vecchi cacciatori che predano i "deboli" nel mondo. Malgrado alcuni barbari abbiano conquistato armamenti più evoluti come spade e asce, e talvolta possano conquistare o fondare delle città, i Barbari rimangono prevalentemente nomadi che distruggono e saccheggiano tutto ciò che capita a tiro. Non si può trattare con i Barbari: devono essere distrutti prima che loro distruggano te!
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El término "bárbaro" fue acuñado por los griegos, y originalmente se utilizaba para referirse a cualquier extranjero. Pero desde entonces ha adquirido unas connotaciones negativas, pues suele emplearse al hablar de las civilizaciones a las que se considera "inferiores" a la propia. Los chinos, por ejemplo, pensaban que todas las culturas extranjeras (desde los manchúes a los turcos, pasando por los europeos) eran bárbaras. En Roma se empleaba el término para referirse a los hunos y las tribus germanas, así como a los galos, que eran más avanzados.[PARAGRAPH:2]En Civilization IV, este término engloba a todos los pueblos que no forman parte de ninguna civilización organizada del juego, y en lugar de eso se componen de cazadores-recolectores que atacan al "débil" mundo civilizado. Aunque algunos bárbaros pueden llegar a adquirir armas bastante avanzadas (espadas y hachas, por ejemplo), y aunque de vez en cuando pueden capturar ciudades o construir las suyas propias, en el fondo siguen siendo unos nómadas bandidos que lo destruyen todo a su paso. No se puede negociar con ellos, ni es posible aplacarlos: ¡hay que destruirlos antes de que ellos te destruyan a ti!

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Mongol tribes entered into history with the birth of Temujin, born in c.1167 AD in the wild steppe-land of Mongolia, which is bordered by modern China and Russia. When Temujin was nine years old, tribal rivals poisoned and murdered his father Yesugei, creating a power vacuum in the tribe that resulted in the exile of young Temujin and his family as fugitives. In time Temujin would return to claim his inheritance, forge political alliances, and vanquish old rivals. In 1204 AD he summoned a kuriltai war council and proceeded to unite all local nomad tribes by force, becoming the first man ever to unite the Mongols. It was at this time he received the title 'Genghis Khan', meaning 'Great Ruler'. [PARAGRAPH:2]China, at the time, was divided into three parts: the Ch'in, who were the most powerful, reigned in the north at Beijing; the Sung occupied the South; and the Hsi-Hsia, the weakest of the 3, inhabited the western flank of the Great Wall. The Mongol conquest against China began in 1211 when the consolidated tribes of the Great Khan struck at the Hsi-Hsia, with tremendous success. Not impressed with the defeat of his weaker neighbor, the new Emperor of Ch'in insisted on a public display of servitude from Temujin. Temujin reacted by ordering a general advance against the Ch'in Empire. The resulting war lasted for approximately 23 years, and ended in the complete destruction of the Ch'in. Although the Mongols began the war as nomadic horsemen, by the time they defeated the Ch'in they had learned how to use advanced siege weaponry to capture cities. During this campaign Temujin ensured that the epic war upon the Ch'in did not occupy all of his resources and time; there were older enemies to address. [PARAGRAPH:2]Amid the war against the Ch'in the Mongols also rallied against the Kara-Khitay, one of the original Kuchlug tribes that had fled from defeat during Temujin's war of unification. Victory over the Kara-Khitay provided the Mongols a common frontier with the Shah of Khwarizm, who ruled a large Muslim state that stretched from modern day Iran to southern Russia as far as the Caspian and Aral Seas. Temujin initially attempted to establish friendly relations with the Shah Ala-al-Din, but he was contemptuously rebuffed, and the Mongol emissary killed. That was a mistake. In 1219 a Mongol horde estimated at 100,000 horsemen invaded Khwarizm and the other cities that lay along the rich Silk Way. Due to their stubborn resistance, the cities of Khwarizm were destroyed, their populations slaughtered or enslaved, and the area almost completely depopulated. Ala-al-Din fled in exile and died shortly thereafter. In many respects, this area today still has not recovered from the Mongol invasion.[PARAGRAPH:2]After destroying Khwarizm, the Mongols had access to Russia. Not content with remaining a peaceful neighbor, Temujin's successor Ogodai permitted his generals to lead an extraordinary campaign into southern Russia, which would be staged largely in the winter months. In a series of campaigns between 1237-40, the Mongols completely subjected the various principalities of Russia, destroying anyone who opposed them. From Russia, the Mongols continued their western advance by invading Poland, Silesia, and Hungary. They easily defeated the armies of Poland, Germany, and Hungary, and appeared poised to erupt into Western Europe. But the death of Ogodai, the great khan, caused the armies to retreat in order to seek new orders, thus sparing most of Europe from destruction. Less fortunate was the Muslim world, as Baghdad was sacked in 1258 by yet another Mongol army and the Caliph executed by being trampeled to death beneath Mongol horses. The destruction of Baghdad and slaughtering of its population was a blow that the Arab Empire of the Caliphs never fully recovered from. The Mongols were finally turned back for the first time by the Mameluks of Egypt in 1260.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mongol children were taught to ride on horseback from the age of three, and were given bow and arrows to use for hunting at the age of five. Horseback riding became a natural way for the Mongols to conduct war. When speed was essential, a Mongol rider could even sleep while in the saddle; and by using a system that consisted of approximately four remounts, Temujin's army was capable of traversing 130 miles in two days, with no breaks for food. Another defining characteristic of a Mongolian army was the speed and voracity with which it was able to accept and prepare for battle. The Mongols' harsh, nomadic lifestyle had prepared them well for the rigors of war; and they often thrived in conditions that would be considered intolerable by any other military of its time. When the need arose they could last up to ten days at a time without cooking food, during which they would sustain themselves by drinking the blood of their horses. Their primary weapon consisted of horse archers called Keshiks, who could fire with great speed and incredible accuracy from the back of a saddle. The mobility of the Mongol forces gave them a great tactical advantage within battles that Mongol generals would exploit over and over again.[PARAGRAPH:2]Every victory wrought by the Mongols was followed by slaughters of incredible scale. No citizens, with the exception of those who were useful to the Mongol war effort, were spared in these attacks. In 1221, the Islamic city of Merv was captured; 700,000 were murdered (this number is almost certainly exaggerated but still amazing), and a rearguard was assembled to dispatch any citizens who were fortunate enough to have escaped the original slaughter - this was routine work for the Mongol army. It is said that Temujin planned to depopulate northern China for use as a pasture for his livestock, until being told that subjects would pay more in taxes than cattle.[PARAGRAPH:2]By the end of the 13th century Mongol armies had been involved in action in countries including: Poland, Japan, Korea, Hungary, Russia, Palestine, Egypt, Persia, India, China, Cambodia, Burma, Vietnam, and Indonesia. After Temujin's death in 1227 five more Khans would follow, including Kublai Khan, whose triumph was the union of all of China under his rule. However, the death of Kublai Khan in 1294 AD marked the end of an era for Mongol conquests, and the march of Mongol armies began to decline. While many of the khanates founded by the Mongols lasted for several more centuries, the age of the great nomadic forces was over. Although their era was brief in duration, the Mongols conquered the largest empire the world has ever seen and terrorized virtually the entire Eurasian continent.

The Mongols were finally turned back for the first time by the Mameluks of Egypt in 1260.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mongol children were taught to ride on horseback from the age of three, and were given bow and arrows to use for hunting at the age of five. Horseback riding became a natural way for the Mongols to conduct war. When speed was essential, a Mongol rider could even sleep while in the saddle; and by using a system that consisted of approximately four remounts, Temujin's army was capable of traversing 130 miles in two days, with no breaks for food. Another defining characteristic of a Mongolian army was the speed and voracity with which it was able to accept and prepare for battle. The Mongols' harsh, nomadic lifestyle had prepared them well for the rigors of war; and they often thrived in conditions that would be considered intolerable by any other military of its time. When the need arose they could last up to ten days at a time without cooking food, during which they would sustain themselves by drinking the blood of their horses. Their primary weapon consisted of horse archers called Keshiks, who could fire with great speed and incredible accuracy from the back of a saddle. The mobility of the Mongol forces gave them a great tactical advantage within battles that Mongol generals would exploit over and over again.[PARAGRAPH:2]Every victory wrought by the Mongols was followed by slaughters of incredible scale. No citizens, with the exception of those who were useful to the Mongol war effort, were spared in these attacks. In 1221, the Islamic city of Merv was captured; 700,000 were murdered (this number is almost certainly exaggerated but still amazing), and a rearguard was assembled to dispatch any citizens who were fortunate enough to have escaped the original slaughter - this was routine work for the Mongol army. It is said that Temujin planned to depopulate northern China for use as a pasture for his livestock, until being told that subjects would pay more in taxes than cattle.[PARAGRAPH:2]By the end of the 13th century Mongol armies had been involved in action in countries including: Poland, Japan, Korea, Hungary, Russia, Palestine, Egypt, Persia, India, China, Cambodia, Burma, Vietnam, and Indonesia. After Temujin's death in 1227 five more Khans would follow, including Kublai Khan, whose triumph was the union of all of China under his rule. However, the death of Kublai Khan in 1294 AD marked the end of an era for Mongol conquests, and the march of Mongol armies began to decline. While many of the khanates founded by the Mongols lasted for several more centuries, the age of the great nomadic forces was over. Although their era was brief in duration, the Mongols conquered the largest empire the world has ever seen and terrorized virtually the entire Eurasian continent.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]The Mongol tribes entered into history with the birth of Temujin, born in c.1167 AD in the wild steppe-land of Mongolia, which is bordered by modern China and Russia. It was at this time he received the title 'Genghis Khan', meaning 'Great Ruler'. [PARAGRAPH:2]China, at the time, was divided into three parts: the Ch'in, who were the most powerful, reigned in the north at Beijing; the Sung occupied the South; and the Hsi-Hsia, the weakest of the 3, inhabited the western flank of the Great Wall. The Mongol conquest against China began in 1211 when the consolidated tribes of the Great Khan struck at the Hsi-Hsia, with tremendous success. Not impressed with the defeat of his weaker neighbor, the new Emperor of Ch'in insisted on a public display of servitude from Temujin. Temujin reacted by ordering a general advance against the Ch'in Empire. The resulting war lasted for approximately 23 years, and ended in the complete destruction of the Ch'in. Although the Mongols began the war as nomadic horsemen, by the time they defeated the Ch'in they had learned how to use advanced siege weaponry to capture cities. During this campaign Temujin ensured that the epic war upon the Ch'in did not occupy all of his resources and time; there were older enemies to address. [PARAGRAPH:2]Amid the war against the Ch'in the Mongols also rallied against the Kara-Khitay, one of the original Kuchlug tribes that had fled from defeat during Temujin's war of unification. Temujin initially attempted to establish friendly relations with the Shah Ala-al-Din, but he was contemptuously rebuffed, and the Mongol emissary killed. That was a mistake. In 1219 a Mongol horde estimated at 100,000 horsemen invaded Khwarizm and the other cities that lay along the rich Silk Way. Due to their stubborn resistance, the cities of Khwarizm were destroyed, their populations slaughtered or enslaved, and the area almost completely depopulated. From Russia, the Mongols continued their western advance by invading Poland, Silesia, and Hungary. The mobility of the Mongol forces gave them a great tactical advantage within battles that Mongol generals would exploit over and over again.[PARAGRAPH:2]Every victory wrought by the Mongols was followed by slaughters of incredible scale. No citizens, with the exception of those who were useful to the Mongol war effort, were spared in these attacks. In 1221, the Islamic city of Merv was captured; 700,000 were murdered (this number is almost certainly exaggerated but still amazing), and a rearguard was assembled to dispatch any citizens who were fortunate enough to have escaped the original slaughter - this was routine work for the Mongol army. It is said that Temujin planned to depopulate northern China for use as a pasture for his livestock, until being told that subjects would pay more in taxes than cattle.[PARAGRAPH:2]By the end of the 13th century Mongol armies had been involved in action in countries including: Poland, Japan, Korea, Hungary, Russia, Palestine, Egypt, Persia, India, China, Cambodia, Burma, Vietnam, and Indonesia. TEXT.English: [H1]Genghis Khan [\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Khan of the Mongol Empire [\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD] 1152/1167 - 1227[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]The Khan who founded the world's largest empire was given the name Temujin at birth. At his death, Temujin's empire encompassed over 13.8 million square miles and 100 million people, about half of the world's entire population. [PARAGRAPH:1]Temujin was born into a family of the minor Mongol nobility. His father was murdered when he was nine, leaving his mother to teach Temujin how to ride a horse, shoot a bow, and tend the animals. She also taught her son that allies were crucial to one's survival, and Temujin took this lesson to heart. By the time Temujin had reached his late teens, he had gathered to him a group of very loyal vassals, with whom he shared the spoils of his wars. He also became blood brothers with men from the leading Mongol families. However, Temujin was first and foremost a pragmatist; he would remain friends with these leaders as long as it suited him and he would discard or betray them at need. [PARAGRAPH:1]Temujin grew in power and prominence, and he was eventually accepted as leader of all of the Mongols. He reorganized the military, promoting men of competence rather than men of good breeding. This gave him the unwavering backing of the common soldiers and the officers. After defeating his last internal foe, Temujin was named "Genghis Kahn," meaning either "Oceanic Ruler" (or possibly "Fierce Ruler"). After fully securing his position at home, Kahn began his extraordinary series of conquests across Asia and Europe. [PARAGRAPH:1]Genghis Khan was far more interested in victory than he was in glory in battle. Before attacking a city or country, Genghis Khan sent the local rulers "orders of submission," in which he demanded immediate surrender. If the rulers did so, they were allowed to continue governing as long as they provided him tribute in money and labor. If the rulers did not surrender, they could expect little mercy once defeated. [PARAGRAPH:1]As a political leader, Genghis Kahn adopted a policy of religious tolerance, which eased tensions with the local priests. He recruited foreigners to serve as officers in his army and in his government, allowing them to rise to prominence according to their abilities, thus giving the ablest men reason to support him rather than to plot against him. He issued a set of laws for his conquered lands, which among other things punished horse theft with death and imposed severe punishment on disobedient soldiers. He also allowed full trade with Europe, and for the first time it was possible for European merchants to travel all the way to China in (relative) safety. [PARAGRAPH:1]As a military leader, Genghis Khan was exceptional. He maintained tight discipline among his troops, punishing them severely for infractions. He developed a sophisticated intelligence network across Asia, and he used the intelligence to craft clever military campaigns that fully exploited his enemy's weaknesses. Genghis Khan's troops were extraordinary, as well. The Mongols were superb light cavalrymen, and their ability to shoot arrows from the saddle was unbelievable. At first his armies were ignorant of the arts of siege warfare, but as more and more armies refused to meet his forces in the open field; his men grew skilled with catapults and the other tools for fighting men behind walls. [PARAGRAPH:1]Genghis Khan's first campaigns were against the Tanguts, who controlled the lucrative trade routes between the East and West. After subduing them, he conquered other foes in Central Asia and Northern China. No one could stand against him. During his last and most extraordinary campaign, he set out with 200,000 warriors and captured Bukhara, Samarkand, Balkh, Nishapur and Herat in succession. After remaining in Central Asia for four years, Genghis Khan headed back home, only to die en route. [PARAGRAPH:1]Something more than a barbarian and something less than an enlightened ruler, Genghis Khan remains one of the most extraordinary warrior-kings of all time.
TEXT.French: [H1]Gengis Khan [\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Khan de l'Empire mongol [\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates : [\BOLD] 1152/1167 - 1227[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biographie :[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Le khan qui fonde le plus vaste empire du monde s'appelait Temüdjin à la naissance. A sa mort, son empire couvre plus de 35,8 millions de kilomètres carrés et comprend 100 millions d'habitants, soit près de la moitié de la population mondiale. [PARAGRAPH:1] Temüdjin naît dans une famille de la petite noblesse mongole. Son père est assassiné alors qu'il n'a que neuf ans, obligeant sa mère à lui apprendre comment monter un cheval, bander un arc et garder les animaux. Elle lui enseigne également que les alliés sont essentiels à sa survie et Temüdjin prend cette leçon très à coeur. A la fin de son adolescence, il peut compter sur un groupe de vassaux extrêmement loyaux avec qui il partage ses butins de guerre. Il devient par ailleurs frère de sang avec les hommes d'autres grandes familles mongoles mais il reste pragmatique : il restera ami avec ces chefs tant que cela lui conviendra mais il s'en débarrassera ou les trahira si besoin est. [PARAGRAPH:1]Temüdjin renforce son pouvoir et sa renommée et finit par se faire accepter comme chef de tous les Mongols. Il réorganise l'armée, promouvant les hommes en fonction de leurs compétences et non de leur origine sociale, ce qui lui vaut le fidèle soutien des simples soldats et des officiers. Une fois son dernier ennemi personnel éliminé, Temüdjin se fait proclamer "Gengis Kahn", ce qui signifie soit le "Souverain océanique", soit le "Chef suprême". Après avoir assuré ses positions dans son pays, Khan entreprend d'extraordinaires conquêtes en Asie et en Europe. [PARAGRAPH:1]Sur le champ de bataille, Gengis Khan donne plus d'importance à la victoire qu'à la bataille. Avant d'attaquer une ville ou un pays, il envoie aux chefs locaux des "ordres de soumission" dans lesquels il a coutume de demander la capitulation immédiate. S'ils acceptent, ils sont autorisés à continuer à gouverner tant qu'ils lui fournissent un tribut en monnaie ou en travail. Dans le cas contraire, ils doivent s'attendre à peu de clémence après leur défaite. [PARAGRAPH:1]Comme chef politique, Gengis Kahn adopte une politique de tolérance religieuse qui réduit les tensions avec les prêtres locaux. Il recrute des étrangers qui servent comme officiers dans son armée et son gouvernement et leur offre de gravir les échelons selon leurs mérites, donnant ainsi plus de raisons à ces hommes talentueux de le soutenir. Il proclame plusieurs lois destinées aux territoires conquis qui punissent notamment de mort le vol de chevaux et impose de sévères punitions aux soldats désobéissants. Il autorise également, sans aucune restriction, le commerce avec l'Europe et, pour la première fois, il est possible aux marchands européens de voyager jusqu'en Chine en (relative) sécurité. [PARAGRAPH:1]Comme chef militaire, Gengis Khan est exceptionnel. Il maintient une discipline stricte au sein de ses troupes, les punissant sévèrement pour toute infraction. Il développe un réseau sophistiqué de renseignements dans toute l'Asie et utilise ce service pour préparer d'habiles campagnes militaires qui exploitent parfaitement les faiblesses de l'ennemi. Les troupes de Gengis Khan sont toutes aussi exceptionnelles. Les Mongols forment une remarquable cavalerie légère et leur capacité à tirer des flèches en selle est impressionnante. A l'origine, les armées de Gengis Khan ignorent tout de l'art de la guerre de siège mais face au refus de leurs ennemis pour les affrontements à découvert, ses hommes se dotent de catapultes et autres outils qui permettent de combattre des hommes abrités par des murs. [PARAGRAPH:1]Les premières campagnes de Gengis Khan l'opposent aux Tangoutes, qui contrôlent les lucratives routes commerciales entre l'Orient et l'Occident. Après les avoir soumis, il combat d'autres ennemis en Asie centrale et en Chine du Nord. Aucun peuple ne lui résiste. Au cours de sa dernière et extraordinaire campagne, il part avec 200 000 guerriers et s'empare successivement de Boukhara, Samarcande, Balkh, Nichapur et Herat. Après être resté quatre ans en Asie centrale, Gengis Khan se décide à rentrer mais il meurt en route. [PARAGRAPH:1]Plus qu'un barbare et moins qu'un souverain éclairé, Gengis Khan reste l'un des plus extraordinaires rois-combattants de tous les temps.
TEXT.German: [H1]Dschinghis Khan [\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Khan des Mongolenreichs [\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte: [\BOLD] 1152 oder 1167-1227[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Dschingis Khan, oder Temudschin, war ein Khan der Mongolen, der die turko-mongolischen Stämme vereinte und weite Teile Zentralasiens und Nordchinas kontrollierte. Als er starb, umfasste sein Reich mehr als 35 Millionen Quadratkilometer Land mit 100 Millionen Menschen ... mehr als die Hälfte der Weltbevölkerung. [PARAGRAPH:1]Temudschin stammte aus einer hoch angesehenen Familie und wurde als ältester Sohn des Clanchefs Yesügai Bahadur geboren. Nach der Ermordung seines Vaters lebte der erst 9-jährige Temudschin mit seiner Mutter und seinen Geschwistern in bitterer Armut. Angeblich hat Temudschins Mutter den sich ständig streitenden Brüdern mit einem Gleichnis die Bedeutung von Stärke durch Einigkeit verdeutlicht. Sie forderte die Jungen zunächst auf, einen Pfeil zu zerbrechen. Anschließend band sie mehrere Pfeile zusammen und befahl ihren Kindern, diese ebenfalls zu zerbrechen. Da dies nicht gelang, war die Belehrung seiner Mutter für den späteren Großkhan ein prägendes Erlebnis. Dank seines dipolmatischen Geschicks fand er einige treue Gefolgsleute, denen er als Anreiz für ihre Treue reiche Beute auf zukünftigen Feldzügen zusicherte. Allerdings war und blieb Temudschin ein Pragmatiker, der wusste, dass er sich nicht blind auf die Loyalität seiner Gefolgsleute und Blutsbrüder verlassen durfte. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nachdem er die Steppenstämme vereint und seine gefährlichsten Gegner unterworfen hatte, führte er einen blutigen Feldzug gegen die Mörder seines Vaters: die Tataren. Im Jahr 1206 berief Temudschin einen Reichstag (Kuriltai) ein. Dort wurde er von den anwesenden Schamanen und Stammesfürsten zum Dschingis Khan, dem Großkhan aller Mongolen erhoben und bekam damit als erster Khan den Titel "ungestümer Herrscher" (oder "ozeangleicher Herrscher"). Nachdem er seine Macht gefestigt hatte, begann Temudschin einen nie da gewesenen Eroberungsfeldzug quer durch Asien und Europa. [PARAGRAPH:1]Temudschin ging es allein um den Sieg. Bevor er eine Stadt oder ein Land attackierte, schickte er dem Herrscher den "Befehl zur Unterwerfung" und forderte dessen Kapitulation. Folgte der Herrscher diesem Befehl, blieb er im Amt, musste den Mongolen jedoch Tribut zollen. Weigerte er sich, löschten die Mongolen nicht selten ganze Städte aus. [PARAGRAPH:1]Dschinghis Khan vertrat eine Politik der religiösen Toleranz, um die Spannungen zwischen ihm und den örtlichen Priestern beizulegen. Er rekrutierte Fremde als Offiziere und berief sie in seine Regierung, um sie an sich zu binden und die Gefahr eines Aufstandes zu verringern. In den von ihm eroberten Ländern rief er Gesetze ins Leben, die beispielsweise Pferdediebstahl mit dem Tode bestraften und drakonische Strafen für militärischen Ungehorsam vorsahen. Ferner förderte er den Handel mit Europa. Europäische Händler konnten nun erstmals (relativ) sicher bis nach China reisen. [PARAGRAPH:1]Dschinghis Khan war ein brillanter Kommandeur, der seine Soldaten mit harter Hand disziplinierte. Dank eines ausgeklügelten Spionagenetzwerks in ganz Asien war er in der Lage, die Schwächen seiner Feinde zu erkennen und zu nutzen. Dies ermöglichte ihm die Kontrolle seiner perfekt ausgebildeten Soldaten, die wie keine andere Kavallerie der damaligen Zeit in der Lage waren, vom Rücken ihrer Pferde zu kämpfen. Anfangs waren Temudschins Armeen keine Belagerungsheere. Als jedoch immer mehr Gegner eine offene Schlacht mit den Mongolen scheuten, setzten diese vermehrt Katapulte und andere Belagerunfswaffen ein.[PARAGRAPH:1]Temudschins erste Kriegszüge richteten sich gegen die Tanguten, die die lukrativen Handelsrouten zwischen dem Osten und dem Westen kontrollierten. Nach ihrer Unterwerfung eroberte er weite Teile Zentralasiens und Nordchinas. Niemand konnte sich ihm widersetzen. Im Laufe seines letzten Feldzugs eroberte er mit 20.000 Kriegern Bukhara, Samarkand, Balkh, Nishapur und Herat. 1227 starb Dschingis Khan während eines neuerlichen Feldzugs gegen die Tanguten. [PARAGRAPH:1]Dschinghis Khan war weder ein Barbar, noch ein aufgeklärter Herrscher. Man könnte ihn allerdings als den außergewöhnlichsten Feldherren aller Zeiten bezeichnen.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Genghis Khan [\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Khan dell'impero mongolo [\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vissuto nel: [\BOLD] 1152/1167 - 1227[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Al Khan che fondò l'impero più grande del mondo, fu dato il nome di Temujin. Alla sua morte, l'impero di Temujin contava quasi 14 milioni di miglia quadrate di territorio e 100 milioni di abitanti, circa la metà della popolazione mondiale dell'epoca.[PARAGRAPH:1]Temujin nacque in una famiglia della nobiltà minore mongola: suo padre venne assassinato quando aveva soltanto nove anni, lasciando alla madre il compito di addestrarlo a cavalcare un cavallo, tirare con l'arco e accudire gli animali. Ella gli insegnò anche che gli alleati erano fondamentali per la sopravvivenza, lezione che Temujin apprese alla perfezione. Poco prima di compiere vent'anni, Temujin aveva riunito intorno a sé un gruppo di vassalli leali, con i quali aveva condiviso le spoglie di guerra. Inoltre, divenne fratello di sangue con i membri delle maggiori famiglie nobili dei Mongoli. Tuttavia, Temujin era innanzitutto una persona pratica: avrebbe mantenuto la sua amicizia con questi leader finché gli sarebbero tornati utili e li avrebbe abbandonati o traditi non appena se ne fosse presentato il bisogno.[PARAGRAPH:1]Temujin acquisì potere e prestigio e venne infine accettato come leader di tutti i Mongoli. Riorganizzò l'esercito e promosse gli uomini capaci, piuttosto che quelli di nobile nascita: questo gli concesse il fermo appoggio dei soldati e degli ufficiali comuni. Una volta eliminati i nemici interni, Temujin venne nominato "Genghis Khan", ovvero "dominatore oceanico" o anche "feroce governatore". Dopo aver reso solida la propria posizione in patria, Khan diede iniziò alla sua straordinaria serie di conquiste attraverso l'Asia e l'Europa.[PARAGRAPH:1]Genghis Khan era più interessato alla vittoria che alla gloria della battaglia: prima di attaccare un paese, Khan inviava ai governatori locali un "ordine di sottomissione", nel quale chiedeva la resa immediata. Se i governatori accettavano, avrebbero potuto continuare a governare, fornendogli dei tributi in denaro e manodopera, altrimenti non avrebbero ricevuto alcuna pietà una volta sconfitti.[PARAGRAPH:1]Come capo politico, Genghis Khan adottò una linea di tolleranza religiosa, che smorzò le tensioni con i sacerdoti locali. Egli reclutava anche degli stranieri per coprire le cariche di ufficiali dell'esercito e del governo, fornendo ai suoi uomini un ulteriore motivo per supportarlo, piuttosto che complottare alle sue spalle. Emanò una serie di leggi per le terre conquistate che, tra le altre cose, punivano con la morte il furto di cavalli e aggravavano le pene per la disobbedienza dei soldati. Infine, consentì il commerciò con l'Europa e per la prima volta ai mercanti europei fu concesso di raggiungere la Cina in (relativa) sicurezza.[PARAGRAPH:1]Come capo militare, Genghis Khan fu eccezionale: mantenne una stretta disciplina tra le truppe, punendole severamente per qualsiasi infrazione. Sviluppò un'avanzata rete informativa per tutta l'Asia e sfruttò le informazioni ottenute per progettare accuratamente le campagne militari, sfruttando i punti deboli dei nemici. Anche le truppe di Genghis Khan erano straordinarie: i Mongoli erano degli eccellenti cavalleggeri e la loro abilità con l'arco in sella era incredibile. Inizialmente, l'esercito non era esperto nelle arti della guerra d'assedio, ma, mano a mano che i nemici rifiutarono di affrontare le truppe in campo aperto, i suoi uomini acquisirono dimestichezza con le catapulte e gli altri strumenti per l'assedio delle fortificazioni.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le prima campagne militari di Genghis Khan si svolsero contro i Tanguti, che controllavano le proficue rotte commerciali tra l'Est e l'Ovest. Dopo averli soggiogati, Khan sconfisse gli altri nemici dell'Asia Centrale e della Cina del Nord. Nessuno poteva opporsi alla sua avanzata. Durante la sua ultima e straordinaria campagna, partì con 200.000 guerrieri e conquistò, in ordine, Bukhara, Samarcanda, Balkh, Nishapur e Herat. Dopo essere rimasto in Asia Centrale per quattro anni, Genghis Khan fece ritorno a casa, morendo lungo il viaggio.[PARAGRAPH:1]Più di un barbaro e meno di un governatore illuminato, Genghis Khan rimane uno dei re guerrieri più straordinari di tutti i tempi.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Gengis Kan [\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Kan del imperio mongol [\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió: [\BOLD] 1152/1167 - 1227[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]El kan que fundaría el imperio más grande del mundo nació con el nombre de Temujin. A su muerte, su imperio comprendía casi catorce millones de millas cuadradas y cien millones de personas, casi la mitad de la población del mundo en aquel entonces. [PARAGRAPH:1]Temujin nació en una familia de la baja nobleza mongola. Su padre fue asesinado cuando él tenía nueve años, y su madre tuvo que enseñarle sola a montar a caballo, a disparar con el arco y a cuidar de los animales. También le enseñó que contar con aliados era vital para garantizarse la supervivencia, una lección que Temujin atesoraría siempre. Antes de que acabara su juventud, ya había reunido un grupo de vasallos muy leales, con los que compartía los despojos de sus campañas. También forjó lazos de sangre con miembros de las principales familias mongolas. Sin embargo, Temujin era por encima de todo un pragmático; conservaría la amistad de estos líderes mientras le conviniera, y los traicionaría o abandonaría cuando fuese necesario. [PARAGRAPH:1]Poco a poco, su poder e influencia fueron aumentando, hasta que finalmente fue aceptado como líder de todos los mongoles. Reorganizó el ejército, promocionando a los hombres en función de su competencia y no de su ascendencia. Esto le proporcionó el apoyo incondicional de los soldados y los oficiales. Tras derrotar al último de sus adversarios internos, Temujin recibió el nombre de "Gengis Kan," que significa "Señor Oceánico" (o, posiblemente "Señor Fiero"). Tras asegurar su posición en su propio país, Kan inició una extraordinaria serie de conquistas por Asia y Europa. [PARAGRAPH:1]Por encima de la gloria en el campo de batalla, lo que interesaba a Gengis Kan era la victoria. Antes de atacar una ciudad o un país, enviaba a sus gobernantes unas "órdenes de sumisión" en las que exigía una rendición inmediata. Si obedecían, los gobernantes podían conservar el puesto mientras le proporcionaran un tributo en metálico y en mano de obra. Si se negaban, podían esperar poca piedad una vez derrotados. [PARAGRAPH:1]Como líder político, Gengis Kan adoptó una política de tolerancia religiosa que facilitó las relaciones con los sacerdotes de cada región. Reclutó extranjeros para que lo ayudaran en el ejército y el gobierno, permitiendo que ascendieran en función de sus méritos. Con esta medida daba a los más capaces una razón para apoyarlo en lugar de conspirar en su contra. Promulgó una serie de leyes para los territorios conquistados que, por poner varios ejemplos, establecían la pena capital para el robo de caballos e imponían severos castigos para los soldados desobedientes. También permitió que el comercio con Europa fluyera sin interrupciones y así, por primera vez, fue posible que los mercaderes europeos viajaran hasta China con (relativa) seguridad. [PARAGRAPH:1]Como líder militar, Gengis Kan fue excepcional. Mantenía una rígida disciplina entre sus tropas, castigando severamente las infracciones. Desarrolló una sofisticada red de inteligencia por toda Asia, y utilizó la información obtenida de este modo para planear hábiles campañas que explotaban al máximo las debilidades del enemigo. Sus tropas también eran extraordinarias. La caballería ligera mongola era formidable y su capacidad para disparar sin desmontar, prodigiosa. Al principio sus ejércitos no dominaban el arte del asedio, pero a medida que aumentaba el número de enemigos que se negaban a luchar contra ellos a campo abierto, sus hombres fueron dominando las catapultas y demás instrumentos de poliorcética. [PARAGRAPH:1]Las primeras campañas de Gengis Kan se llevaron a cabo contra los tanguts, quienes controlaban las lucrativas rutas mercantiles que separaban el este y el oeste. Tras vencerlos, derrotó a otros enemigos en el centro de Asia y el norte de China. Nadie podía resistírsele. Durante su última y más extraordinaria campaña, reclutó un ejército de 200.000 guerreros, con el que capturó Bukhara, Samarkanda, Balkh, Nishapur y Herat, una detrás de otra. Tras pasar cuatro años en Asia central, regresó a su hogar, pero la muerte lo alcanzó antes de llegar. [PARAGRAPH:1]Gengis Kan, que no era ni un bárbaro ni un gobernante ilustrado, sino algo intermedio entre ambos, sigue siendo uno de los más extraordinarios caudillos guerreros de todos los tiempos.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Karakhanids were a Turkic dynasty that ruled parts of Central Asia from the 9th through early 13th centuries. Their arrival in Transoxania signaled a definitive shift from Iranian to Turkic predominance in Central Asia, though the Karakhanids themselves gradually assimilated the local Perso-Arab Muslim culture. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Kara-Khanid Khanate was a confederation formed in the early 9th century by the Karluks, Yagmas, Chigils, and other Turkic peoples living in the Zhetysu, Western Tian Shan, and Western Xinjiang areas. By the mid-10th century, the Karakhanids had converted to Islam, and adopted Muslim names and honorifics while retaining Turkic regnal titles such as Khan, Khagan, Ilek and Tegin. Later on their rulers adopted the title sultan, though as was common of Turkic and Mongol nomads the Kara-Khanid state remained divided into appanages. By 950, they had absorbed Kashgar and were waging religious war against their Buddhist and Tengrist neighbors, reportedly prompting a mass conversion of Turks in the year 960.[PARAGRAPH:1]Starting in 990 the Karakhanids began full scale invasions of the Samanid domains. By 999, the Samanids had been largely destroyed and their lands split between the Karakhanids and the Ghaznavids. In 1006, the Buddhist Kingdom of Khotan was conquered, and the Kara-Khanid state was at its greatest extent and arguable peak. Early in the 11th century however, the unity of the Kara-Khanid dynasty was fractured by frequent internal warfare, and the state was eventually split into two independent parts. This disunity would contribute to the Karakhanids being successively vassalized or conquered by their more powerful neighbors, including the Seljuks and the Kara Khitai. They were finally extinguised in the early 13th century by the the Khwarezmshah, the Kara Khitai, and the Mongols.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Shaybanids are the patrilineal descendants of Shayban (Shiban), the fifth son of Jochi and grandson of Genghis Khan. Until the mid-14th century, they acknowledged the authority of the descendants of Batu Khan and Orda Khan, such as Uzbeg Khan. The Shaybanid horde was converted to Islam in 1282 and gradually assumed the name of Uzbeks.[PARAGRAPH:1]As the lineages of Batu and Orda died out in the course of the great civil wars of the 14th century, the Shaybanids under Abu'l-Khayr Khan declared themselves the only legitimate successors to Jochi and put forward claims to the whole of his enormous ulus, which included parts of Siberia and Kazakhstan. Their rivals were the Timurids, who claimed descent from Jochi's thirteenth son by a concubine. Several decades of strife left the Timurids in control of the Great Horde and its successor states in Europe, namely, the Khanates of Kazan, Astrakhan, and Crimea.[PARAGRAPH:1]However, the Shaybanids under Muhammad Shaybani were able to wrest control of Samarkand, Bukhara and (for a time) Herat from the Timurids, establishing the Shaybanid dynasty as rulers of the independent Khanates of Bukhora and Khwarezm (Khiva).

TEXT.English: [H1]Duwa[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Khan of the Chagatai Khanate[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 1282 - 1307[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Duwa was the second son of Chagatai khan Baraq. Kaidu, who held much of the power in the khanate, appointed Duwa as ruler in an effort to gain peace between himself and the sons of Baraq. This ensured the loyalty of the Chaghataids from that point until Kaidu's death. In early 1295, Kaidu's attempts to spread his power within the Ilkhanate gave Duwa an excuse to invade that Mongol kingdom. Supported by Kaidu's son Sarban, he invaded Khurasan and Mazandaran while the Ilkhanid commanders were involved in a succession struggle far to the west. For eight months he stayed in Mazandaran; when he left, he pillaged many cities on the way back. Duwa attempted to convince the Kartids of Herat to defect to his side, but they refused. Due to a lack of progress he was recalled by Kaidu back to Central Asia, and the campaign ended.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the east, Duwa was engaged in constant conflict with the Yuan dynasty. When Kaidu died after battling against the Yuan, the political situation changed. Duwa ignored Kaidu's choice of successor, Orus, and instead picked Kaidu's firstborn son Chapar to take his father's place. Chapar was enthroned in 1303, thanks to Duwa's effort. Duwa insisted Chapar submit to Temur Khan, and around 1304 a general peace among the Mongol states was declared, finally ending the Kaidu-Kublai war. The settlement favored Duwa much more than Chapar, a fact which set a rift between the two. Fighting broke out between the troops of both parties, and the sons of Kaidu were ultimately defeated by Duwa with assistance from the Yuan. In 1307 Duwa died, to be succeeded by his own son Konchek.
TEXT.French: [H1]Merkurios[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ruler of Nubian kingdom of Makuria[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned:[\BOLD] 697 - c.722[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Merkurios was ruler of the Nubian kingdom of Makuria. During his reign Makuria absorbed the Nubian kingdom of Nobatia. The first year of Merkurios' reign can be dated by an inscription on the foundation stone in Faras, which was dated to AD 707, and also to Merkurios' eleventh regnal year. In 710, Merkurios erected an inscription at Taifa, which indicates that his kingdom had united with Nobatia by that date. John the Deacon, an Egyptian Christian writing around 768, described Merkurios as the "New Constantine", which means that Merkurios likely played some important role in the Nubian church.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Kingdom of Makuria was a kingdom located in what is today Northern Sudan and Southern Egypt. It was one of a group of Nubian kingdoms that emerged during the decline of the Aksumite Empire, which it had been part of from approximately 4BC to AD 950. Makuria originally covered the area along the Nile River from the Third Cataract to somewhere between the Fifth and Sixth Cataracts. It also had control over the trade routes, mines, and oases to the east and west. Its capital was Dongola (Old Nubian: Tungul), and the kingdom is sometimes known by the name of its capital.[PARAGRAPH:1]By the end of the 6th century it had converted to Christianity, but in the 7th century Egypt was conquered by the Islamic armies, and Nubia was cut off from the rest of Christendom. In 651 an Arab army invaded, but it was repulsed and a treaty known as the baqt was signed creating a relative peace between the two sides that lasted until the 13th century. Makuria expanded, annexing its northern neighbour Nobatia either at the time of the Arab invasion or during the reign of King Merkurios. The period from roughly 750 to 1150 saw the kingdom stable and prosperous, in what has been called the "Golden Age". Increased aggression from Egypt, and internal discord led to the state's collapse in the 14th century.
